He does not try to compete with Ms. Fey as she bounces from furious hauteur to dizzy desperation but instead nimbly returns her volleys of comic energy.

The two of them are fun to watch, though not as much fun as they might have been in a riskier, crazier movie. The best scenes belong to Lily Tomlin, brilliantly cast as Portiaâ€™s mother, an unbowed second-wave woman warrior with a pair of borzois and a Bella Abzug tattoo. In the history of American comedy, Ms. Tomlin sort of is Ms. Feyâ€™s mother, and the on-screen ambivalence of the relationship gestures toward Ms. Feyâ€™s complicated relationship with her precursors. (This theme was memorably explored in an episode of â€œ30 Rockâ€ù featuring Carrie Fisher as a pioneering television writer who turns out to be a bitter, boozy wreck.)

Mr. Weitz, with and without the collaboration of his brother, Chris, has a mellow, off-speed approach to screwball situations. What is disarming, and sometimes frustrating, about â€œAdmissionâ€ù is its niceness, an acceptance of the way things are that splits the difference between tolerance and complacency. Late in the game, the dean warns Portia that if some of the liberties she has taken in admitting Princetonâ€™s new class were ever to come to light, â€œthe whole system would fall apart.â€ù

â€œWe wouldnâ€™t want that,â€ù she says, and though the film notes her sarcasm, it also essentially affirms her acceptance of the status quo. Mr. Weitz tends to regard potentially infuriating aspects of contemporary American society with more of a raised eyebrow than a clenched fist. â€œIn Good Company,â€ù his 2004 glance at predatory business practices, and â€œAmerican Dreamz,â€ù his 2006 musical mockery of Bush-era politics and reality television, are both notable for their niceness, and â€œAdmissionâ€ù is similarly nonconfrontational.
And also strangely tentative, as if it could not quite figure out what kind of movie it wanted to be. â€œJust be yourself!â€ù Portia would say. And then she would put it on the waiting list.
â€œAdmissionâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Discreet sex, tame swearing and shocking SAT scores.

The title of Ana Piterbargâ€™s moody not-quite-a-thriller â€œEverybody Has a Planâ€ù doesnâ€™t apply to its protagonist, AgustÃ_n (Viggo Mortensen). He has an acute, unmooring malaise that has left him almost blank. A pediatrician in Buenos Aires, he drops out of his life and holes up in his study, growing a beard and growing strange.
AgustÃ_n, though, gets a second act built on an ugly deed. He assumes the identity of his twin, Pedro, and enters Pedroâ€™s world, the Tigre Delta, in search of he knows not what.

Ms. Piterbarg, who wrote and directed, makes the delta â€” a bayoulike landscape of mist-shrouded waters and far-apart dwellings â€” an eerie place out of time. With its lonely expanses, outlaw inhabitants (Pedro has been involved in various misdeeds) and bursts of violence, it could be the setting for an Argentine western. Thatâ€™s not a bad way to think about â€œEverybody Has a Plan,â€ù in which the fight between good and evil plays out not at high noon but in AgustÃ_n.

Mr. Mortensen, who grew up in Venezuela and Argentina and speaks a fine, mumbly Spanish, does an excellent, unflashy job of making the two brothers distinct. The dead-eyed Pedro has an extra layer of scruff that the sad-eyed AgustÃ_n canâ€™t approach, even with his beard and his dingy sweaters and flannels.

And Mr. Mortensen keeps you watching, even when the movieâ€™s storytelling underwhelms. But â€œEverybody Has a Planâ€ù is less about story than about texture and atmosphere. They stay with you, as does the haunted visage of AgustÃ_n, drifting on the delta waters.
â€œEverybody Has a Planâ€ù is rated R (under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Sex, hacking-knife violence and brooding.

â€œGimme the Loot,â€ù Adam Leonâ€™s loose and rambunctious debut feature, tells the tale of two young artists scrambling to kick-start an ambitious project. Or, if you prefer, it follows a pair of vandals through a day of improvised criminality. Really, though, itâ€™s both: a celebration of outlaw creativity and entrepreneurial gumption.

Malcolm (Ty Hickson) and Sofia (Tashiana Washington) are Bronx graffiti writers who conceive an ambitious plan to tag the big plastic apple that pops up in Citi Field every time the Mets hit a home run. (They refuse to use the name of the Metsâ€™ new home, calling it Shea Stadium.) The pair need $500 to finance this venture, and in the course of a long, hot day they zigzag across New York trying to raise the money by stealing, selling weed and other devious, dubious means.

The movieâ€™s title evokes the menace and swagger of Notorious B.I.G., but its spirit is closer to the bouncy mischief of earlier, 1980s hip-hop. Though Malcolm and Sofia â€” especially Sofia â€” like to talk tough and strike thuggish poses, there is something sweet about their eagerness to prove themselves. â€œBombingâ€ù the apple, they believe, will make them legends in the graffiti world and beyond, and Mr. Leon both respects their dream and views it as a romantic, almost childlike fantasy.

He also has an acute eye and ear for the sights and sounds of the real New York. An encounter between Malcolm and a (relatively) rich Manhattan girl (ZoÃ« Lescaze) â€” a client of the pot merchants whose product Malcolm is peddling â€” is a sly and eloquent mini-film about sex, race and class in the city. And â€œGimme the Lootâ€ù has a lot to say about the contradictions of a place that is defined by both abundant opportunity and ferocious inequality.

But the film makes its points in a lighthearted, street-smart vernacular, treating its protagonists not as embodiments of a social condition but rather as self-aware individuals who are, like teenagers everywhere, both smart and dumb. Their friendship â€” which is based above all on shared artistic ambitions â€” is a perfect comic pairing. Sofia is intense and unsmiling, while Malcolm is a charming, goofy chatterbox, and they make a vivid impression, even without spray paint.

The British punk-rock explosion was only months from detonation in the early summer of 1976, the time of Marc Evansâ€™s high school musical, â€œHunky Dory.â€ù This sun-bleached, candy-colored movie is set in southern Wales, where Vivienne Mae (Minnie Driver), a passionate, feisty drama teacher, mobilizes her apathetic students to stage a rock opera based on Shakespeareâ€™s â€œTempestâ€ù in the final weeks of the school year. The score will consist of existing rock songs.

At various moments this endearing but sudsy movie, which spills all over the place, evokes â€œHigh School Musical,â€ù â€œGleeâ€ù and â€œBilly Elliot.â€ù But unlike them, it feels less like a corporate product than like an earnest, eccentric expression of its creatorsâ€™ nostalgia for the twilight of a musical lotus land before the Sex Pistols and the Clash changed everything. The closest thing to a rock god is David Bowie, whose â€œLife on Mars?â€ù stands as the unofficial theme song of â€œThe Tempest.â€ù

Vivienne is the most progressive voice at a hidebound institution whose prim archvillain, Miss Valentine (Haydn Gwynne), condescendingly informs her students that she is â€œmiddle class,â€ù and that they are â€œworking class.â€ù Predictably, the loutish physical education teacher, Mr. Cafferty (Steve Speirs), is also contemptuous of artistic expression. But Vivienne has an ally in the schoolâ€™s headmaster (Bob Pugh), who bravely assumes the role of Prospero after a student drops out.

The movie is an overstuffed, disorganized potpourri of rehearsals and student melodramas anchored in Ms. Driverâ€™s spunky performance. Davy (Aneurin Barnard), the handsome, dreamy-eyed student who plays Ferdinand, is in love with Stella (Danielle Branch), the productionâ€™s Miranda, who wonâ€™t give him the time of day. Davy is so bereft he briefly transfers his yearnings to Vivienne, who deftly deals with his crush.

Evan (Tom Harries), the blond, curly-haired boy who portrays Ariel, is questioning his sexuality and discreetly pines after Davy. The showâ€™s Caliban, Kenny (Darren Evans), is a skinhead with a strong voice who canâ€™t take his classmatesâ€™ teasing and drops out.

The unusual use of music in â€œHunky Doryâ€ù puts the movie in its own niche. The arrangements for the Hunky Dory Orchestra are sophisticated, and their tone unabashedly romantic. Ferdinand and Mirandaâ€™s love song, â€œDonâ€™t Talk,â€ù by the Beach Boys, has rarely sounded better. One of Arielâ€™s numbers conjuring magic is Nick Drakeâ€™s haunting â€œCello Song,â€ù beautifully crooned by Mr. Harries. Calibanâ€™s ballad of alienation is David Crosbyâ€™s brooding â€œEverybodyâ€™s Been Burned.â€ù The Electric Light Orchestraâ€™s â€œStrange Magic,â€ù â€œOne Summer Dreamâ€ù and â€œLivinâ€™ Thingâ€ù are also heard and relate effectively to the Shakespeare play.
After many mishaps, including a fire that nearly burns down the school, the elaborate production is finally staged outdoors. What little we see of it is charming.

What could this nostalgic, softhearted pop fantasy mean to todayâ€™s young audience? Will any of its songs be remotely familiar to moviegoers born after 1980? Pop memories are short. If the world conjured by â€œHunky Doryâ€ù is sweetly appealing, it has all the pertinence of a dream half-remembered from long ago.

Who is Leonie Gilmour and why does she rank her own biopic? For the writers of â€œLeonie,â€ù Hisako Matsui (who also directed) and David Wiener, the short answer is that sheâ€™s the mother of the sculptor Isamu Noguchi. And the long answer is this plodding film.Leonie (Emily Mortimer, who against all odds creates a credible character) meets and falls in love with a Japanese poet, Yone Noguchi, who is living in New York. She becomes his editor, lover and the mother of his child. For some reason â€” motivations in â€œLeonieâ€ù are either murky or too neatly explained â€” he dumps her when sheâ€™s pregnant and moves back to Japan. She joins him there, but their relationship is over, and she strikes out on her own.

â€œLeonieâ€ù doesnâ€™t stint on the biopic mush. Thereâ€™s golden light to evoke the past; pretty violin music to punctuate scenes; and a voice-over by the older Leonie that delivers nuggets like this: â€œI have always believed that when everything is lost, the future still remains.â€ù

The filmmakers paint Leonie as a free spirit, an instinctive feminist who loves whom she chooses and lives as she wants. Playing Leonieâ€™s best friend, Christina Hendricks illustrates the opposite, a woman whose spirit has been quashed by a conventional marriage. Thatâ€™s how the storytelling works: it telegraphs and draws lessons, the biggest being that Leonieâ€™s example and support made an artist of Isamu. (She has him design their new house when heâ€™s 10.)
Leonie Gilmour was almost certainly unusual and unusually self-reliant. Too bad that the film that bears her name ultimately reduces her to the mother of her child.
â€œLeonieâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Brief nudity before the door is shut on Leonieâ€™s sexuality.

â€œWe have to run now!â€ù are five words no heavily pregnant woman ever wants to hear, though when the alternative is being beaten to a bloody pulp by a gang of feral children, a cumbersome belly seems the least of your problems.

And so it proves for Beth (Vinessa Shaw), near term and vacationing in Mexico with her husband, Francis (Ebon Moss-Bachrach), in â€œCome Out and Play.â€ù The latest entry in a subgenre best described as the contraceptive horror movie â€” other examples include â€œChildren of the Cornâ€ù and â€œVillage of the Damnedâ€ù â€” this chilly excursion by the Belarussian writer and director Makinov (a nom de guerre) favors atmosphere over plot and nihilism over hope.

Remaking the little-seen 1976 shocker â€œWho Can Kill a Child?,â€ù Makinov transports the couple to a picturesque island that seems eerily devoid of adults. Silently glowering rugrats pepper the dock, but streets and stores remain ominously deserted. And though we are teased with random glimpses of what has happened and what might lie ahead, the film maintains a deliberately unhurried pace that builds tension naturally and with minimum interference from the soundtrack.

Stripped down and edited for disequilibrium rather than clarity, â€œPlayâ€ù is less interested in pandering to gorehounds than in highlighting our reluctance to view children as anything other than innocent. Cleverly manipulating sunlight and shadow, Makinov â€” an odd duck who works in a mask and believes modern life is â€œstupidâ€ù â€” presents us with tykes whose idea of fun is to fashion necklaces from severed ears. Letâ€™s hope none of the crafters on Etsy are watching.

For the American military June 28, 2005, was a very bad day. A four-man Navy SEAL reconnaissance team in the Hindu Kush region of Afghanistan had been caught in a mountainside firefight with overwhelming Taliban forces, and the Special Operations helicopter sent to extract them was shot down. The 16 men aboard died, as did 3 of the 4 team members on the ground. (The one who lived, Marcus Luttrell, wrote a best-selling account, â€œLone Survivorâ€ù; the major-motion-picture version, starring Mark Wahlberg, is scheduled for release next fall.)

â€œMurph: The Protectorâ€ù is a short, spare documentary about Lt. Michael P. Murphy, the SEAL team leader awarded the Medal of Honor posthumously in 2007. Mr. Murphy, a Long Island native, is recalled as a stand-up son, brother and friend, a lifeguard at Lake Ronkonkoma Beach, a graduate from Penn State who surprised those close to him with declaring his intent to enter the Navyâ€™s elite SEAL unit. â€œYou donâ€™t wish that for your son, to be put in harmâ€™s way,â€ù says his father, Daniel Murphy, himself a Vietnam veteran who was wounded in action.

Weâ€™re told of Mr. Murphyâ€™s perseverance in achieving his goal. But limited to what his family and friends can describe â€” there is virtually no video of Mr. Murphy â€” the film doesnâ€™t give a full sense of its subject. Instead, it works best as a report from stateside: the early news of the firefight; the visit from Navy officers; the drive up from Dover Air Force Base in Delaware, escorted by police units along the way, to burial at Calverton National Cemetery. The honors came after, including the naming of a new destroyer and the Medal of Honor, which was the first given for combat in Afghanistan. As operations there wind down, â€œMurph: The Protectorâ€ù reminds us of the valor expended on distant front lines and the holes left at home.
â€œMurph: The Protectorâ€ù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested) for themes of war and death.

The most recent â€œDie Hardâ€ù movie â€” which the record shows I reviewed a little more than a month ago, although I have no recollection of it â€” was terrible, but it turns out not to have been the worst â€œDie Hardâ€ù movie this year. That honor, for the moment at least (itâ€™s only March!), belongs to â€œOlympus Has Fallen,â€ù which is not, strictly speaking, part of the franchise at all. It is more a â€œschool of Die Hardâ€ù production, in which a weary and battered law enforcement professional, severely constrained by time and space, fights off a ridiculous number of bad guys.

The bad guys in this case are the North Korean minions of a nasty superterrorist (Rick Yune), the setting is the White House, and the Bruce Willis understudy is meaty old Gerard Butler, playing a knocked-around Secret Service agent named Mike Banning. Banning was part of the presidentâ€™s security detail â€” and buddies with Potusâ€™s young son, Connor (Finley Jacobsen) â€” until a tragic accident got him exiled to the Treasury Department. The same accident removed Ashley Judd from the picture, for which she can be both mourned and envied.

The square-jawed commander in chief (Aaron Eckhart) is held hostage in a bunker beneath 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, along with the vice president and some cabinet members, notably the secretary of defense (Melissa Leo). Meanwhile, in another location, Angela Bassett, Morgan Freeman and Robert Forster earn some money barking out orders and looking at screens full of intel. The body count is high, the action is mean and bloody, and digital reproductions of popular Washington landmarks take a terrible beating

All of which â€” and Dylan McDermott as a turncoat former colleague of Banningâ€™s â€” is more or less what you would expect. And the director, Antoine Fuqua, is skilled at orchestrating both hand-to-hand mayhem and large-scale explosions. It may be too much to ask for anything more, but, on the other hand, if youâ€™re going to go to the trouble of pretending to blow up the White House, you might also want to pretend that something was at stake.

Sadly, Mr. Butler lacks the wit and the range to convey anything other than grouchy belligerence, and the script, by Creighton Rothenberger and Katrin Benedikt, seems intent on squandering opportunities to be clever or interesting. The motivations of the villains are fairly straightforward, and what seem like promising implications of an elaborate conspiracy are discarded, as is the possibility of a â€œHome Alone: The White Houseâ€ù caper involving Connor.

But viewers who need a dose of bloated, moronic pseudo-patriotism right now may appreciate â€œOlympus Has Fallen,â€ù at least as a stopgap until the similar-looking â€œWhite House Downâ€ù opens in June. Iâ€™d say it canâ€™t be worse than this, but who am I kidding?
â€œOlympus Has Fallenâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Blood and bad words.

The animated â€œSilver Circleâ€ù is set in a dystopian Washington in 2019, when the Federal Reserve Police, in riot gear, are forcibly seizing houses from homeowners when they refuse to sell them to the government. At the same time, inflation runs amok, and working-class people turn to an underground economy, using silver for money. Societyâ€™s ills, you see, stem from all that paper money circulating.

But an insurrection is afoot, evidenced by a protest singer wearing a Ron Paul T-shirt, who intones, â€œListen to the words of the man with the rifle in his hand/â€˜Donâ€™t be mistaken, I believe in peace but I wonâ€™t be taken.â€™Â â€ù When a Federal Reserve investigator (voiced by Deâ€™Lon Grant) researches a case of arson on Federal Reserve Bank properties, he meets Zoe (Philana Mia), a pistol-packing revolutionary handy at the wheel in a car chase. Soon he is pulled into a conspiratorial web of romance, violence and excruciatingly trite dialogue.

According to the filmâ€™s Web site, an organization called American Film Renaissance is the productionâ€™s â€œfiscal sponsorâ€ù; that group has screened films like David Zuckerâ€™s clumsy Michael Moore parody, â€œAn American Carol,â€ù at its festival. â€œSilver Circle,â€ù directed by Pasha Roberts, has a similarly arch, polemical zeal. It also offers cold, sterile, cheap-looking computer animation vastly inferior to that of most video games. Ron Paul acolytes, help yourself. Everyone else, stay away.
â€œSilver Circleâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for violence, strong language, drug use and mild sexual situations.

â€œIâ€™m just a meat delivery guy and a terrible one at that,â€ù declares David Wozniak (Patrick Huard), a lovable oaf in â€œStarbuck,â€ù Ken Scottâ€™s sloppy, feel-good French Canadian comedy. David, who is 42 and works in his fatherâ€™s butcher shop, has one claim to fame, should he ever decide to shed his anonymity.

Under the pseudonym Starbuck (the actual name of a famously fertile Canadian Holstein bull), he made 693 sperm donations to a clinic between 1988 and 1990 that resulted in 533 births. Until a class-action suit is filed against the clinic by 142 offspring demanding to know Starbuckâ€™s identity, David has all but forgotten his seminal spree.

This shamelessly sentimental movie relies on the likable performance of Mr. Huard, a stocky, soulful actor who infuses David with an endearing, bleeding-heart humanity. For reasons that are never given, David is $80,000 in debt, and the shady lenders want their money back. Davidâ€™s girlfriend, ValÃ©rie (Julie Le Breton), is pregnant, but his history of unreliability keeps her from trusting him.

Davidâ€™s life changes when he is given a folder with the photos and profiles of his progeny, and he surreptitiously looks them up, one by one. His conscience pricked, he anoints himself their guardian angel without revealing his identity and does good deeds on their behalf.

With the exception of ValÃ©rie, female characters are all but absent in this movie, which doesnâ€™t even acknowledge the existence of the plaintiffsâ€™ birth mothers. â€œStarbuckâ€ù is so father-centric as to imply unintentionally that Davidâ€™s children sprang full-blown from the plastic cups into which he deposited his sperm while ogling girlie magazines.
By the time David, ValÃ©rie and their newborn and Davidâ€™s other progeny swarm into a euphoric group hug, â€œStarbuckâ€ù is up to its eyeballs in mush. You may want to regurgitate.
â€œStarbuckâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for sexual content.

â€œThe Croodsâ€ù makes a better study of Stone Age sociology than it does a childrenâ€™s movie. But itâ€™s colorful and has an appealing central character and â€” who knows? â€” might even give the little ones something more challenging to think about than its tired main plot.

First, about that plot: Once again, a rebellious, presumably teenage girl, Eep, is butting heads with her overprotective father, Grug. Criminy; is there no other family dynamic available for exploration out there in animated-movie land? Anyway, Grug (the voice of Nicolas Cage) is intent on keeping Eep and the rest of his prehistoric family safe in their cave. His mantra: â€œNever not be afraid.â€ù Curiosity and exploration are bad.

But Eep sneaks out and encounters a young stranger, Guy (Ryan Reynolds), who has an encyclopedic level of knowledge compared with what the Croods have managed to accumulate. There are also hints that he is of a different, higher-functioning species, which puts the budding romance between Eep and Guy in a crossbreeding zone that modern paleontologists are still debating.

In any case, the movie is at its most interesting and amusing when riffing on how cavemen might have reacted to new experiences and ideas, like fire and shoes. Whether the kiddies will appreciate that is unclear, but theyâ€™ll certainly like the voice work done by Emma Stone as Eep. She puts refreshing spunk into a character who otherwise is, alas, doomed to follow the same old story line.
â€œThe Croodsâ€ù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested) because, as Grug knew, the prehistoric world was often a scary place.

â€œThe Sapphiresâ€ù tells the story of an all-female singing quartet on the way to stardom in the 1960s. As is usual in such tales, the group, known as the Cummeragunja Songbirds before their gemological rechristening, faces its share of obstacles, but in spite of internal disharmony and tough circumstances, the singersâ€™ voices rarely falter.

The movie itself, directed by Wayne Blair from a script by Keith Thompson and Tony Briggs, is sort of the opposite â€” a solid, stirring song sung with more sincerity than polish. (It is inspired by a true story; one of the real Sapphires, Beverley Briggs, is Mr. Briggsâ€™s mother.) But the raggedness of â€œThe Sapphiresâ€ù canâ€™t be separated from its exuberant charm. Like the Sapphires themselves, the film is determined to muscle its way into your heart, which would have to be a lump of gristle to resist it.

Three of the four singers â€” Gail (Deborah Mailman), Julie (Jessica Mauboy) and Cynthia (Miranda Tapsell), who are sisters â€” live on a dusty reservation in the Australian outback, members of that countryâ€™s despised and oppressed Aboriginal population. Traveling into town to perform at a talent competition, they are greeted with racist taunts and denied the victory that they have obviously earned. But they do catch the bleary eye of Dave Lovelace (Chris Oâ€™Dowd), an itinerant Irish promoter whose great passions in life are liquor and American popular music, especially R&B.

At that point the Sapphiresâ€™ repertory tends more toward Merle Haggard than Aretha Franklin, and it falls to Dave to persuade them that their true musical affinity, as women who identify themselves as black, is with African-American artists on the other side of the world. This is somewhat opportunistic on Daveâ€™s part â€” he sees a lucrative future for the girls entertaining the â€œsoul brothersâ€ù serving in Vietnam â€” but also a sharp historical insight. The local discrimination that the Sapphires suffer is part of a global pattern, and we see their experiences reflected in footage of American racial turmoil and of black pop-culture heroes like Muhammad Ali.

On their way to Vietnam the women and their manager stop in Melbourne to collect a fourth Sapphire, Kay (Shari Sebbens), an Aborigine who was a victim of the Australian governmentâ€™s forced adoption policy. This shockingly cruel practice â€” the subject of Phillip Noyceâ€™s wonderful 2002 movie, â€œRabbit-Proof Fenceâ€ù â€” took Aboriginal children from their homes and placed them in boarding schools or with white families. (These officially sanctioned kidnappings continued into the 1970s; the Australian government apologized for them this week, reiterating a broader apology issued in 2008.) Kay, painfully confused about her identity, must also confront Gailâ€™s bitter accusations of betrayal. Does Kay think sheâ€™s better than the others because of her lighter skin and relatively privileged upbringing?

In one of his music lessons Dave explains that while country music is based on the embrace of misfortune, soul defiantly insists on hope in the face of misery. And it is true that the genius of Memphis and Motown in the 1960s lay precisely in its alchemical transmutation of specific woe into universal joy. In a similar spirit â€œThe Sapphiresâ€ù turns a heavy load of personal and political trouble â€” war, bigotry, alcoholism, family breakdown â€” into bouncy, spirited entertainment.

The music certainly helps: energetic renditions of classics like â€œWhat a Manâ€ù and â€œI Canâ€™t Help Myself (Sugar Pie Honey Bunch),â€ù as well as original versions of radio hits by Creedence Clearwater Revival and Sam & Dave. But the personalities of the Sapphires themselves carry the movie.

The story is hectic, sometimes to the point of chaos, and the characters are broadly drawn â€” Gail is bossy, Cynthia is boy crazy, while Julie, the youngest and the mother of a baby, possesses the biggest talent â€” but the performances are funny and full of credible emotion. Mr. Oâ€™Dowd, an easygoing comic actor (as seen in â€œBridesmaidsâ€ù and â€œThis Is 40â€ù), seems happy to be along for the ride, and there is no good reason to feel otherwise.
â€œThe Sapphiresâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Some swearing and some scary wartime moments.

Unlike some nonfiction tales of grace under adversity, â€œYou Donâ€™t Need Feet to Danceâ€ù leaves in the mundane obstacles rather than skipping to reassuring triumph. Low-key to a fault, Alan Govenarâ€™s vÃ©ritÃ© documentary joins the Guinean-born drummer and dancer Sidiki Conde on his daily rounds and observes the added labor and gumption required of a working artist who cannot walk or stand.

Mr. Conde, introduced waking up in his East Village apartment, plays traditional West African drums and teaches music to disabled children. His legs withered by childhood polio, he makes his way by means of wheelchair, bike and, in a pinch, his muscular arms. Polite good cheer sees him past an apparently apathetic doorman when he enters a building for a class appointment and encounters double stairs in the foyer. Even exiting his own walk-up with a bag takes that extra bit of effort.

In a film plunked somewhat unfortunately between the inspirational and the ordinary, the impressively patient Mr. Conde voices public-service-announcement sentiments about being able to do as much as anyone else. His past career and the present strain evident on his face go under-explained, and his Guinean accent at times makes his speech hard to follow. None of which matters when Mr. Conde dances briefly and ecstatically on his arms, but surely thereâ€™s more to say about his art and life.
Death is always hovering just out of sight in â€œMy Brother the Devil,â€ù but thereâ€™s nothing deadening about this engaging first feature from the Welsh-Egyptian filmmaker Sally El Hosaini.

Quite the reverse. Invigorating and unpredictable, the story (also by Ms. Hosaini) tracks the forced maturation of two British-born Arab brothers living in an East London tower block. Mo (Fady Elsayed), college-bound and respectful of his Egyptian parents, nevertheless idolizes his older brother, Rashid (James Floyd), whose membership in a neighborhood gang seems glamorous and lucrative. But when tragedy upends their respective paths and Rashid befriends an older French photographer (SaÃ¯d Taghmaoui), his sudden awareness of alternatives to his intellectually and emotionally arid life will prove more destructive than the violence that made it possible.

Rejecting the dreariness of most street-kid dramas, David Raedekerâ€™s cunning photography bathes everything in a rich, golden light that aggressively beautifies the cement-and-convenience-store landscape. Nuances of faith, politics and sexual identity enrich what initially presents as a classic good son-bad son tale, and although the filmâ€™s melting-pot patois is occasionally too dense to decipher, we get the gist. Even without words, the skill of the performers (some of whom are nonprofessionals) and the compassion of their director communicate just fine.

Sometimes a movie is so awful that the word awful is not up to the task of conveying its awfulness. The awful â€œInAPPropriate Comedyâ€ù is such a movie. It is memorably awful. It is stunningly awful. It is so awful that we are fortunate that â€œawfulâ€ù has an adverbial use that means â€œveryâ€ù or â€œextremely.â€ù This movie is awfully awful.

The film, directed by Vince Offer and starring some people whose careers, we can hope, ended the moment it opened, is a sketch-comedy collage whose unifying theme is offensiveness. It ricochets among a half-dozen or so bits: a gay Dirty Harry-like character (Adrien Brody); a bigot (Ari Shaffir) who harasses Jews, blacks and Asians; two film critics (Rob Schneider and Michelle Rodriguez) who specialize in pornographic movies with names like â€œSushi Mama.â€ù Someone poking a tablet computer selects which wretched bit comes next, the source of the â€œappâ€ù affectation in the title.

Some humorists can pull off this type of parody, but the makers of this witless embarrassment arenâ€™t among them. The purpose of comedy like this is to call out offensive behavior by putting it under a glaring spotlight, but who needs that today, when homophobes picket at soldiersâ€™ funerals, and the Internet provides a forum for any variety of hate speech that real-life racists and bigots can dream up?

So â€œInAPPropriate Comedyâ€ù fails just on the basis of its core idea. But the execution is inept as well, with Mr. Offer showing no mastery of comic tone or timing. Bits that start out unfunny (which is to say, all of them) are allowed to just keep going, like a stand-up who is bombing but wonâ€™t get off the stage.
Awful concept, awful writing, awful delivery. â€œInAPPropriate Comedyâ€ù is, in a word, terrible.
â€œInAPPropriate Comedyâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian), though, really, no one of any age should see it.

Watching â€œWelcome to the Punchâ€ù I kept hoping for clowns, the inflatable kind that you sock in the head and that bounce back again and again â€” or maybe a couple of pugilists with tragic faces and Michelangelo musculature. While this curiously titled, intently self-serious British cops-and-robbers showdown doesnâ€™t feature any clowns, it does include plenty of mano-a-mano action and a clutch of presumably unintended laughs. This isnâ€™t a warning. Itâ€™s a recommendation.

There are good movies and plenty more bad ones and many, many more that fall somewhere in between. And then there are enjoyable absurdities like â€œWelcome to the Punch,â€ù which contain evaluative multitudes and which, scene by scene, register as not bad, pretty good and flat-out ridiculous. As such, movies like this hit a very specific cinephile sweet spot. Theyâ€™re decent enough to keep your eyes fixed on the screen, hooking you with performances, pictorial beauty, even a gesture. Yet theyâ€™re also inept enough â€” they strain under the weight of their own illogic, their clumsiness and influences â€” to make you wish you were watching this with your favorite film nerds so you could share in that great communal ritual: talking over the fun bad movie.

The opening of â€œWelcome to the Punchâ€ù (the title refers to a location) begins in a promisingly mysterious room with strong graphic lines, pulsing screens, silky camera moves and a body on the floor. This scene is soon embellished with four men in black suits and gas masks who are carrying big bags and large guns and appear to be executing the final stages of a heist in a glassy tower of power. From their cool and precise choreography as they climb on four black motorcycles, roaring into the desolate icy-blue mean streets, it is immediately evident that the writer and director Eran Creevy, a self-professed genre geek, has absorbed Michael Mannâ€™s crime epic â€œHeatâ€ù into his bloodstream.

The thieves are soon joined in that strangely uninhabited night by a cop, Max Lewinsky (James McAvoy) who, from the looks of his clenched jaw and zooming car, is very angry, very determined and terminally alone. After some cat and mouse among the urban buttes and mesas Max tracks the men to a tunnel. A voice on his police radio sings out warnings about not following them. Max does; heâ€™s that kind of cop or at least that type of genre staple. Resourcefully he corners one of the thieves, Jacob Sternwood (Mark Strong). True to his name, Sternwood coldly shoots Max, but only wounds him. Sternwood is that kind of villain, and this is definitely that kind of movie.

From the way he piles on the sleek surfaces and anomie, Mr. Creevy doesnâ€™t appear to be suffering from the anxiety of influence; instead he seems to be reveling in it. â€œWelcome to the Punchâ€ù doesnâ€™t just owe a debt to Michael Mann it also, in conscious homage or not, skims from Mann-influenced titles like â€œInfernal Affairs,â€ù the great Hong Kong crime trilogy. More than a few sequences in â€œWelcome to the Punch,â€ù including the inaugural chase sequence on empty streets (Where is everybody? you may wonder), suggest as well that Mr. Creevy has made a study of Christopher Nolanâ€™s â€œDark Knightâ€ù series. Unlike Quentin Tarantino, however, whose transformation of his many influences is the foundation of a personal vision, Mr. Creevy engages not in metamorphosis but in simulation.

Part of the pleasure of watching a movie like â€œWelcome to the Punchâ€ù is peeling away the multiple layers of inspiration, isolating the allusions and figuring out if theyâ€™re what works or whether the movie earns a little credit. On the evidence of this one movie Mr. Creevy canâ€™t write worth a lick â€” the dialogue is often risible, the plot complications uninteresting, the twists overly telegraphed â€” but the performances are solid and sometimes better than that, specifically in the case of Mr. Strong, an actor who can find depth even in shallows like these. There are so many familiar faces here â€” Andrea Riseborough, Peter Mullan, David Morrissey, Jason Flemyng, Ruth Sheen â€” that you half expect Daniel Radcliffe to materialize amid the bullets and nonsense. But it isnâ€™t that kind of movie.

Pablo Bergerâ€™s â€œBlancanievesâ€ù combines two recent movie trends: the updating of classic fairy tales and the rediscovery of silent film. Hollywood studios have lately been turning venerable childrenâ€™s bedtime stories â€” â€œLittle Red Riding Hood,â€ù â€œHansel and Gretelâ€ù and of course â€œSnow White,â€ù Mr. Bergerâ€™s source â€” into special-effects-heavy action spectacles. Meanwhile a handful of European directors (notably Michel Hazanavicius, in â€œThe Artist,â€ù and Miguel Gomes, with â€œTabuâ€ù) have been drawn to the archaic glamour of monochrome images, boxy frames, heightened gestures and unheard dialogue.

What unites these tendencies might be a desire to find a way toward the new by means of the old, or else a more basic nostalgia, a longing for magic and wonder in a cynical time. â€œBlancanievesâ€ù deftly blends cinematic antiquarianism, period atmosphere and primal emotions. Set in Spain in the 1920s, it replaces the spooky northern European romanticism of the Brothers Grimm with a swooning, tragic sensibility native to (or perhaps stereotypically associated with) the Iberian Peninsula. The Snow White character, named Carmen, is the daughter of a bullfighter (Daniel GimÃ©nez Cacho) and a flamenco dancer (Inma Cuesta), and her story hums with jealousy, vanity and other volatile passions.

Many of these pulsate in the heart of Carmenâ€™s stepmother, Encarna (Maribel VerdÃº, seen in â€œPanâ€™s Labyrinthâ€ù and â€œY Tu MamÃ¡ TambiÃ©nâ€ù), a delectably wicked villain who is transformed before our eyes from a lovestruck nurse to a perverse and murderous gold digger, as cruel to her husband as she is to his daughter.

Encarna marries the girlâ€™s father after he is paralyzed by a bull named Lucifer. (His wife has died in childbirth after witnessing the injury.) Carmen, played as a wide-eyed, soft-featured child by Sofia Oria, is comforted by the companionship of her father, her grandmother (ÃÅngela Molina) and a mischievous rooster named Pepe, this filmâ€™s answer to the scrappy terrier that was everyoneâ€™s favorite part of â€œThe Artist.â€ù

There are dwarfs too, who befriend Carmen after she has grown into a lovely and spirited young woman (played by Macarena GarcÃ_a). Also a poisoned apple, though no magic mirror and, strictly speaking, no handsome prince.

As in the Disney cartoon version, the psychosexual subject of the Grimmsâ€™ story â€” which is laced with themes of erotic envy and filial guilt â€” is muted but not entirely suppressed. The gender politics, meanwhile, are decisively updated: Blancanieves (as the dwarfs call Carmencita) is not only a passive princess or a helpful housekeeper, but also a matador, like her dad. And the misogyny that makes Encarna such a monstrous and memorable figure is balanced by the addition of another, male nemesis for her stepdaughter.

Though Mr. Berger conjures lovely antiquarian images â€” and uses Alfonso de Vilallongaâ€™s score to shift the emotional current from seething melodrama to camp to gentle farce â€” â€œBlancanievesâ€ù never quite achieves the uncanny, haunting intensity of the silent films it so studiously and lovingly mimics.

In that respect, it is very much like â€œThe Artist,â€ù which was an enjoyable and admirable entertainment without quite managing to be a great movie. Its emotions felt simplified, rather than enhanced, by the discipline of silence. While â€œBlancanievesâ€ù is less self-conscious â€” though set in the 1920s, it is not about the world of silent films, as such â€” it communicates the delights of pastiche rather than the thrill of original creation, a secondhand movie love that is seductive but not entirely satisfying.
â€œBlancanievesâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Scary images and sexual implications.
Itâ€™s all about protecting the young people, of course. â€œWe stand to lose a whole generation of kids,â€ù Cherrie Brady, a community advocate, says in â€œCode of the West.â€ù

This film from Rebecca Richman Cohen is a mostly dutiful documentary that drifts dangerously close to earnestness. It tells a sad, rage-provoking story about the 2010 campaign to repeal Montanaâ€™s legalization of medical marijuana. (And the â€œGodfatherâ€ù juxtaposition between a legislative vote and federal grow-house raid is creative.)

Opponents contended that the drugâ€™s presence led to increased use among teenagers and that the patients with prescriptions were healthy â€œold hippies.â€ù Too bad the titleâ€™s import is largely lost. The â€œCode of the Westâ€ù was another bill the Montana Legislature considered in 2010, a symbolic list of noble 19th-century cowboy guidelines to live by. But that point â€” that those values are a far cry from what the anti-marijuana forces are demonstrating â€” barely registers.

Tom Daubert, who was indicted as a partner in Montana Cannabis, tries to say something kind about his political opponents and achieves memorable passive-aggression: â€œI think theyâ€™re afraid of the complexity of life.â€ù

But the whole thing comes down to Lori Burnam, navigating her modest home while attached to various tubes. Marijuana, she says, is the only medication that relieves her pain from cancer and emphysema without incapacitating side effects. Near the end of the film she has to switch to morphine. Burnam died in January.

Without knowing how much the actor Neil Hopkins was paid to perform in â€œDetour,â€ù Iâ€™m guessing it wasnâ€™t enough. Like Ryan Reynolds in â€œBuried,â€ù Mr. Hopkins must convey hunger, thirst, physical injury and slow asphyxiation in a confined space; unlike Mr. Reynolds, he must do so within the constraints of a barrel-scraping budget. As his character, Jackson Alder, says at one point, â€œThat canâ€™t be good.â€ù

And it isnâ€™t, especially for a concept thatâ€™s no longer novel. Although the director, William Dickerson, and his writing partner, Dwight Moody, came up with their idea in 2007, since then many of us have seen â€œ127 Hoursâ€ù and a few of us have even seen the Adrien Brody misfire â€œWrecked.â€ù That leaves â€œDetourâ€ù with a wall of audience ennui to scale, and without a major star or a punchy plot innovation, this respectable debut is unlikely to leave a mark.

Too bad, really, because Mr. Hopkins plays the resourceful Jackson with desperate avidity. Knocked unconscious when a mudslide washes his Jeep Cherokee off a California highway, Jackson awakens in a muck-enshrouded prison, his moon roof straining beneath the weight of wet earth. For the next 80-odd minutes he will fight for survival in the slowly tilting vehicle, ingeniously repurposing whatever he can rip from the floor or salvage from the toolbox.

Cellphone video of happier times punctures the misery and relieves the claustrophobia, but the real credit here goes to Ethan Friedericks, whose imaginative sound design maintains a constant sense of threat. At times the groan and scream of collapsing metal sounds so authentic you might mistake Jacksonâ€™s heavy breathing for your own.

Few things can be more embarrassing than being arrested while performing cunnilingus, as the 16-year-old Davis (Shane Kippel) can attest. Nabbed in his bedroom for drug possession while enthusiastically pleasuring his girlfriend, Davis is soon joining fellow teenage offenders Angel (Mateo Morales) and Butch (Adam Butcher) as the newest inmates of a juvenile prison in Montana.

For the remainder of â€œDog Pound,â€ù thatâ€™s where they â€” and the movie â€” will stay, chewed up by a system more Darwinian than Aristotelian. As our three newbies are caught in a relentless cycle of violence and recrimination (no learning or growing here), the film descends into a pit of miserabilism. Pale walls frame pasty complexions, and morals are as gray as the mush served in the dining hall. When violence flares itâ€™s shocking and elemental, but also brief: most of the time the tone is one of measured restraint.

Updating Alan Clarke and Roy Mintonâ€™s 1979 â€œScumâ€ù (originally a 1977 television play made for the BBC and subsequently deemed too controversial for broadcast), the director, Kim Chapiron, proves an excellent choreographer of brutality. Refusing to lean on flailing cameras or a pounding score, he employs calmly observational framing backed by a doleful, twangy guitar. Even amid the chaos of a riot, the viewer is never unmoored.

But without a strong political point (unlike its source material), â€œDog Poundâ€ù feels hollow and hopeless. A searing performance from Mr. Butcher grounds the film, but we are given no hint of where his characterâ€™s rage comes from: like so many of the behaviors around him, itâ€™s sui generis, just another problem with no solution.

In the domestic, ostensibly dark farce â€œFamily Weekend,â€ù 16-year-old Emily (Olesya Rulin), a driven high school athlete, snaps when her affluent, eccentric family fails to show for her jump-rope competition. Conscripting her siblings â€” her movie-obsessed younger sister (Joey King); her younger brother (Robbie Tucker), a savant with perfect memory; and her dimmish older brother (Eddie Hassell) â€” for the crime, she ropes her type-A working mother (Kristin Chenoweth) and burned-out painter father (Matthew Modine) to chairs and teaches them lessons in parenting. She wants them to be â€œnormal,â€ù which among other things apparently means a nonvegetarian diet and trying to talk her brother out of his suspicions that he might be gay.

This belabored comedy, directed by Benjamin Epps, has a slick visual veneer and some capable performances, especially by Ms. Rulin and Ms. King. But the script, by Matt K. Turner, is loaded with contradictions, its hollow flirtation with subversion amount to airplane pablum. Its most ludicrous proposition is that a disciplined statewide school athletic champion would proclaim herself a â€œfreak.â€ù As the story nears its conclusion and the emotional orchestral swells on the soundtrack gather, the conflicts are resolved in orderly succession. Does Emilyâ€™s fractured family regroup? Does it show up for her next championship? Should you bother to see this?
â€œFamily Weekendâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for some sexual content and drug use.
A couple of surprises await fans of â€œG.I. Joe: Retaliation,â€ù a follow-up to the 2009 moneymaker â€œG.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra.â€ù
Those surprises will not be spoiled here because, this being yet another film inspired by a Hasbro toy, the movieâ€™s other main attributes are noise and heavy weaponry.

In this adventure the G.I. Joes have a problem at the very top of the chain of command: the president (Jonathan Pryce, back from the first movie) is behaving oddly. Itâ€™s as if some maleficent being has taken over his body. Who could have done such a thing?

The Joes find themselves on the receiving end of a devastating attack by their own government, and only a few are left to fight back. (The casualties are among the filmâ€™s surprises.) The heavily muscled Roadblock (Dwayne Johnson) takes the lead, one of several characters from the G.I. Joe mythology not among the core players in the first movie. Others include Firefly (Ray Stevenson), who is a bit disappointing; Flint (DJ Cotrona), who is boring; Jinx (Elodie Yung), who isnâ€™t given enough to do; and Lady Jaye (Adrianne Palicki), who is just about right. Oh, and the original G.I. Joe, Joe Colton, turns up in the person of Bruce Willis, who really needs to stop doing this kind of dumb bit part.

The G.I. Joes get help from an unexpected source along the way. And the filmâ€™s director, Jon M. Chu, executes a pretty good high-altitude fight scene. Still, there should be a â€œFans Onlyâ€ù sign at the door of every theater.
â€œG.I. Joe: Retaliationâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned), because the G.I. Joes are fighters.

Who is crazy, and who is sane? That question nags at almost all the characters in â€œMental,â€ù a hectic, hyperkinetic farce that reunites the Australian director P.J. Hogan with Toni Collette, the star of his hit 1995 comedy, â€œMurielâ€™s Wedding.â€ù In â€œMentalâ€ù Ms. Collette plays Shaz, an unkempt, bong-smoking, knife-carrying nanny hired off the street by Barry Moochmore (Anthony LaPaglia), the mayor of Dolphin Heads, a coastal town in Queensland.

Barry is at his witsâ€™ end when he impulsively invites Shaz, who is hitchhiking with her dog, to watch over his five out-of-control adolescent daughters. A philandering husband and an absent father, Barry has just committed his distraught wife, Shirley (Rebecca Gibney), to a psychiatric hospital and desperately needs someone to look after the children. He is so detached from his family that he canâ€™t even remember his daughtersâ€™ names.

How crazy is Shirley? In the movieâ€™s opening scene, she is shown manically waltzing around trilling â€œThe Sound of Musicâ€ù while hanging out the family laundry. One of her fantasies has always been to be Maria von Trapp, leading a brood of happy, singing children down an Austrian mountainside.

But her daughters â€” Coral (Lily Sullivan), Michelle (Malorie Oâ€™Neill), Leanne (Nicole Freeman), Kayleen (Chelsea Bennett) and Jane (Bethany Whitmore) â€” are undisciplined, self-loathing outcasts who are convinced that they are mentally ill. Coral worries that she is schizophrenic, and Michelle sleeps in a shack outside the house to avoid being spotted by aliens intent on abducting her.

The neighbors and relatives are just as eccentric. The next-door neighbor Nancy (Kerry Fox) is a neat freak who spends hours every morning scrubbing the driveway with a toothbrush. Shirleyâ€™s older sister Doris (Caroline Goodall) makes life-size dolls of children, which she carries around.

Installed in the Moochmore home, Shaz becomes an assertive surrogate parent who tells the girls that the reason they feel alienated is that they are the next step in the human evolution to perfection. She leads them through exercises in power and subversion, the funniest of which is an invasion of Nancyâ€™s house that involves leaving menstrual blood on her white furniture. To develop self-reliance, Shaz organizes a mountain-climbing expedition.

When she and the girls disturb the neighborhood calm, â€œMentalâ€ù feels like an extreme satire of 1950s suburban conformism, in which Shaz suggests a female Randle McMurphy (of â€œOne Flew Over the Cuckooâ€™s Nestâ€ù) leading an insurrection. The movie is none too subtle in its portrayal of the â€œnormalâ€ù world as even crazier than the mental ward where Shirley is confined.

â€œMentalâ€ù wildly overplays the kookiness and quirk. An indication that it doesnâ€™t know when to stop is a subplot involving Trevor (Liev Schreiber), a shark hunter who operates an amusement park attraction where Coral works as his assistant. Trevor has a shadowy history with Shaz that includes a daughter who may or may not have been devoured by a shark. With this abrupt and late left turn, the movie loses its tenuous cohesion and turns into a frantic, flailing mess.

Around 2006, the year her second â€œTwilightâ€ù book hit, Stephenie Meyer cooked up a little science-fiction something called â€œThe Hostâ€ù that has, inevitably, been turned into a movie. Ms. Meyer of course unleashed both a new era of vampire romanticism and a female audience that has ravenously fed on that romanticismâ€™s innocent passions.

Robert Pattinson, who played Edward in the â€œTwilightâ€ù movies, is a pale, phlegmatic beauty similar to those in the work of Andrew Niccol who â€” ta-da â€” directed â€œThe Host.â€ù Mr. Niccol, meanwhile, has carved out a niche with visually sleek, emotionally cool futuristic movies like â€œGattacaâ€ù and â€œIn Time,â€ù which like â€œThe Twilightâ€ù series, are often bloodless, tonally unmodulated and yet somehow watchable.

Set in Genericville, U.S.A., â€œThe Hostâ€ù takes place after an alien race, the Souls, has transformed most of the human population into smiling peaceniks, like a nation of hospitality workers. Some humans, like Melanie (Saoirse Ronan), and her brother, Jamie (Chandler Canterbury), have managed to escape. The story kicks in when Melanie is captured and another alien, who for some reason is called a Seeker (Diane Kruger), slices open Melanieâ€™s neck and inserts a Soul, a luminous white blob with tentacles that look like sperm. Once implanted, a Soul is supposed to take over its hostâ€™s consciousness, but Melanie fights her Soul, called Wanderer â€” distractingly, she talks to it from inside their shared body â€” and together they run off to an Eden-like refuge stocked with supplies and cuties (Max Irons, Boyd Holbrook, Jake Abel).

Dopey, derivative and dull, â€œThe Hostâ€ù is a brazen combination of unoriginal science-fiction themes, young-adult pandering and bottom-line calculation. That sounds like it should work (really!), but it never does, largely because the story is as drained of energy as are its moony aliens. Ms. Ronan and some special contact lenses spook up the Wanderer (renamed Wanda), but the alienâ€™s serenity is a dreary liability. And the split-personality squabbles within Melanie generate no tension, even when each character sets sights on a different slab of male prime. The only real fun comes from bushwhacking through the movieâ€™s thicket of influences and commercial imperatives and marveling at its weird combination of â€œTwilightâ€ù-like chaste romance, Cronenberg-lite body horror and Heinlein-esque puppet mastery.

The movie winds down to a crawl not long after Melanie/Wanda settles into the refuge (utopias tend to be bores), but Ms. Ronan keeps on trucking. With her clear, steady gaze and a physical bearing and gestural style that feel highly disciplined, she has always come across as preternaturally mature. Thereâ€™s an almost otherworldly aspect to her screen presence, partly due to her stillness and her own translucent eyes, which can suggest grave intensity or utter detachment. She may turn into another Cate Blanchett.

For now, though, Ms. Ronan, who turns 19 next month, just has to prove that she is smoothly transitioning to adulthood and ready for the corresponding roles, which, for a young woman in American movies means she has to demonstrate sex appeal and kiss some guys. Ms. Ronan does. Sheâ€™s ready.
â€œThe Hostâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Gun violence and bloody wounds.
â€œSomebody Up There Likes Meâ€ù is a 24-hour film. That is, 24 hours after you see it, itâ€™s still lingering in your mind. But 48 hours after? Gone.

The film, the latest from Bob Byington (â€œHarmony and Meâ€ù), features the same mumbly, schlumpy young man who inhabits a lot of projects like this that end up with the â€œindieâ€ù label. This one is Max (Keith Poulson), who exhibits little ambition, doesnâ€™t react when women do him wrong, treats people indifferently and in general seems to be purposely navigating the world in such a way as to have no impact.

There are two constants in his life. One is his friend Sal (nicely played by Nick Offerman of â€œParks and Recreationâ€ù), though Mr. Byington isnâ€™t interested in telling us much about their friendship or, really, any of the relationships in the story. The other is a mysterious magic suitcase that apparently keeps him young while everyone around him ages. The film jumps through 35 yearsâ€™ worth of time, with gray hairs and children materializing but no one, especially Max, really maturing.

Itâ€™s all kind of cute. Maybe a little too cute, but it does have a nice circle-of-life ending. And along the way, Mr. Byington shows a knack for observational humor, slipping in sly jokes that force you to keep paying attention despite the slim plot. Droll and interesting; just not very substantial.

â€œThe Place Beyond the Pines,â€ù Derek Cianfranceâ€™s new movie, reveals the scale of its ambitions by slow and patient accretion. The film starts out as the modest tale of a small-time carnival performer â€” a motorcycle stunt rider â€” who turns to crime for misguided but nonetheless semi-admirable reasons, and in the early scenes you might mistake it for an earnest, locavore indie melodrama.

Which it is, only bigger, longer and elevated to a place on the border between grandeur and grandiosity. Set in and around Schenectady, N.Y. (whose Mohawk name is evoked in the title), â€œThe Place Beyond the Pinesâ€ù has a lot to say about class, manhood and the curious operations of fate, themes that Mr. Cianfrance articulates with blunt conviction and, at times, impressive artistry. He goes on too long: the three-part story, spread over nearly two and a half hours, represents a triumph of sympathetic imagination and a failure of narrative economy. But if, in the end, the film canâ€™t quite sustain its epic vision, it does, along the way, achieve the density and momentum of a good novel.

If it were a book, the name on the spine might be Russell Banks or Joyce Carol Oates, since, like them, Mr. Cianfrance is drawn to blue-collar landscapes of the northeastern United States. This Schenectady, seen at two different moments 15 years apart, feels like a place that time forgot, far away from the tumult of politics or commercial popular culture. Itâ€™s a small town of beat-up houses and late-night diners whose citizens dwell under film-noir shadows of violence and corruption.

Luke (Ryan Gosling), first glimpsed as a tattoo-covered torso striding away from the camera, shows up with his seedy, itinerant fairground crew and encounters Romina (Eva Mendes), with whom he had a fling the last time he was in town. When he finds out that his wild oat has sprouted into a baby named Jason, Luke decides to stick around, insisting that he and Romina and Jason can be a family, even though Romina lives with another man (Mahershala Ali). To win her over and support his child, Luke, with the help of a local mechanic (the excellent Ben Mendelsohn), starts robbing banks, speeding away on his motorcycle.

The second section of â€œThe Place Beyond the Pinesâ€ù is about another man, a police officer named Avery (Bradley Cooper), who is also the father of a baby boy. The third panel of what Mr. Cianfrance has described as a triptych is about the two sons (grown into Emory Cohen and Dane DeHaan). Iâ€™m reluctant to say more, less out of a fear of spoilers than out of respect for the filmâ€™s structural audacity.

Mr. Cianfranceâ€™s previous movie, â€œBlue Valentine,â€ù with Mr. Gosling and Michelle Williams, was built around a chronological trick. It shuttled back and forth in time between the beginning and the end of the main charactersâ€™ relationship. The most radical aspect of â€œThe Place Beyond the Pinesâ€ù is its relentless linearity, the way it tells its story without foreshadowing or flashing back or resorting to other conventional shortcuts. Watching it is refreshing and absorbing partly because it is rare for a film to show this kind of confidence in its own narrative momentum, which is also a gesture of faith in the audienceâ€™s willingness to pay attention.

Your attention is especially rewarded by the work of Mr. Gosling and Mr. Cooper, who offer contrasting studies in tragic, shortsighted masculine intensity. Mr. Goslingâ€™s cool self-possession â€” the only thing he was allowed to display in â€œDriveâ€ù â€” is complicated, made interesting, by hints of childlike innocence and vulnerability. In the middle of stickups, Luke raises his voice almost to a shriek, and his dream of paternal fulfillment is almost pathetically naÃ¯ve.

His most serious flaw may be his commitment to a romantic view of himself as an outlaw with a noble cause. Avery, the son of a judge (Harris Yulin), is threatened above all by his own righteous arrogance, which undermines his relationship with his wife (Rose Byrne) and clouds his professional prospects. Mr. Cooper, once again showing himself to be a restless and resourceful talent, plays Avery as a handsome, charming winner who is nonetheless very difficult to like.

The sins of these two complicated fathers are visited on their sons, and it is in the third-act swirl of revenge and redemption that â€œThe Place Beyond the Pinesâ€ù goes wrong, trading its grit and psychological insight for overwrought, capitalized emotions. As the movie wears on, you start to notice Mr. Cianfranceâ€™s overreliance on certain shots (like the long, behind-the-head follow) and the insistent, stabbing squall of Mike Pattonâ€™s otherwise effective score. (Speaking of music, the movie ends with a Bon Iver song that would have been more powerful if it had not been used in a similar way in â€œRust and Bone.â€ù)

The failures of this film are the product of its aspirations, which makes it easy to forgive, even though the disappointment is hard to shake. The movie is a little like both its anguished protagonists, going wrong in the name of vanity and love.
â€œThe Place Beyond the Pinesâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Crime, punishment, drugs, swearing.

The title of Maren Grainger-Monsen and Nicole Newnhamâ€™s film happens to evoke the function of many documentaries: enlighten audiences about world problems and make them feel a bit more hopeful now that someone with initiative is taking care of things. Centered on a neighborhood in Kolkata lacking potable water, â€œThe Revolutionary Optimistsâ€ù puts a spin on this tendency because these caretakers of the future are youngsters with a surprising knack for talking points.

Amlan Ganguly, a former lawyer, runs an outreach program for children that goes far beyond reading, writing and responsibility. With Mr. Gangulyâ€™s encouragement, two 12-year-old spitfires, Sikha and Salim, campaign for a proper water delivery system. Two other children â€” a girl waylaid by early marriage and another by the need to support a sick mother by working at a brickyard â€” serve as cautionary tales.

Thatâ€™s part of what makes the movie, which has trouble hitting stride, a bit of an underachiever, content with letting the successful children serve their purpose as models of autonomy. Mr. Ganguly also organizes dance classes, which lead to some of the freer and more moving scenes. But as heartening as it is to see a slum child tutored about vicious cycles of adversity and using the buzzword â€œpartnershipâ€ù with aplomb, the film comes to feel cut and dried.

Explaining why something is funny is about as fruitful and friend-winning an endeavor as explaining why itâ€™s not. â€œWrong,â€ù from the director of the ready-made cult film â€œRubber,â€ù demonstrates exactly that, with its sluggish chain of absurd situations: an office in which it is perpetually raining; a pizza delivery girl who quits her marriage after falling in love during a failed phone order; a backyard palm tree mysteriously replaced by a pine.

Like a series of blackout gags without the blackouts (and with a lot of repeats), Quentin Dupieuxâ€™s sun-bright movie of episodic misadventures continues in this fashion, embracing Opposites Day as a screenwriting principle.

The neurotic protagonist, Dolph (Jack Plotnick), shares something of the bewilderment and bouffant of Henry from David Lynchâ€™s â€œEraserheadâ€ù and primarily seeks the return of his missing dog, Paul. But even that involves strained wackiness: a self-help guru, Master Chang (William Fichtner with an ambiguous accent), has stolen the pooch, supposedly for Dolphâ€™s own good.

Mr. Dupieuxâ€™s â€œRubber,â€ù a similarly take-it-or-leave-it affair about a killer tire, featured self-reflexive antics that offset its repetitive violence (and brought out the playfully theorizing Frenchman within its director). â€œWrongâ€ù lets most of its random gags and view-askew premises twist in the wind like hamhandedly wacky improv comedy, punctuated with synthesizer effects. The filmâ€™s misguided flatness is perhaps its fatal flaw, not so much deadpan or existential as just monotonous.

Not helping are a couple of one-note comic characters, a French gardener (Eric Judor of the Gallic comedy duo Eric et Ramzy) and the headlong pizza girl (Alexis Dziena). But as the sleuth hired to find the dog, Detective Ronnie (Steve Little of HBOâ€™s â€œEastbound & Downâ€ù) shows the value of a little swagger and timing in a film too often enamored of compartmentalized oddity. And Mr. Plotnick as the petless, milquetoast Dolph can have a pleasantly aggrieved sweetness; that he goes to work in spite of having been fired does arouse a spot of feeling.

Mr. Dupieux, again playing a one-man-bandâ€™s worth of filmmaking roles, obviously has sufficient creative control (seen especially in the video simulating the perspective of waste passing through a dogâ€™s digestive tract). But thatâ€™s not the same as giving a movie shape and drive, and it would take a firmer hand to right this â€œWrong.â€ù

â€œI refuse to paint the world black,â€ù declares Pierre-Auguste Renoir (the great French actor Michel Bouquet) in â€œRenoir,â€ù Gilles Bourdosâ€™s compassionate late-life portrait of this French Impressionist painter, infirm with rheumatoid arthritis. â€œA painting should be something pleasant and cheerful,â€ù he adds. â€œThere are enough disagreeable things in life. I donâ€™t need to paint more.â€ù

It is the summer of 1915 and Renoir, 74, has just lost his beloved wife, Aline. He will die four years later. The great man, now rich and famous, is slavishly attended by a retinue of female servants, several of whom are former artistâ€™s models, at his farm, Les Collettes, at Cagnes-sur-Mer on the Cote dâ€™Azur. World War I rages to the north.

His two older sons, Pierre (Laurent Poitrenaux) and Jean (Vincent Rottiers), have both suffered serious battle injuries. Early in the film Jean returns home on crutches to convalesce from a wound that nearly cost him a leg. A third son, Claude (Thomas Doret), a k a Coco, in his early teens, lives on the property.

Despite laboring in excruciating pain, which requires his hand to be tied to his paintbrush, Renoir remains obsessed with the way â€œthe velvety texture of a young girlâ€™s skinâ€ù absorbs the light. He experiences a surge of vitality when he meets the 15-year-old AndrÃ©e Heuschling (Christa ThÃ©ret), a k a Dedee, a voluptuous, mouthy, high-strung redhead recommended as a model by Henri Matisse.

â€œToo early, too late,â€ù Renoir comments wryly, meaning that their age difference prevents them from becoming lovers. For Renoir, AndrÃ©e, who has a ravenous appetite for life, is the spirit made flesh, a beauty â€œTitian would have worshiped,â€ù he announces.
Renoirâ€™s philosophy is distilled in five words: â€œFlesh! Thatâ€™s all that matters.â€ù

While watching the movie, exquisitely photographed by the Taiwanese cinematographer Mark Ping Bing Lee (â€œIn the Mood for Loveâ€ù), you may surrender to that unabashedly sensual vision, celebrated in every shot of Les Collettesâ€™ gorgeous, seething landscape of windblown trees, grass and streams that reflect what Renoir calls â€œthe fury running through my nerves.â€ù

But the movie, like its subject, refuses to stir up unnecessary melodrama. There are many small conflicts and psychological undercurrents, but the closest thing to a narrative theme is the effect AndrÃ©e has on the Renoir household. Pierre-Auguste, Jean and Claude all fall under her spell, while Renoirâ€™s caretakers are outraged by her arrogance. In a violent outburst, she smashes several priceless plates.
When AndrÃ©e and Jean first meet, and she asks him what he wants to do with his life, he replies glumly that he has â€œno dreams and ambitions.â€ù
She scolds, â€œNever say that to a woman â€” sheâ€™ll despise you.â€ù
They have an affair during which AndrÃ©e, who dreams of being a movie star, stokes his interest in filmmaking, and we see his first steps in that direction.

Just outside the gates of Les Collettes lies the real world in its war-torn shambles, glimpsed in a scene in which the radiant AndrÃ©e rides her bicycle past rows of wounded, disfigured soldiers sprawled by the roadside, who eye her with a mixture of hunger and despair. Here is the horror Renoir has shut out of his sight.

Mr. Rottiers plays the 20-year-old Jean as a blank lost soul waiting for his future to find him. When he recovers, he is torn between staying with AndrÃ©e and returning to the war to fight beside his comrades.

The movie ends as Jean is about to leave Les Collettes. He didnâ€™t die. After returning safely, he and AndrÃ©e married, and before they separated in 1931, she made 15 silent films under the name Catherine Hessling. Jean went on to cinematic immortality as the creator of classics like â€œGrand Illusionâ€ù and â€œThe Rules of the Game.â€ù

â€œRenoirâ€ù doesnâ€™t strain to create a deeper sense of artistic continuity between father and son beyond suggesting that Pierre-Auguste and Jean shared a vision of life expressed in the fatherâ€™s advice to â€œlet yourself be carried through life like a cork on water.â€ù
That sense of fluidity is embodied in the canvases shown in the film (painted by the famous art forger Guy Ribes), whose figures dissolve into the landscape and into one another in an ethereal mist.
â€œWhat must control the structure is not the line,â€ù Renoir declares. â€œItâ€™s the color.â€ù
â€œRenoirâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for art-related nudity and brief language.

An ode to movie love at its most deliriously unfettered, â€œRoom 237â€ù is a nonfiction look at some very serious film fans who take â€œThe Shining,â€ù Stanley Kubrickâ€™s 1980 masterpiece, very, very seriously. They know â€” deep in their obsessive, sometimes demented cinephile hearts â€” that Kubrick did more than make a feverishly entertaining film about a family falling apart in an isolated hotel called the Overlook. He also embedded amazing messages in â€œThe Shining,â€ù cunningly weaving secrets and signs into the filmâ€™s very fabric, leaving clues about the Holocaust in elevators and messages about the Apollo 11 Moon landing in a sweater. In books, blogs and now this movie these fans carry forth the godheadâ€™s gnostic communiquÃ©s.

And here you thought that â€œThe Shiningâ€ù was a movie, as in a dazzling aesthetic object, a cultural touchstone, a showcase for Jack Nicholson, a perverse family drama, a fiendishly clever horror story, a triumph of personal vision and yet another Kubrickian technical tour de force â€” all or none of the above. For contemporary reviewers it was, like much of Kubrickâ€™s work, a divisive object. Some lavished praise on it, while others picked up an ax, dismissing the film as boring and flaccid, comparing it unfavorably to Stephen Kingâ€™s book. For his part Mr. King was so dissatisfied that he adapted his novel into a six-hour mini-series called â€œStephen Kingâ€™s The Shining,â€ù leaving no doubt whom he deemed its true auteur.

Mr. King and some reviewers might have been unhappy with Kubrickâ€™s adaptation, but it exerted an astonishing, almost hypnotic pull on moviegoers like Geoffrey Cocks, one of the voices that the filmmaker Rodney Ascher has tapped for â€œRoom 237.â€ù (The title refers to an Overlook room.) Mr. Cocks, a history professor at Albion College in Michigan, explains that he wasnâ€™t impressed when he first saw â€œThe Shining.â€ù But it snaked under his skin, and he wondered if heâ€™d missed something. So, â€œI went back to see it again, and I began to see patterns and details that I hadnâ€™t noticed before,â€ù he says in â€œRoom 237.â€ù â€œI kept watching the film again and again and again.â€ù And what he found, gleaning significance from props like a typewriter, is â€œa deeply laid subtext that takes on the Holocaust.â€ù

You never see Mr. Cocks in â€œRoom 237,â€ù though if you visit the Albion College Web site, you can peek at his photo and check out his academic bona fides. In broad terms â€œRoom 237â€ù is a nonfiction movie â€” its human and cinematic subjects are real enough â€” but itâ€™s more of a personal essay than a traditional documentary, specifically in its truth claims. Its five interviewees are chatty (most are men, unsurprising given the film-nerd world), whose voice-overs accompany a stream of visuals. Most of the images have mostly been plucked from â€œThe Shining,â€ù but Mr. Ascher also draws on other Kubrick titles, including â€œ2001: A Space Odysseyâ€ù and â€œBarry Lyndon,â€ù along with an assortment of archival material.

Mr. Cocks, whose books include â€œThe Wolf at the Door: Stanley Kubrick, History and the Holocaust,â€ù proves the most rational of these voices because, however tenuously, he grounds his interpretation both in history and the visible evidence that is â€œThe Shiningâ€ù itself. â€œWhy a German typewriter,â€ù he asks, as Mr. Ascher shows the machine in question. An Adler (â€œeagleâ€ù in German), it sits ominously on a desk in the Overlook, where each day Jack Torrance (Mr. Nicholson) tries to untap his genius. Itâ€™s the same one on which he types â€” again and again â€” â€œAll work and no play makes Jack a dull boyâ€ù â€” the refrain that Kubrick, with music, camera moves, framing and a smothering air of dread, transforms into a portent of evil.

That the typewriter changes color in the film doesnâ€™t shake Mr. Cocks. For him the machine is a crucial referent as is the repeat of the number 42 (which appears on a jersey and elsewhere). â€œIf you put the number 42 and a German typewriter together,â€ù Mr. Cocks says, â€œyou get the Holocaust.â€ù All right â€” but what does that mean? No one says, but, like a dutifully literal (or sly) student, Mr. Ascher illustrates this part of Mr. Cocksâ€™s thesis by cutting from the notorious tsunami of blood in â€œThe Shiningâ€ù to a photo of Auschwitz and then back to Kubrickâ€™s red wave. â€œBecause it was in 1942,â€ù Mr. Cocks continues, â€œthat the Nazis made the decision to go ahead and exterminate all the Jews they could. And they did so in a highly mechanicalâ€ù â€” Mr. Ascher cuts back to the typewriter â€” â€œindustrial and bureaucratic way.â€ù

That sounds bonkers and close to a trivialization of a historical catastrophe, even if Mr. Cocks presents a case thatâ€™s reinforced by Kubrickâ€™s interest in the Holocaust (it was the subject of one of his unrealized projects, â€œAryan Papersâ€ù) and by the evil throbbing throughout â€œThe Shining.â€ù The problem is that his reading, at least here, doesnâ€™t resonate as anything but a deeply personal, even private interpretation. The four other interviewees in â€œRoom 237,â€ù including the entertaining Bill Blakemore, a correspondent for ABC News, advance even less persuasive arguments about Kubrickâ€™s film that are tethered, at times laughably, to what could be just resonant props, continuity errors or â€” as with a carpet design â€” tantalizing, teasing emblems of Kubrickâ€™s oft-repeated interest in puzzles and enigmas.

Mr. Ascher doesnâ€™t overtly comment on these theories, although his comical insertion of Tom Cruise smashing one gloved hand into another in â€œEyes Wide Shutâ€ù â€” to represent the interviewees thinking super-hard â€” strongly conveys an amused, ironic detachment. Like â€œThe Shiningâ€ù and its maze within a maze, Mr. Ascherâ€™s movie is something of a labyrinth. Puzzling your way through its compilation of vaguely lucid and crackpot ideas is pleasurable though, for avid movie lovers, it may also feel like a warning. To listen to one other interviewee, Juli Kearns, talk about an â€œimpossible windowâ€ù in the Overlook (â€œItâ€™s like a character in itself, it takes overâ€ù), you are reminded (again!) of Susan Sontagâ€™s declaration that â€œinterpretation is the revenge of the intellect upon art.â€ù

Such readings have only proliferated because of the ease with which a film like â€œThe Shiningâ€ù can be watched, paused and re-watched at the touch of a remote. And part of what makes â€œRoom 237â€ù fascinating to watch and think about (beyond other peopleâ€™s loopiness) is that it shows how works of art become encrusted with their reception. Itâ€™s a process that has only been accelerated by the Internet, where millions of loony and lovely interpretations bloom. The interviewees in â€œRoom 237â€ù are of course just fans of an especially zealous stripe. Yet, in their accumulation of signs, clues and messages, they are also creating an archive of sorts â€” call it the Kubrick Files â€” that, however fanciful or paranoid, now exists as an adjunct or even alternative to those of official critical discourse. Itâ€™s the revenge of the nerds ad infinitum.
Depicting the unconventional life of the Chilean musician and folk artist Violeta Parra, â€œVioleta Went to Heavenâ€ù unfolds as a poetic sine wave of celebration and defeat.

By turns charming, selfish, passionate and dismissive, Parra (beautifully played by Francisca GavilÃ¡n) poured herself into her songs, emotionally resonant wails of romantic pain and social injustice. Fathered in 1917 by a charismatic drunk who left her only a guitar and memories of desperate poverty, she embarked on a life of itinerant performance. Traipsing across the Andes with one or more of her siblings, traveling to Poland to showcase her music and, astonishingly, persuading the Louvre to mount an exhibition of her tapestries, Parra bulldozed all obstacles.

Based on the memoirs of Parraâ€™s son, Angel, and structured around a fictionalized television interview drawn from various sources and set several years before her suicide in 1967, â€œVioletaâ€ù has a wild, impressionistic tone that prizes emotion over fact. Skipping around in time, the director, AndrÃ©s Wood, skates over Parraâ€™s involvement with Communism to focus on a personality awash in contradictions. Husbands and children appear as mere adjuncts to her art, whether dragged around the countryside while she collects traditional songs or abandoned for years while she frolics in Europe with her young lover, the Swiss flautist Gilbert Favre (Thomas Durand).

Indispensably supported by Miguel Ioan Littinâ€™s exquisite photography, Mr. Wood has created a poignant portrait of an artist unable to escape the stamp of her class or the burdens of aging. The grand exhibition tent she erects on a hilltop becomes, in the end, an apt metaphor for dashed dreams, its canvas unable to keep out the rain and its empty seats unable to turn back time.

The actor, director and playwright Tyler Perry has long embraced religion in his films, but perhaps never more so than in his slack fable â€œTemptation: Confessions of a Marriage Counselor.â€ù Adapted from his 2008 play, â€œThe Marriage Counselor,â€ù the movie inveighs against deviation from the church, monogamy and the righteous path of cooking meals for a husband.

The story is framed by a tale that a couples therapist imparts to a cheating wife.
