With the filmâ€™s incessant strings and narration by Hugh Bonneville of â€œDownton Abbey,â€ù the earnest yet pompous tone could almost be mistaken for a Monty Python parody of the BBC-standard style. Most comical, however, and also pathetically anticlimactic, is the bold declaration that Prince William might actually change diapers.

Kitchen-sink realism for the 21st century: that would describe the first three-quarters of â€œBroken,â€ù the fine but unnecessarily convoluted first feature film by the British theater director Rufus Norris about the tensions in a grubby middle-class neighborhood of North London. The movie lacks the visual austerity and despairing tone of its forerunners in the late 1950s and early 1960s. These people are not poor. But most are unhappy, coarse and highly stressed, and the social climate is claustrophobic.

With a screenplay by Mark Oâ€™Rowe, based on a novel by Daniel Clay, â€œBrokenâ€ù is a portrait of a seedy urban enclave whose most prominent feature is a junkyard where the children frolic among rusted automobile husks. The milieu is observed mostly through the eyes of Skunk (Eloise Laurence), a spunky, curious 11-year-old girl.

The tomboyish Skunk, whose character is reminiscent of Scout Finch from â€œTo Kill a Mockingbird,â€ù lives with her caring father, Archie (Tim Roth), a lawyer; her teenage brother, Jed (Bill Milner), who warns her of the approaching nightmare of high school; and their strong-willed, 35-year-old nanny, Kasia (Zana Marjanovic). Skunk â€” wonderfully played by Ms. Laurence â€” has Type 1 diabetes, and there are repeated scenes of her pricking her finger and checking her blood sugar.

The family has a scary neighbor, Bob Oswald (Rory Kinnear), who is a loutish, rage-aholic widower raising three unruly daughters who share his aggressive belligerence: the teenagers Saskia (Faye Daveney) and Susan (Rosalie Kosky-Hensman), and the barely pubescent Sunrise (Martha Bryant).

In an early scene, Skunk witnesses Bobâ€™s savage beating of a cowering, mentally disabled teenager, Rick (Robert Emms), who also lives nearby. Susan has falsely accused Rick of rape in a frantic attempt to avoid her fatherâ€™s wrath after he finds a condom wrapper in her bedroom and goes ballistic. An examination reveals her to have been untouched.
The Oswald girls, like their father, are bullies who, with his tacit approval, physically threaten the neighborhood youth, including Skunk.

Skunk and Archie are the most stable characters in this volatile environment. Even their harmonious household is ruffled when Kasia gives up waiting for her long-term boyfriend, Mike (Cillian Murphy), a teacher, to make a commitment and bluntly offers herself to Archie, who reciprocates.

The compacted melodrama intensifies when Susan, who has since lost her virginity and is now pregnant, lodges a second rape accusation, this time against Mike, who is innocent. At a certain point, Mr. Norris forsakes realism for theatricalized fantasy, and â€œBrokenâ€ù ultimately loses its stylistic cohesion, if not its humanity.

Setting aside the likes of â€œParis Je Tâ€™Aime,â€ù the themed omnibus film appealingly maintains the notion that an all-star team of adventurous filmmakers will have both marketing appeal and formal Ã©clat. â€œCentro HistÃ_rico,â€ù commissioned to promote the Portuguese city of GuimarÃ£es as a 2012 European Capital of Culture, groups short films from a deadpan Finnish director (Aki Kaurismaki), a Basque neighbor (Victor Erice, in documentary mode) and two native sons (Pedro Costa and Manoel de Oliveira) who happily continue to direct exactly as they wish.

Mr. Costaâ€™s segment, â€œSweet Exorcist,â€ù especially makes no bones about its seriousness of purpose (even if it is named after a Curtis Mayfield album). It follows Ventura, the Cape Verdean star of this directorâ€™s film â€œColossal Youthâ€ù (2007), through Dantean woods and into a suspended elevator for a historical dialogue with a statuelike camouflaged soldier (and others), touching upon Portugalâ€™s 1974 revolution and torturous legacy. Decidedly unfootnoted, Mr. Costaâ€™s contribution is a stringent, heady, narcotic passage that brooks no stragglers.

Diametrically opposed in approach is Mr. Ericeâ€™s â€œVidros Partidosâ€ù (â€œBroken Windowsâ€ù), a television-friendly oral history about a nearly 160-year-old textile factory, now defunct. Workers spanning multiple generations and speaking one by one in seated head-on shots recall cyclical lifestyles and their pride and fatigue. Looking for the spark amid the drudgery and the conflicted tradition of such labor, Mr. Erice singles out, in a panoramic black-and-white photograph of a crowded mess hall, one womanâ€™s Mona Lisa smile.

Bookending â€œCentro HistÃ_ricoâ€ù is lighter fare, falling into line with the titleâ€™s tour guide echo. Mr. Kaurismakiâ€™s â€œTavern Manâ€ù imagines, not very memorably, the silent-film routine of a waiter-proprietor (Ilkka Koivula) at a cafe thatâ€™s slightly but decisively off the beaten path. In the quartetâ€™s closer, â€œO Conquistador Conquistadoâ€ù (â€œThe Conqueror Conqueredâ€ù), Mr. Oliveira closely directs another variation on colonialism and the power dynamics and aesthetics of the gaze. The Oliveira regular (and grandson) Ricardo TrÃªpa plays a tour guide who seems most struck by how the voracious sightseeing rabble turn the tables on statues of his countryâ€™s high and mighty.

That notion has probably occurred to people who have fought their way through picture-snapping crowds at home or abroad, and the filmâ€™s final shot might seem a little too apt a summary of an audienceâ€™s reaction: Mr. TrÃªpa, looking into the camera, shrugs.

Tomas, the slim teenager from BogotÃ¡, Colombia, in Juan AndrÃ©s Arango GarcÃ_aâ€™s film â€œLa Playa D.C.,â€ù has a few options for rising above his financially struggling family and rough past. (â€œLa Playaâ€ù is Spanish for â€œthe beach,â€ù the nickname for a BogotÃ¡ neighborhood popular with Afro-Colombians from the Pacific Coast.) The film follows Tomas (Luis Carlos Guevara) as he leaves home; pairs up with his savvier older brother, Chaco (James SolÃ_s); and tries to help his younger brother, Jairo (AndrÃ©s Murillo), an addict deep in debt.

As Tomas, the finely featured Mr. Guevara harbors a quiet tenacity and looks sharp, but canâ€™t consistently marshal his energies for his big scenes. Mr. Arango GarcÃ_aâ€™s camera, however, casually observes several moments â€” like Tomasâ€™s bold make-out sessions with a girl at the mall or some more anonymous bumping and grinding at a dark club â€” with a spontaneity that rings true.

The monikers Ice-T and Ice Cube nod to the influence of Iceberg Slim, the pimp turned author whose real name was Robert Beck, on the ethos and style of gangster rap. In further homage, Ice-T has produced â€œIceberg Slim: Portrait of a Pimp,â€ù a documentary told through talking-head admirers including Chris Rock and Snoop Dogg.

The film was directed by Ice-Tâ€™s manager, Jorge Hinojosa, a first-time director who credits reading Mr. Beckâ€™s first book, â€œPimp: The Story of My Lifeâ€ù (1967), at Ice-Tâ€™s suggestion, with teaching him everything he needed to know about â€œthe gameâ€ù of managing a rap star with larger ambitions. A fascinating subtext of the film is that the terms â€œpimpâ€ù and â€œgameâ€ù refer both to the sometimes illegal strategies for surviving street life and to the storytelling and selling of that experience through art. As Ice-T says when citing the influence of Mr. Beckâ€™s books on his music, â€œThere are two sides: the game and the B side.â€ù

But an explanation of that B side, including the nuances and paradoxes of self-exploitation, are only hinted at rather than explored. Though directed with some flourishes, including a riveting use of music and attractive animated pulp art, the film is weighed down by the testimony of bespectacled professors from hip critical studies and English departments and a psychologist, who describe Mr. Beckâ€™s biography without the punch and lyricism of his prose. (He was 73 when he died in 1992.)

â€œThere are no esoteric psychiatrist dialogues, dead preachments or leaden footnotes on the living pages of this book,â€ù Iceberg Slim wrote in the introduction to his 1969 book, â€œMama Black Widow.â€ù If only the same could be said of this film.

â€œIceberg Slim: Portrait of a Pimpâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for sexual content, some violent images and language, including academic use of the words â€œpimpinâ€™Â â€ù and â€œho.â€ù

It was, apparently, a war to end all subtlety. Ron Maxwell, director of the Civil War drama â€œCopperhead,â€ù renders everything in capital letters in this story of dissent and repression on the home front. Though the tale, based on a novel by Harold Frederic, remains relevant to our time, the film is too self-conscious and tedious for the message it delivers.

Billy Campbell is Abner Beech, a New York dairy farmer who was no fan of slavery but was opposed to the war â€” a Copperhead, in the political labeling of the day. Abnerâ€™s son (Casey Thomas Brown) falls for the daughter of his fatherâ€™s tormentor (Lucy Boynton) and enlists to impress her. Itâ€™s impossible not to root for Kristen Wiig, even while you wait in vain for the funny to pop in her latest. A forced, laugh-challenged comedy with an appealing if not terribly well-used cast, â€œGirl Most Likelyâ€ù is the first movie that Ms. Wiig has taken the lead in since the 2011 runaway hit â€œBridesmaids.â€ù In that comedy, she played an amusingly self-involved singleton without a love life, bright prospects or a home to call her very own. (Mind you, she did have Jon Hamm on demand.) The Garden State, or at least a generic abstraction of it, plays a significant role in â€œGirl Most Likely,â€ù which was written by Michelle Morgan and directed by Shari Springer Berman and Robert Pulcini. When the movie opens, Ms. Wiigâ€™s character, Imogene, is safely ensconced in that glistening bubble called the Upper East Side, where sheâ€™s busily getting ready for a soiree. She keeps calling her boyfriend, Peter (Brian Petsos), leaving messages that, as she races from apartment to taxi and party, tremble with intensifying, barely contained desperation. By the time the party is over, her relationship is, too, and most everything else seems imperiled, including her friendships with a gaggle of socialite simpletons (June Diane Raphael, among others).

The breakup with Peter sets off a calamitous chain of events that leads to Imogene being put into the custody of her New Jersey mother, Zelda (Annette Bening). Wielding an accent even more strategically gaudy than her tight, sparkly clothes, Zelda is the walking, tawking embodiment of Imogeneâ€™s fears and prejudices. Zeldaâ€™s name suggests both class aspirations and maybe psychological instability, but mostly she registers as a classically cartoonish mother, one nesting with a kooky male threesome that includes her sweetly oddball son, Ralph (Christopher Fitzgerald), a lover, the Bosche (Matt Dillon), and a roomer, Lee (Darren Criss). Unsurprisingly, thereâ€™s more to Zelda than her tube tops and inoffensively bad habits, even if the smart yet oh-so-stupid Imogene is the last to know it.

Ms. Berman and Mr. Pulciniâ€™s films include fiction titles like â€œAmerican Splendorâ€ù (about the comic-book writer Harvey Pekar) and documentaries like â€œOff the Menu: The Last Days of Chasenâ€™s.â€ù A more recent credit, â€œThe Nanny Diaries,â€ù is a charmless, ungainly comedy that, as the awkwardly directed â€œGirl Most Likelyâ€ù suggests, may not have been the anomalous misfire it seemed. Ms. Morganâ€™s script chugs along on low-key humor and leans on more clichÃ©s (you can go home again, at least in movies) than it mildly subverts, so it needed directors who could give it real lift and bounce. Despite Ms. Wiig, Imogene remains similarly flat, more of an outline than the filled-in personality that would have elevated her sitcom agonies (and a stalled playwriting career) into something truthful.

As you wait for Imogene to self-actualize, the actors keep you watching and hoping and sometimes manage to find a moment of grace, as when Imogene goes to Atlantic City to hear Lee perform in a 1990s cover band. As she sits frozen in place, eddies of embarrassment (for him, for her) tug at her features and shudder through her body, even as she begins rocking and nodding to the beat. As she realizes heâ€™s actually pretty good, her discomfort turns into incredulity and then delight, a transformation thatâ€™s both fun to watch and meaningful because, as her reserve crumbles, so does a lifetime of carefully, foolishly nurtured pretenses. Lee has a real gift and so, too, does Imogene, the difference being that before she can have her moment she first needs to learn one tediously long lesson.
â€œGirl Most Likelyâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). A faked suicide and some bedroom tumbling.

The closest thing to a human character in Nicolas Winding Refnâ€™s blood-drenched, nihilistic reverie â€œOnly God Forgivesâ€ù is Crystal (Kristin Scott Thomas), a foul-mouthed, platinum-haired gorgon who flies to Bangkok from the United States to avenge the murder of Billy (Tom Burke), the elder of her two sons. That Billy came to a bloody end after savagely raping and murdering a 16-year-old prostitute doesnâ€™t seem to bother Crystal, who runs an international drug smuggling enterprise. â€œIâ€™m sure he had his reasons,â€ù she says airily.

Crystalâ€™s mission is to persuade her younger son, Julian (Ryan Gosling), who ran a kickboxing gym with Billy, to find the killer and bring his head to her on a platter. She assures Julian that this is what Billy would have done had Julian been the victim.

Ms. Scott Thomas, heavily made up to resemble a hybrid of Donatella Versace and Madonna, dispenses dirty-mouthed dish with an elocutionary hauteur. In one risible speech she compares her sonsâ€™ penis sizes. If Ms. Scott Thomasâ€™s camp caricature rivals anything in the Joan Crawford playbook in grotesquerie, it still canâ€™t breathe life into this corpse of a movie.
So what is on Mr. Refnâ€™s mind? Here is what he says in a directorâ€™s note: â€œThe original concept for the film was to make a movie about a man who wants to fight God.â€ù All right. Whatever.

The God surrogate, Chang (Vithaya Pansringarm), is a sword-wielding retired policeman whom the production notes describe as â€œa figurehead of divine justice who has resolved to scourge the corrupt underworld of brothels and fight clubs.â€ù When not slicing and dicing people, he can be found crooning pop songs in a karaoke bar.

Unable to give his automaton any suggestion of an inner life, Mr. Gosling moves through â€œOnly God Forgivesâ€ù as if in a slow-motion trance. He starred in Mr. Refnâ€™s last film, â€œDrive,â€ù and will survive this catastrophe. But whether Mr. Refn can recover is open to question.

â€œOnly God Forgivesâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for extreme, bloody violence; grisly images; sexual content; and language.

The gag, or one of three, in Dean Parisotâ€™s action-comedy sequel â€œRED 2â€ù is that its killer oldsters are unflappable not because theyâ€™re too cool but because theyâ€™re seen-it-all semi-retirees. Cars careen, lazily written infiltration plans are executed, and the violence is plentiful and toothless. You can tell the villain has been revealed when heâ€™s the only one who really cares about murder.
â€œRED 2â€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Former killers bloodlessly taking care of business â€” nothing to be alarmed about.

In 1988 a BBC talk show, â€œThatâ€™s Life,â€ù invited Nicholas Winton, then 79, to sit in the front row of the studio audience while his good works were praised. He had saved the lives of 669 children, most of them Jewish, in Nazi-occupied Czechoslovakia with his own personal Kindertransport. The woman sitting next to him at the show was one of them. And if you donâ€™t feel teary when Mr. Winton learns on the air that virtually everyone in the audience that day had been one of those children, you have no heart.

The scene appears in â€œNickyâ€™s Family,â€ù an enthralling documentary by Matej Minac that artfully tells the story of how Mr. Winton, now 104, a British stockbroker, gave up a 1938 skiing holiday to answer a friendâ€™s request for help in Prague and didnâ€™t stop helping until the warâ€™s beginning stopped him. He worked frantically, placing youngsters in English homes; put away photos and documents about his project; and told nobody, not even his wife. She eventually discovered his scrapbooks in the attic; his secrecy is never fully explained.

With lovely cinematography and lively editing, the story is told in vintage black-and-white film clips that seem oddly fresh; present-day interviews; and the kind of dramatic re-creation video usually seen on basic-cable crime or ghost shows. But those scenes, shot in muted colors with hints of sepia, are surprisingly evocative.
The Canadian journalist Joe Schlesinger narrates. He, too, was one of the 669.

With performances that take up roughly 15 minutes of screen time combined, Stephen Moyer and Radha Mitchell star in â€œEvidenceâ€ù in much the same way that God stars in the Old Testament. â€œWeâ€™re the police,â€ù a detective says at one point. â€œWeâ€™re not just idiots running around.â€ù
You mean, like the rest of the cast?

In the 2011 remake of â€œThe Green Hornet,â€ù in which he played Kato, Jay Chou, the Taiwanese pop singer and actor, paid homage to Bruce Lee. Demonstrating all manner of choreography â€” song-and-dance numbers, kung fu battles, high-speed chases â€” â€œThe Rooftopâ€ù is frenzied, funny and knowing, drenched in lavish, often surreal, imagery. The filmâ€™s uneven final reel grows increasingly dark, as scores are bloodily settled. Predictably, Mr. Chouâ€™s pop-kitsch impulses â€” he wrote 10 songs for the filmâ€™s score â€” win out. Still, as a showcase of his imagination and ambition, â€œThe Rooftopâ€ù makes a memorable calling card.

â€œThereâ€™s something historical about us,â€ù says one of the Romeows, a crew of septuagenarians that generally meets every Wednesday in Brooklyn for dinner and conversation. Heâ€™s right, and history should record their weekly â€” but rare â€” achievement more often. Thank goodness this gentle, affectionate documentary does it.

Thereâ€™s nothing flashy about â€œThe Romeowsâ€ù the film or the Romeows the men, but what theyâ€™ve created â€” their lifeâ€™s art â€” matters. Itâ€™s sitting around a restaurant, eating family style, every Wednesday, just to talk. (Romeows stands for Retired Older Men Eating Out Wednesdays.)

Thereâ€™s no narrative drive, and none is needed. The primary members have been bonded since their days as Brooklyn College undergraduates, when they formed a house plan, described as an informal alternative to fraternities. Thereâ€™s a scene in which they attend their 50th reunion at the college in 2009, but mostly we just see them sitting at a table â€” or standing around Nathanâ€™s Famous in Coney Island â€” talking about memories, politics, culture and friendship.

A few well-known folks show up in the honorary Romeow world, including Senator Barbara Boxer of California, but they just chat as well. The cameraâ€™s not interested in anything more than these great older faces and what they have to say. Itâ€™s the affirming longevity of that lifelong chat, and the celebration of it, that makes them and this film special.

Unapologetically designed both to inform and affect, Gabriela Cowperthwaiteâ€™s delicately lacerating documentary, â€œBlackfish,â€ù uses the tragic tale of a single whale and his human victims as the backbone of a hypercritical investigation into the marine-park giant SeaWorld Entertainment.

Denied on-camera interviews with park executives, who have strenuously taken issue with the filmâ€™s contentions in a lengthy news release, Ms. Cowperthwaite tells the distressing story of Tilikum, a 12,000-pound bull orca implicated in the deaths of three people. Through the rueful voices of former trainers and whale experts, a narrative driven by disillusion and regret unfolds as the trainers point to a gap between SeaWorldâ€™s public image and behind-the-scenes reality.

Seemingly supported by chilling video and the oral testimonies of two witnesses to Tilikumâ€™s first attack in 1991, the trainers accuse SeaWorld of cover-ups and misinformation. Much of the footage is painful to watch: bleeding whales, flanks raked by the teeth of their fellow captives; a trainer crushed between two gigantic beasts with only his wet suit holding him together; another trainer dragged repeatedly to the bottom of a pool until he manages to escape. Providing context for this alarming behavior, researchers describe highly socialized, caring creatures used to living in thousands of miles of ocean and ill suited to theme parks where they may be subjected to repeated overnight confinements in dark concrete pens.

â€œIf you were in a bathtub for 25 years, donâ€™t you think youâ€™d get a little psychotic?â€ù Jane Velez-Mitchell, a CNN anchor, wonders in a clip thatâ€™s used in the film. Other signs of mental distress, like severe tooth and stomach problems caused by the whales gnawing on their enclosures, are described. But the filmâ€™s most harrowing moment occurs not while addressing Tilikumâ€™s 2010 mutilation and killing of a senior trainer, Dawn Brancheau, at the park in Orlando, Fla., but in a face-to-face with a former whale hunter, the diver John Crowe. Tearfully recalling his traumatic capture of whale calves four decades ago in Puget Sound while their mothers howled pitifully (â€œWe were only after the little onesâ€ù), Mr. Crowe seems haunted to this day by the unearthly sound of the animalsâ€™ apparent grieving.

Calmly and methodically countering SeaWorldâ€™s contention that whales benefit from captivity â€” the Web site â€œOrcas in Captivityâ€ù places the current total at 45 â€” Ms. Cowperthwaite questions the advisability of exploiting mammals whose brains, the neuroscientist Lori Marino suggests, may be more complex than our own.
â€œWhen you look into their eyes, you know somebody is home,â€ù one of the trainers says. Perhaps thatâ€™s why SeaWorldâ€™s most well-known show was called â€œBelieve.â€ù
â€œBlackfishâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Gouged whales and mauled humans.

A mindblower of a mockumentary, â€œColossusâ€ù will leave you reeling in the best of ways, dizzy from a rock â€™nâ€™ roll Tilt-A-Whirl that swirls with duplicity and hilarity. At its core is a vÃ©ritÃ© documentary by a Cockney-spouting producer, Clark Larson, about his â€œartificial bandâ€ù of mostly Americans, living for three months in a house in Russia.

The band, called Colossus, is invented simply for the film and works and lives under increasingly underfinanced conditions, all for the sake of Clarkâ€™s documentary within the documentary we see. And the members of the documentary crew â€” the real one and the fake one, maybe â€” are living under the same circumstances, devolving from professional standards to whatever works.

Confused? Just wait. Anchored by lectures from Clark (played with effortless verve by the filmâ€™s director, Mark Hendrickson) on how easy, helpful and normal it is to be manipulative, the documentary we see and the one within it are not as they appear. Nor is Clark.

His struggling will make you gasp at his preposterous lies one minute and admire his vision the next. The movie is thick with levels: the music (not always good, but even then feeds the film in good ways); the camerawork (from a Russian-style montage of the history of corrupted power to phantasmagorical play with angles and frame speed); and the morality tale. If, at times, thereâ€™s a sense that the playfulness is getting out of control, the movieâ€™s liberated use of the powers of filmmaking â€” which, letâ€™s face it, are all about manipulation â€” make it not just worthwhile but boldly so.

â€œStill Mine,â€ù like Michael Hanekeâ€™s â€œAmourâ€ù and Sarah Polleyâ€™s â€œAway From Her,â€ù is an old-age love story told with minimal sentimentality. If â€œAmour,â€ù with its unflinching vision of dementia, is the toughest of the three, and â€œAway From Herâ€ù is the saddest, â€œStill Mine,â€ù directed and written by Michael McGowan, has a similar spiky integrity. Dry-eyed and observant, it refuses to pity Craig and Irene Morrison (James Cromwell and GeneviÃ¨ve Bujold), the aged couple at its center.
â€œIâ€™m just worried that our luck is beginning to run out,â€ù frets Craig, a proud, eagle-eyed geezer, after discovering that Irene, in a mental lapse, has fallen down the stairs.
â€œI donâ€™t think so,â€ù she replies cheerfully. â€œBy all rights, I should have broken my hip.â€ù

The Morrisons, in their late 80s, are the heart and soul of this small, sturdy film with great North Atlantic scenery. Living outside the village of St. Martins in New Brunswick, Canada, they are keenly aware that after spending 61 years together and raising seven children, their time is running out.

Craigâ€™s short-term solution to their problems is to build a smaller home on their 2,000 acres. Two of their children (Rick Roberts and Julie Stewart), who warily keep tabs on them, offer to help. But Craig, who is descended from a long line of shipbuilders, insists on doing it alone, even after his best friend warns that no one over 70 should get on a ladder. The children know better than to push their stubbornly independent parents to give up their way of life and move into a retirement home.

The image of the fiercely self-reliant Craig raging against the dying of the light may verge on clichÃ©. But Mr. Cromwell, who is more than a decade younger than his character, lends Craig a compelling depth, intelligence and resoluteness. He stands about 6-foot-7, and with a Roman nose on a head that seems chiseled out of rock, radiates an imperial authority. Ms. Bujold, alert and birdlike, imbues Irene with a starchy tenacity and a sharp sense of humor.

The Morrisons are still in love. In one of the movieâ€™s most powerful moments, Irene, her eyes flashing with anticipation, asks Craig to take off his clothes. â€œI want to look at you, old man,â€ù she says lustily before they embrace, naked. Irene is still capable of jealousy. After reminding her husband of the one woman, long dead, who threatened to come between them, she warns him that if he ever cheats on her, sheâ€™ll leave him. From his expression of absolute devotion, it is clear that will not happen.

In the slender plot, Craig proceeds to build his dream house by hand, unaware, until a hard-nosed government inspector (Jonathan Potts) comes calling, that he is flouting the local building code by not submitting plans and specifications for approval. After a stop work order is imposed, and numerous building code violations are cited, Craig eloquently argues his case. But there is no fighting the rigid, unsympathetic bureaucracy. Even an articulate, sympathetic lawyer (Campbell Scott) makes no headway. The rules are the rules. Along with the possibility of imprisonment, Craig risks having the half-finished structure bulldozed.

â€œStill Mineâ€ù doesnâ€™t carry us to the moment when the Morrisonsâ€™ luck runs out. There is a respite. But the end is clearly in sight. The filmâ€™s vision of a long-married couple keeping each other going with mutual love and support, and a shared resistance to outside interference, is more vital than a thousand movies populated by hot, squirming teenagers.
â€œStill Mineâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). It has partial nudity.
Unfolding in Brooklyn on the night of President Obamaâ€™s 2008 election, â€œBig Wordsâ€ù explores weighty themes with a very light touch.

Weaving race, class, sexual orientation and politics â€” as well as the evolution of rap music â€” into a wistful tapestry of male disaffection, the filmâ€™s writer and director, Neil Drumming, introduces three not-so-young men whose friendship fell apart 15 years earlier along with their rising hip-hop group.

All are to some extent stalled in the past, paralyzed by issues and resentments they have never addressed. John (Dorian Missick), a rhyming genius recently fired from the computer job he despised, hangs out in a strip club, unsure of his next move. His cousin James (Gbenga Akinnagbe), a successful publicist dissatisfied with his upscale life and long-term boyfriend, is unwilling to recall his history as a closeted rapper. And Terry (Darien Sills-Evans), angry and aimless, remains soured by the bitterness of success denied and talent betrayed.

As Mr. Drummingâ€™s whip-smart screenplay effects an uncomfortable group reunion, the filmâ€™s playlike structure and relaxed rhythms perfectly frame conversations infused with pre-gentrification memories and music industry nostalgia. Throughout, his droll, insightful dialogue has a natural pop and sway that the actors clearly relish â€” especially Yaya Alafia, magnificent as a coolly self-possessed dancer who sees right through Johnâ€™s smoke screen of apathy.

Warmly photographed by Cliff Charles, â€œBig Wordsâ€ù is an engrossing, coming-of-middle-age drama that shows how disappointment can fester and derail a life. By the end, hope and change seem possible but far from guaranteed.

The dread gathers and surges while the blood scarcely trickles in â€œThe Conjuring,â€ù a fantastically effective haunted-house movie. Set largely in 1971, it purports to tell a story based on â€œtrue case filesâ€ù about a family of seven whose pastoral dream became a nightmare soon after they moved into a Rhode Island farmhouse. One day, Mom, Dad and the girls are settling into their conveniently sprawling, creaking, squeaking two-story house â€” the rooms quickly become a disorienting maze â€” and the next, theyâ€™re playing hide and creep with a mysterious, increasingly malevolent force.

The director James Wan plays much the same game with you. Written by the brothers Chad Hayes and Carey W. Hayes, the movie opens with a jittery, funny prologue involving a couple of pretty nurses right out of a Roger Corman quickie, a devil doll named Annabelle (shades of Rod Serling and Chucky) and a pair of married paranormal experts, Ed and Lorraine Warren (Patrick Wilson and Vera Farmiga). The Warrens quickly take care of business, and Mr. Wan does the same. With shock cuts, gliding camera movements, muted colors that evoke David Fincherâ€™s â€œZodiacâ€ù and tricks learned from â€œThe Twilight Zone,â€ù Mr. Wan â€” whose first sly shot is of a cracked, smiling face â€” sets a relentlessly uneasy tone that imperceptively shifts between intense seriousness and lightly mocking.

The real Ed and Lorraine Warren, lifelong investigators of the paranormal â€” their Web site calls him a demonologist and her a trance medium â€” established the grandly named New England Society for Psychic Research in 1952 but are most famous for their exploits in another house, in Amityville, on Long Island. (Mr. Warren died in 2006; Ms. Warren was a consultant on â€œThe Conjuring.â€ù) The Warrens declared that Dutch Colonial demonic, a diagnosis that led to more than a dozen â€œAmityvilleâ€ù movies and stoked the market for haunted-house tales. What happened when the Warrens entered the Rhode Island home in â€œThe Conjuringâ€ù hasnâ€™t received the same attention, although one of the daughters, Andrea Perron, has published a memoir.

The movie takes off with Carolyn (an excellent Lili Taylor) and Roger (Ron Livingston, very good), moving their family into their new home. Heâ€™s a truck driver, while she runs the house and five girls ranging from preschool age to high school. Theyâ€™re appealingly real, with an easy intimacy thatâ€™s strikingly different from the canned version briefly seen in a clip from â€œThe Brady Bunch.â€ù The only perceptible crack in the facade is that theyâ€™re struggling financially, a fissure suggested by Carolynâ€™s quietly tense demeanor, Rogerâ€™s knotted forehead and the houseâ€™s smudged, unpainted walls. Once they move in, they canâ€™t move out, a bad situation that speaks as much to today as to the storyâ€™s inflation-plagued period. Things are rocky even before they go bump in the night.

When Mr. Wan lingers on Carolynâ€™s crumbling smile itâ€™s obvious that it isnâ€™t only the Perron house thatâ€™s troubled. Itâ€™s been estimated that 75 percent of Americans believe in the paranormal, while only 54 percent believe global warming has begun. Evidently itâ€™s easier to believe in the terrors that canâ€™t hurt us than to believe in those that can, which may partly account for why so many vampires, zombies and their paranormal ilk are running amok in the popular imagination. Each era brings its own allegorical terrors, and in the 1970s, a golden age of horror cinema, the aftershocks of the 1960s found expression in stories about diabolically terrifying spawn who, with their swiveling heads and annihilating violence, were grotesque embodiments of a generational anxiety.

â€œThe Conjuringâ€ù isnâ€™t just primarily set in the 1970s, it also taps into the paranoia that is both an evergreen American trait and a crucial characteristic of films of that era, horror and otherwise. With amusing self-awareness, Mr. Wan (his earlier movies include â€œSawâ€ù and â€œInsidiousâ€ù) leans on the usual genre tricks throughout, making you jump with hard edits and doors being squeaked open by unseen hands. But he also makes intelligent use of narrative delay and ellipses that help build suspense and suspicion. The script generally doesnâ€™t overexplain, and neither does he. When things start going wrong at the Perronsâ€™ â€” a bird crashes into the house, bruises bloom on Carolynâ€™s body â€” the family knows somethingâ€™s amiss but canâ€™t read the signs. The deeply religious Warrens (Lorraine wraps rosary beads around one hand) think that they can, and do.

Mr. Wilson makes Ed an appealing, somewhat ridiculous square, which fits nicely with Ms. Farmigaâ€™s unsmiling intensity and undercurrents of fragility. Their characters are as appealing as the Perrons, but Mr. Wan smartly keeps enough distance from the Warrens that you can see that these true believers are also hovering at the edge of dangerous fanaticism. That gives the movie a shiver of political currency even if a greater, more sustaining pleasure of this particular haunted-house fantasy is how it works as a metaphor for moviegoing itself. When the Perrons first settle into their house, theyâ€™re facing the future with bright, anxious smiles that arenâ€™t much different from those of the horror-film faithful who are waiting nervously, hopefully, to be jolted by the next great shocker. Itâ€™s here.
â€œThe Conjuringâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Haunted-house terror.

Committed genre fans endure enormous amounts of recycled garbage in hopes of seeing something, anything, new. Even the most forgiving have their limits, though, and this weekâ€™s multiplex terminus can be found in the noisy nonsense known as â€œR.I.P.D.â€ù

Based on â€œRest in Peace Department,â€ù a Dark Horse comic created by Peter M. Lenkov, the movie has the kind of clever-enough premise that could be easily pitched at a 60-second meeting: a heavenly police force hunts dead villains and sends them to hell. Written by Phil Hay and Matt Manfredi, the movie was directed by Robert Schwentke, who made a promising thriller (â€œFlightplanâ€ù) a few years back.

A barely expressive Ryan Reynolds has the role of Nick Walker, a Boston cop, who after being shot down by his partner (Kevin Bacon), ends up slinging guns for the R.I.P.D. Nick is brought up to speed on the departmentâ€™s doings by Mary-Louise Parker, whoâ€™s carving out a curious action niche playing anti-Barbie romantic foils. Sheâ€™s paired with Bruce Willis in â€œRedâ€ù and â€œRed 2,â€ù and here she matches (half) wits with Jeff Bridges playing Roy Pulsifer, a 19th-century lawman who wears a duster to go with his Buffalo Bill goatee and silky mane. Mr. Bridges is almost always fun to watch, but even his squinting and Slim Pickens-style whooping canâ€™t make the time pass faster.

Stuff happens, most of it crushingly dull. There are gun battles and explosions and at one point masses of junky-looking digital monsters run amok, but whatâ€™s missing is whatâ€™s often absent in industrial moviemaking of this type: story and characters, yes, but also the human touch and a sense that someone behind the scenes actually cares about the work.

Mr. Bridges looks as if heâ€™s having it easier biding his time than does Mr. Reynolds, who looks bored out of his mind or maybe just depressed at his latest career move. Whatâ€™s really a drag about â€œR.I.P.D.â€ù is that itâ€™s exactly the kind of rotten comic-book adaptation that helps give comic-book adaptations a bad name.
â€œR.I.P.D.â€ù is rated PG-13. (Parents strongly cautioned.) Gun violence, explosions and general idiocy.

There is something for everyone in Prabhudhevaâ€™s ambitious Bollywood film â€œRamaiya Vastavaiyaâ€ù â€” comedy, romance, action and the obligatory music-and-dancing numbers â€” but hardly any of it is convincing, and the proceedings are rife with clichÃ©s. (The film, a remake of his own â€œNuvvostanante Nenoddantana,â€ù from 2005, seems to have been made anew for the big-screen debut of Girish Kumar, the son of the music and film producer Kumar S. Taurani.)

In the first half, viewers are whisked to a wedding celebration, where the playful jokester Ram (Mr. Kumar), the brideâ€™s cousin, falls in love with Sona (Shruti Hassan), a poor girl from a village in Punjab, who is the brideâ€™s best friend. Sona thinks Ram, raised in Australia by billionaire parents, is a spoiled brat. He doesnâ€™t do much to prove her wrong. Itâ€™s more hate at first sight than love, but Ram wins her over eventually.

One hurdle down, but then thereâ€™s a bigger one: Their families just donâ€™t feel the love. Ramâ€™s mother thinks Sona is a straight-up schemer and boots her from the festivities. Later on, when Ram arrives in Sonaâ€™s village to ask for her hand, Sonaâ€™s brother, Raghu (sincerely portrayed by Sonu Sood), presents him with an impossible challenge: To marry Sona, Ram must farm a parcel of land and reap more wheat than Raghu.

While Mr. Kumarâ€™s goofy routine is a bit much in the first half (nearly undermining the plausibility of the romance), he hits a better stride in the more serious second half, when Ram disproves Raghuâ€™s own bias â€œthat the rich donâ€™t value relationships.â€ù But then again, you canâ€™t really blame a man for being protective of his young sister in a world of salivating men and rich parents hellbent on protecting their interests at any cost.

Somebody else almost always has it worse, â€œTerrafermaâ€ù reminds us, but thatâ€™s not a comfort in this latest film from Emanuele Crialese. Far from it. For a fisherman and his family struggling to make a living in the 21st century on a Sicilian island, a flood of illegal African immigrants brings moral questions and other complications to their doorstep. Playing out the consequences of that encounter on the family yields dramatic moments of decision, but what comes afterward feels more like a show of resolve than compelling drama.

While the blaze of sun and the glittering sea bottled on screen are invigorating, Mr. Crialese plunks down a familiar old-ways/new-ways story. The bearded patriarch, Ernesto (Mimmo Cuticchio), wants to keep fishing with his adolescent grandson, Filippo (Filippo Pucillo). Ernestoâ€™s son, who organizes parties and activities for tourists, says the boat would make more money when junked for scrap. Ernestoâ€™s daughter, Giulietta (Donatella Finocchiaro) â€” Filippoâ€™s young-looking mother â€” opts for renting out rooms.

When Ernesto and Filippo happen upon a boat of refugees, they find that their altruistic impulses put them at odds with the police. Giulietta does her part, secretly harboring a pregnant Ethiopian (Timnit T., a real-life refugee) at the same time sheâ€™s hosting three young Italian weekenders.

Mr. Crialese, who also directed â€œRespiroâ€ù off the coast of Sicily and the trans-Atlantic immigrantâ€™s tale â€œGolden Door,â€ù makes an effort to ennoble his subjects. A dinner scene is delicately rendered with chiaroscuro lighting, while alternating head-on shots during tense conversations between Timnit T. and Ms. Finocchiaro seem intended to confront the audience with the gravity of the situation. Even the filmâ€™s title invites comparison to â€œLa Terra Trema,â€ù Luchino Viscontiâ€™s 1948 Marxist-neorealist classic about fishermen under the thumb of middlemen.

But itâ€™s rare for Mr. Crialeseâ€™s political conscience to translate into an organic emotional payoff. One such scene does come after Filippoâ€™s moonlit boat date with a visiting tourist is nightmarishly interrupted by another tide of refugees, with grim consequences the next morning.

Itâ€™s a striking moment, as is the filmâ€™s boldly prolonged final shot of a boat alone at sea. But as â€œTerrafermaâ€ù tightens its focus on a courageous resolution of tough issues, too much nuance is jettisoned along the way.
â€œTerrafermaâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for some language, brief nudity and violent encounters.

For her fifth feature documentary, â€œFirst Comes Love,â€ù the Brooklyn filmmaker Nina Davenport continues to explore her favorite subject â€” herself. Childless at 41, confronting her â€œrapidly diminishing ovarian reserveâ€ù and a persistent lack of potential baby daddies, Ms. Davenport embarked on the in-vitro highway. A camera, a posse of friends and a casually affluent family followed along.

â€œMy aunt is crazy,â€ù opines her 11-year-old nephew, Addison. Ms. Davenportâ€™s father agrees, calmly refusing to endorse a decision that he deems â€œridiculous.â€ù Polling continues, in vignettes that veer from celebratory to cautionary to terrifying. (The single friend frazzled by two rambunctious toddlers will haunt me for some time.) The approach is cheerfully candid and the humor often sly: as one sister-in-law warns of the financial stresses of child rearing, the camera pulls back cheekily to reveal a beautifully appointed mansion filled with toys.

Yet this midlife confessional could have reached beyond the maternal cravings of highly educated, urban-dwelling singletons had it plumbed peopleâ€™s heads as thoroughly as Ms. Davenportâ€™s birth canal. Neither Eric, her initially reluctant sperm donor, nor Amy, her best friend and birthing partner, has any desire to be a parent, but both find their commitment qualms trampled beneath Ms. Davenportâ€™s single-minded sprint to the delivery room. And though her father might come across as an insensitive naysayer, I rather liked him: smart and pragmatic, heâ€™s the kind of parent who thinks caring for children means more than just cheerleading. Later, as we watch him bounce baby Jasper on his knee (noting how closely the tyke resembles the man most opposed to his conception), the film becomes less a superficial chronicle of one womanâ€™s desire for a child than a recognition of the forces that kick into play once that child has arrived. Whether we want them to or not.

Jamie Babbitâ€™s golden-hued noir, â€œBreaking the Girls,â€ù takes inspiration from Hitchcockâ€™s psychological thriller â€œStrangers on a Trainâ€ù (itself based on Patricia Highsmithâ€™s novel) and updates it for the texting, itâ€™s-all-about-me generation. But this film goes further, turning the tale into an erotic thriller with too many twists and back stories to count.

Sara and Alex, jokingly plot to kill the otherâ€™s nemesis, but Alex (Madeline Zima), a wealthy wild child with emotional issues, takes it seriously. When they first meet, Alex plays seductress and ensnares Sara (a pleasantly subtle Agnes Bruckner), a law-school student on a scholarship whose world starts to crumble after a rival rats her out for stealing from a tip jar at the bar where she works.

She moves in with Alex, and they share a bed, but Saraâ€™s not on board for murder; Alex, however, will do just about anything to get her way. What follows after one dead body turns up and then another are conspiracies and improbable turns. Ms. Babbit (â€œBut Iâ€™m a Cheerleaderâ€ù) opts for tightly focused shots and close-ups, heightening the sense of Alex and Saraâ€™s isolation and desperation.

Savvy viewers may question a seemingly bright Sara who makes statements like, â€œDonâ€™t you wish that killing could just be legal?â€ù In the meantime, the film does offer some rewards: cameos by Melanie Mayron (â€œthirtysomethingâ€ù) and Davenia McFadden, whom some may recognize from her brilliant turn as the home-invading Grandma Ida on â€œMad Menâ€ù last season.

â€œDrug War,â€ù Johnnie Toâ€™s ferocious crime story, opens with bilious green smoke darkening the sky and ends with a tsunami of blood spilling onto the ground. The green billows out of an illegal meth lab that has exploded while the red pours from the dead and the dying who, throughout this excitingly directed movie, have chased one another as if to the ends of the earth. If the green smoke suggested â€œgo,â€ù the blood can only mean one thing: â€œstop,â€ù which, taken with the surrounding human wreckage, serves as an unmistakably fierce authorial commentary.

The same can be said of all the savagery wedged between the smoke and the blood. Effectively a feature-length chase sequence interrupted by moments of weird comedy and interludes of savage violence, the story and its sympathies are neatly split between bad guys and good, a narrative and emotional divide that has an unsettling effect, much like the crazed yet scarily controlled laughter of one of the villains. And while Mr. To may not fill the movie with rousing speeches, either by inclination or out of political necessity, the brilliant, unsettling action scenes â€” ugly, savage, dehumanizing â€” speak volumes. (This is one of the rare times that the Hong Kong master has shot on the mainland, and if he faced any pressure from Chinaâ€™s censors to soften his material, it isnâ€™t evident to an outsider.)

The characters are introduced rapidly, as is Mr. Toâ€™s fashion. Among the principals are Timmy Choi (a great Louis Koo), a drug kingpin first seen driving away from the meth lab, barely holding onto the wheel as he begins to literally foam at the mouth. Itâ€™s instructive that his law-enforcement counterpart and narrative double, Captain Zhang (Sun Honglei, fantastic), is also introduced while in transit, aboard a bus loaded with contraband, and that heâ€™s initially under cover pretending to be a criminal. Choi and Zhang may be racing forward â€” all the characters rack up miles, their spinning wheels turning this into something of an intermittent road movie â€” but they never seem to get far enough. Round and round they go in a relentless chase that soon feels like a circle.

It can take some doing to figure out whoâ€™s going where and why. Mr. To likes to play with austerity and overload, sometimes mercilessly so. The sheer number of characters zigzagging through the beginning of â€œDrug Warâ€ù â€” many behind a wheel â€” means that sometimes you just need to go with the flow and worry about whatâ€™s happening later. Thatâ€™s a nice change from movies that needlessly hold your hand through every turn, but it also means that you shouldnâ€™t blink. If you do, you may wonder who the two scruffy guys are in the car thatâ€™s chasing the big truck thatâ€™s being driven by two other disheveled guys who seem to have something to do with Choi, whose path and fate will soon cross with those of Captain Zhang, once this heroically peripatetic detective gets off his bus.

He does and, after bringing down someone with a high-flying scissor hold, brings you into a complicated tale that reaches from the crime lords who imperiously flout Chinaâ€™s draconian drug laws to the struggling men and women who in an earlier age would have been slaving over the emperorâ€™s lands. That in itself is startling, as are so many of the details â€” a detective washing recently excreted balloons stuffed with drugs â€” that insistently underscore the human stakes in this war. Among the most unexpected moments in a movie filled with them is the group of sympathetically drawn deaf, mute drug workers. Whether laughing or sharing a convivial meal in a factory crammed with drugs, they are the manifestation of a people who, Mr. To bluntly suggests, must be heard.

With a movie called â€œFrankensteinâ€™s Army,â€ù youâ€™d have every reason to expect a generous serving of cheese along with abundant helpings of gore and gunplay. And you certainly get it in this frenetic found-footage horror film set in the German countryside in 1945.

A Soviet filmmaker (Alexander Mercury) shooting a propaganda movie follows a squad of soldiers â€” archetypes like the hotheaded Vassili (Andrei Zayats), the timid Sacha (Luke Newberry) and the handsome, sympathetic Sergei (Joshua Sasse) â€” behind enemy lines. Before long, they encounter corpses whose innards are bursting with circuitry. A brutal raid on a humble village leads the troop to an underground lair where a mad scientist (Karel Roden), the great-great-grandson of Baron von Frankenstein, has been grafting body parts and scrap metal to create a horde of highly inhospitable cyborgs.

These â€œzombotsâ€ù (conceived by Richard Raaphorst, a longtime conceptual artist for movies, making his feature directing debut) suggest a kind of midcentury steampunk. One incorporates a drill snout, another a deep-sea-diving helmet. Their names include Razorteeth (whose head has mandibles reminiscent of a Venus fly trap), Mosquito Man (with stiltlike appendages) and the self-explanatory Propellerhead. Faded color and overexposed-celluloid textures add antique flavor, as does the refreshing absence of digital effects for the creatures. Narrative depth may be in short supply, but the energy, invention and humor are bracing. And letâ€™s face it: Sometimes cheese tastes good.
â€œFrankensteinâ€™s Armyâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for ripped intestines and an unholy human-teddy-bear hybrid.

Neandertal is a valley in Germany. That meager fact is a spoiler for â€œNeander-Jin: The Return of the Neanderthal Man,â€ù because there is virtually nothing else of value to be gained from watching this film.

In this feature-length crime against comedy from Florian Steinbiss, a Neanderthal magically appears at a rural water-pump station in present-day Germany. A woman (Sarah Muehlhause) who we are told is an environmental sciences student takes a fancy to him despite the skepticism of her egghead father (Mr. Steinbiss). A conniving producer (Milton Welsh) and a pop anthropologist (Jeff Hixon, the filmâ€™s co-writer and executive producer) vie to make a buck off the new arrival.

Routinely botching the basics of setting up characters and scenarios, the film lets punch lines die like dogs and at times resembles a pornographic film without the sex. The Neanderthal himself (Jon Chardiet, who starred in the 1984 hip-hop tie-in â€œBeat Streetâ€ù) makes one pine for the comparatively quicksilver stylings of â€œEncino Man.â€ù
An affront to Neanderthals and modern humans alike, â€œNeander-Jinâ€ù may set us all back thousands of years.

Tourism is not simple. You can say that again, and put a dissertation behind it, when wealthy traveling Americans engage with subsistence economies. In â€œPostales,â€ù a searching and human film directed by Josh Hyde and set in Cuzco, Peru, one grim-faced local woman commodifies herself by donning traditional colorful clothes, pulling a llama along and posing for pictures outside expensive hotels. The cameras snap away. As she says, itâ€™s her job.

â€œPostales,â€ù a joint production of Peruvian and American companies, connects two families â€” one from each nation â€” in ways that seem far too coincidental and multifarious for a story thatâ€™s not a fable. Cuzco is depicted here with a quiet, beautifully filmed naturalism, using medium shots of street dogs juxtaposed with wide shots of shanty squeezed next to shanty in the hills over the Plaza, the city center where most of the filmâ€™s action takes place.

There we meet two 12-year-olds: the honorable Pablo (a sad-faced Guimel Soria Martinez) and Mary (Nadia Alexander, in a performance of natural emotional acuity). Pablo sells postcards (the â€œpostalesâ€ù of the title) for a living. Mary arrives with picture-taking enthusiasm, but unlike the rest of her family, sheâ€™s honestly curious about her surroundings. That quality leads her to Pablo and to a genuine cultural education.

The families of Pablo and Mary also interact, in less compelling and believable ways, but there is strong work from Megan Tusing, Humberto Chaparro and especially Annie Kozuch, who, as Maryâ€™s altitude-troubled mother, acts with telling subtlety.

While the film is let down by its plot, it is much too smart for reductive visions of â€œthe other.â€ù And there are moments, like a heartfelt exchange of keepsakes, when seeing â€œPostalesâ€ù is a memory worth preserving.

Though I sometimes tire of the sufferings of superheroes, I have a permanent soft spot for the Wolverine, the Marvel mutant whose indestructibility causes him endless physical and existential pain. As played by Hugh Jackman through six â€œX-Menâ€ù features (including one about the Wolverineâ€™s origins), he is a shaggy, soulful, perpetually roughed-up character, and a bit of a misfit even among his peers.

â€œThe Wolverine,â€ù directed by James Mangold (â€œWalk the Line,â€ù â€œ3:10 to Yumaâ€ù) and written by Mark Bomback and Scott Frank, is also something of an anomaly in the current, unstoppable wave of comic-book-based movies. It has all the requisite special effects and big-ticket action sequences â€” including a fight on a moving train and a climactic punch-out between the hero and a villain in an oversize metal suit â€” but it also has an unusually intimate, small-scale feel. Inspired by a series published by Marvel in the 1980s, it has more old-style comic-book atmosphere than â€œMan of Steelâ€ù or â€œIron Man 3.â€ù Instead of expounding a tedious origin story or staging an epic battle for apocalyptic stakes, â€œThe Wolverineâ€ù focuses on a specific and self-contained adventure in a richly imagined place.

That would be Japan, where Logan (as the bewhiskered berserker is also known) witnesses the bombing of Nagasaki at the end of World War II. The destruction of cities is of course a staple of action moviemaking, and it is usually saved for the end and shown in crashing, flaming detail. Mr. Mangold defies clichÃ© by dramatizing the actual devastation of a city from a discreet distance early in the film. The atomic bomb casts its shadow over the rest of the movie â€” much as the Holocaust did in â€œX-Men: First Classâ€ù â€” in a sober, tactful way, a sign that the filmmaker is not simply stirring reality into fantasy but rather trying to think about the relationship between them.

After a detour into present-day Alaska, where he proves himself a friend to grizzly bears and an enemy of hunters and personal grooming, Logan is spirited back to Japan. There he finds himself embroiled in a complicated family crisis involving yakuza, samurai, corporate bosses and corrupt politicians. To ensure that no Japanese cultural archetype goes unexploited, Loganâ€™s guide and self-appointed bodyguard is a J-Pop warrior pixie named Yukio (Rila Fukushima) who brings a bright splash of anime color and energy to the movie.

Yukio works for the dysfunctional and powerful Yashida clan, whose patriarch (Haruhiko Yamanouchi) Logan rescued from the radiation in Nagasaki. Yashidaâ€™s granddaughter Mariko (Tao Okamoto) serves as both damsel in distress â€” everyone in Japan wants to kidnap her, it seems â€” and Loganâ€™s love interest. Because he is technically ageless, this is almost not creepy, but also not entirely convincing.

I will leave the plot to spoil itself, pausing to take note of Svetlana Khodchenkovaâ€™s slinky femme fatale turn as the Viper and Famke Janssenâ€™s ghostly appearance as Jean Grey, the long-dead love of Loganâ€™s very long life. She appears in his dreams to remind him and the audience that within that adamantium skeleton beats a soft and sensitive heart.

And Mr. Jackman, for all his growling, flexing and macho wisecracking, keeps our attention focused on Loganâ€™s feelings. So does Mr. Mangold, even as he obeys the imperatives of the action-franchise machine. A modest superhero picture may sound like a contradiction in terms, but really it is a welcome respite. A short one, to be sure. An end-credits teaser â€” stay in your seat! â€” promises a planet-threatening spectacle to come, probably next summer. No wonder the Wolverine looks tired.
â€œThe Wolverineâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). The heroâ€™s claws do a lot of killing, but the gore is edited away.
The problems of three little people amount to even less than a hill of beans in â€œRed Tide,â€ù a tortured-siblings movie set in a depressed town on the west coast of Florida.

Named for the toxic algae that bloom annually in the Gulf of Mexico (and which we never see), this glum drama, made for a pittance by Dino J. Gallina as part of an M.F.A. requirement at the University of Central Florida, is so cut to the bone it seems to have been written in shorthand. What we can gather is that Alex (Adrian Mancinelli), just freed from the pokey and a drug addiction, has returned home with plans to resurrect the family sponge-diving business with the boat belonging to his deceased father. Thereâ€™s just one problem: His older brother, John (JosuÃ© Gutierrez), has used the boat to finance his cocaine-and-Klonopin habit.

Studded with bleached flashbacks and beached dreams, â€œRed Tideâ€ù offers unsympathetic characters â€” Johnâ€™s fiancÃ©e (Michele Feren Simms) does little but supply her beloved with downers to stop him from bouncing off the walls â€” engaged in uninteresting pursuits. Murder is plotted, and illicit romance is kindled, and a dealer named Harry (as invisible as the algae and sounding exactly like the masked torturer from the â€œSawâ€ù movies) lurks off screen. But the undisciplined shooting style and underdeveloped script confound the actors at every turn. Despite their best efforts, they never overcome the limitations of a movie more intent on cutting corners than fleshing out a story.
It may be time for everyone to agree that if youâ€™ve seen one trapped-in-space-with-an-alien-presence movie, youâ€™ve seen them all.

â€œStranded,â€ù directed by Roger Christian, is such a film, and itâ€™s decently made and acted. But being scary is difficult when the same sort of encounter has been turning up in theaters since Sigourney Weaver was a relative unknown.

A meteor shower damages a lunar base, and the four members of the crew soon realize that some kind of life form entered their hermetically sealed world along with the rocks. The crewâ€™s lone woman (Amy Matysio) goes through a bizarre superfast pregnancy as whatever it is tries to use her body to reproduce itself. Everyone becomes suspicious of everyone else â€” is that you talking, or the life form? â€” and no one agrees on what to do, with the ranking officer (Christian Slater) engaging in power struggles with the baseâ€™s doctor (Brendan Fehr). The engineer (Michael Therriault) begins acting oddly.

Words like â€œreplicateâ€ù and â€œsporesâ€ù get tossed around, as the crew struggles to maintain an air supply and send a distress signal. The actors work hard to make us feel their fear of a creature that, for much of the movie, we donâ€™t get to see. We donâ€™t really need to see it, because weâ€™ve seen it or something like it before.
An exhaustingly pretentious heave of artistic self-involvement, â€œThe Time Beingâ€ù takes an exceptionally handsome journey to nowhere at all.

Getting there, however, requires a great deal of angst and moody visuals, these last faultlessly provided by the Romanian cinematographer Mihai Malaimare Jr. The angst is left to Wes Bentley, playing a struggling, near-catatonic artist named Daniel whose primary modes of expression are staring and brooding. (In a comic book, heâ€™d have a cartoon cloud hovering over his head.) Danielâ€™s wife (Ahna Oâ€™Reilly) is understandably fed up, though probably less for his professional malaise â€” when he does rouse himself, he paints a drowning man â€” than for his utter lack of a personality.

When Daniel is summoned to the gloomy home of Warner, a dying eccentric (an underserved Frank Langella), any hope we might have that something is finally going to happen is soon dashed. Issuing bizarre assignments to videotape sunsets and children, Warner shuffles from bed to sofa and back again, all cryptic comments (â€œArtists donâ€™t have familiesâ€ù) and withering looks. Languid shots of pylons and plumes of paint flowering in water punctuate listless conversations, and the various reflections in Danielâ€™s bulging cornea â€” a clock, a blank canvas â€” are more clearly displayed than the charactersâ€™ motivations.

The first feature from Nenad Cicin-Sain (who also wrote the story with Richard N. Gladstein), â€œThe Time Beingâ€ù wants to say something about artistic selfishness. But itâ€™s speaking in a vacuum; however prettily wrapped, this is still just an empty box.

The English heist movie has a history of being cheeky. From â€œThe Italian Jobâ€ù (1969) through â€œLock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrelsâ€ù (1999), a cool, brazen wit and stylized violence mark some of the best examples of complicated robbery scenarios in British cinema. Rowan Athale does not ignore that inheritance with his dense debut feature, â€œWasteland.â€ù

Yet Mr. Athale, born and raised in Yorkshire, where the film takes place, also guides viewers on a long tour of hopeless youth and realistic violence in the economically ravaged north of England before the playful payoff. To borrow from a term for the gritty, working-class British dramas that this film also nods to, itâ€™s a kitchen-sink caper.

The film begins with an effectively mournful aura as we see the badly beaten up Harvey (Luke Treadaway) under the bright light of police questioning as he explains what led him there in the six weeks since he got out of prison for drug possession. In the flashback scenes that dominate the film, Harvey is reunited with his lifelong best friends, Charlie, Dodd and Dempsey.

The buddies cook up a plan, both for revenge and to start a new life (which is, oddly, the very unglamorous dream of being coffee shop owners in Amsterdam). At times, details of this elaborate crime theyâ€™ve concocted are incomprehensible (as are the thick northern accents, even to someone like me who lived for years in London). But a knotty plot is imperative to Mr. Athaleâ€™s aims, since, like Robert Bressonâ€™s film â€œA Man Escapedâ€ù or Wes Andersonâ€™s â€œBottle Rocket,â€ù this is ultimately a story about friendship, about people who would rather follow a delusional pal than logic.

Sure, you can load a lot of overthink involving male-versus-female perspective onto â€œThe To Do List,â€ù a comedy about a girl determined to lose her virginity the summer after high school graduation. But here is all you really need to know: This movie is smarter and better acted and just plain funnier than most of its predecessors in the my-first-time genre, no matter which sex is losing what.

Aubrey Plaza from â€œParks and Recreationâ€ù is the virgin, Brandy Klark, whom we first meet as she is being introduced as valedictorian of the class of 1993 at a graduation in Boise, Idaho. How strait-laced is this kid? After she goes to an underground graduation party and drinks too much, she returns home and volunteers to be grounded.

But Brandy, egged on by two friends (Alia Shawkat and Sarah Steele) and a libido awakened by an encounter with the hunky Rusty (Scott Porter), decides that she has been missing something and methodically sets out to experience sex and everything leading up to it. Itâ€™s an A-student mind-set applied to a trampy task. When Brandy runs into sexual slang she is unfamiliar with, she tries looking it up in the Encyclopaedia Britannica.

Male teenagers have been losing their virginity in movies for years, but the female version of the same story has been less common, and having a woman (Maggie Carey) as both writer and director sets â€œThe To Do Listâ€ù even further apart. But the sensibility that makes this movie work so well doesnâ€™t seem so much feminine as simply intelligent.

Ms. Plaza is wonderfully deadpan throughout, which gives new hilarity to old jokes involving bodily fluids and waste (and pretty much every variety of those has a cameo here). Ms. Carey shoots the sex and almost-sex scenes humorously rather than voyeuristically, making the movie palatable where others are just crass.

But what really makes it all work is the cast surrounding Ms. Plaza. Bill Hader, who just earned his second Emmy nomination for outstanding supporting actor in a comedy series for â€œSaturday Night Live,â€ù deserves some sort of prize for his sly portrayal of Willy, the mangy manager at a pool where Brandy has a summer job as a lifeguard. Many of the funniest scenes include him, yet he doesnâ€™t steal any of them, a difficult trick. And he even manages to build an oddly touching character.

Clark Gregg also stands out as Brandyâ€™s befuddled, conservative father. And Andy Samberg turns up in a deliciously ridiculous small role that wonâ€™t be spoiled here because part of the fun is in just recognizing him.

The movie probably overindulges in 1990s sight gags â€” early computers, archaic-looking dances and so on. Ms. Plaza, who is 29, isnâ€™t always convincing as a recent high school graduate, and the script projects too many grown-up sexual and other attitudes and outlooks onto teenagers.

Ms. Carey also canâ€™t resist, near the filmâ€™s end, defaulting to the usual messages â€” no one likes a slut; donâ€™t hurt your friendsâ€™ feelings â€” which Ms. Plaza delivers awkwardly, like a hostage being forced to recite something for a video camera. But a funny final scene redeems this misstep nicely. In a summer of (so far) noisy box-office disappointments, â€œThe To Do Listâ€ù (made for a reported $1.2 million) seems likely to demonstrate once again that good writing and acting can often be better investments than ever bigger, ever louder special effects.
â€œThe To Do Listâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian), more for language than for any graphic sex.

When Cate Blanchett first cruises into Woody Allenâ€™s â€œBlue Jasmine,â€ù playing a Park Avenue matron fallen on hard times, she looks like a million bucks. Sheâ€™s wearing pearls and a white Chanel jacket, with an HermÃ¨s bag as big as a Shetland pony hanging off one arm. Itâ€™s the sort of important accessory worn by women accustomed to being chauffeured around town. Soon after, though, as she stands with her monogrammed luggage on a nondescript San Francisco sidewalk, she looks frightened, alone â€” like someone who could benefit from some kindness. Instead, she waves off a stranger and, posing a question thatâ€™s as existential as it is practical, demands, â€œWhere am I, exactly?â€ù

Sheâ€™s in the Mission, for starters, but Jasmine French â€” this lost, lonely woman brilliantly brought to quivering life by Ms. Blanchett â€” is more properly in a Woody Allen movie, his most sustained, satisfying and resonant film since â€œMatch Point.â€ù A moral fable about greed and comeuppance, crimes and misdemeanors, â€œBlue Jasmineâ€ù begins with a socialite brought low and evolves into a tragedy that becomes far greater than her own. Itâ€™s a familiar story with a few of the usual suspects, starting with the husband, Hal (a perfect Alec Baldwin, all smile and no soul), an investment type who has talked high yields all the way to prison. The government took him, and then it took the rest, leaving Jasmine with little more than her designer threads and luggage.

Blanchett, Blanche â€” the names seem fated for each. Mr. Allen has said that he didnâ€™t see Ms. Blanchett play Tennessee Williamsâ€™s most famous creation in Liv Ullmannâ€™s celebrated 2009 production of â€œA Streetcar Named Desireâ€ù at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. (Jasmineâ€™s appalled aside about being forced to move to Brooklyn after being priced out of Manhattan amusingly suggests why he didnâ€™t.) Whatever his inspiration, he has been rummaging around in the classics for decades, so his appropriation of â€œStreetcarâ€ù doesnâ€™t surprise. What does is his reimagining Blanche by way of another figure who changes depending on how you hold her up to the light, Ruth Madoff, the wife of Bernard L. Madoff, the investor turned avatar of a fallen world. Itâ€™s a masterly stroke that puts Jasmineâ€™s dissembling into fresh, chilling perspective.

From the moment Jasmine appears on screen sheâ€™s broken, and her contradictions â€” along with the vodka she guzzles and the Xanax she pops â€” keep her in pieces. Sheâ€™s pathetic, absurd, complaining about being broke one minute and explaining why she flew first class the next. As she slips from tremulous flirtations to soused meltdowns, she elicits gasps of compassion and snorts of derision. Jasmine, nÃ©e Jeanette, having reinvented herself, had risen to become a member of New Yorkâ€™s elite but, with everything gone, has come to San Francisco to move in with her sister, Ginger (played with anxious sincerity by Sally Hawkins). For Jasmine this isnâ€™t a comedown, itâ€™s a catastrophe â€” everything is. When she first walks into Gingerâ€™s apartment, she stops dead, as if paralyzed by its unspeakable ordinariness.

Itâ€™s hard to know if Mr. Allen shares Jasmineâ€™s shock at Gingerâ€™s place. (Mere mortals will note the ample square footage, natural light and fireplace.) With a series of sharp contrapuntal flashbacks that move forward in time â€” Hal and Jasmine in their empty new Park Avenue apartment and then later presiding over a dinner bathed in light so burnished golden calf must have been on the menu â€” Mr. Allen illustrates just how drastically sheâ€™s been humbled. The flashbacks tell part of the story, as does Jasmineâ€™s faraway stare, her mood swings and the patter that telegraphs her privilege (â€œI donâ€™t know how anyone can breathe with low ceilingsâ€ù) and which, over time, will sound like the ravings of a homeless woman you might see in certain neighborhoods, the one in ratty furs pushing a cart.

Once moved in with Ginger, Jasmine flutters about, cementing her resemblance to the mothlike Blanche. The allusions to â€œStreetcarâ€ù are copious and obvious, and spotting the quotations initially feels like a kind of humorous parlor game, from the French connection that links Blanche and Jasmineâ€™s names to Mr. Allenâ€™s staging of a violent skirmish, which echoes a similar one in Elia Kazanâ€™s film adaptation. Underscoring the resemblances, Jasmine repeatedly explains that â€œBlue Moonâ€ù was playing when she met Hal, memories that evoke the blue piano that, as Williams wrote in â€œStreetcar,â€ù expresses â€œthe spirit of the life which goes on here.â€ù In the play, Blanche also says that Stanley isnâ€™t the type who goes for jasmine perfume, an aside that carries an accusation.

The specter of Stanley and his white undershirt lives on, if with critical differences, in the figures of Gingerâ€™s ex-husband, Augie (Andrew Dice Clay), and her current lover, Chili (Bobby Cannavale). Each registers as a caricature, with a broad accent and performance, and a swagger that implies a threat. But Mr. Allen isnâ€™t making a case against them, and neither descends into clichÃ© partly because, for all their macho bluster, the two are openly feminized, as if their libidinal energies were being put to better use. Augie and Chili take issue with Jasmine, but they donâ€™t brutalize her, much less set out to destroy her. She has, Mr. Allen suggests, already done the job herself.

Thatâ€™s harsh and also conveniently reductive: Jasmine may be guilty of a great deal, including blinkered entitlement, but the world of big money in which she moved played its role. So, too, did Hal, perhaps the storyâ€™s only real villain, but who, like Augie and Chili, never emerges as a serious countervailing force to Jasmine as Stanley is to Blanche. As if to make up for this missing piece, Mr. Allen himself advances the strongest argument against Jasmine. If he never succeeds in diminishing her appeal, itâ€™s both because Ms. Blanchett maintains a vise grip on the characterâ€™s humanity and because it becomes inexorably clear that, while losing her money helped push Jasmine over the edge, it was also the dirty, easy money, what it promised and delivered, that drove her nuts to begin with.

What did Jasmine know, and when did she know it? These questions come to haunt â€œBlue Jasmine,â€ù and as the past catches up with the present, they help drive this moving, sometimes funny film toward its shattering end. If at times Mr. Allen seems to be answering those questions by pulling the film in one direction even as Ms. Blanchett pulls it in another, this productive dissonance deepens the tension and stakes and, as with a climactic confrontation between Jasmine and Hal, can turn a raw scene into a revelation. This particular battle takes place in their living room, a mausoleumlike shrine to their wealth, painted green, where, against the color of money, they fight for their lives, frantically taking swings at each other without a thought to everyone else they are about to take down.
â€œBlue Jasmineâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Adult behavior and language.

Stepparents, the villains of so many fairy tales and other childrenâ€™s stories, get some redemption in â€œThe Smurfs 2,â€ù a new, not very engaging movie featuring a lot of blue skin and household-name voices.

â€œThe Smurfs 2â€ù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested) for a smattering of rude humor and some cat abuse.

â€œWhen Comedy Went to Schoolâ€ù mines the rich history of borscht belt entertainment, revisiting those who honed their acts in that upstate New York vacation destination for Jewish families in the mid-20th century. Fortunately for the filmmakers, most of the comedians interviewed here â€” Jerry Stiller, Jackie Mason, Jerry Lewis and many other (mostly male) voices â€” provide lighthearted remembrances to elevate this poorly executed documentary.

The comedians, and viewers, deserve better than Robert Kleinâ€™s hokey narration (written by Lawrence Richards) with kickers like â€œtriple oy veyâ€ù; amateurish editing and graphics; and cheesy re-enactments. Those elements distract from the things that work: clips from songs and movies (â€œThe Bellboy,â€ù â€œHistory of the World: Part Iâ€ù); vintage photos and videos of New York City, Yiddish theater and vaudeville acts; and insights from historians.

In exploring the Jewish style of self-deprecating survival comedy, the ability to find a joke in even the darkest times of despair, the film makes a connection to the language and timing of modern humor. The training in the Catskills paid mainstream dividends for busboys and tummlers (who amused hotel guests with shtick) like Danny Kaye and Sid Caesar. Yet the filmmakers fail to show the broader impact that these comics still have on pop culture.

There is a brief section about Hugh Hefnerâ€™s role in helping comics like Lenny Bruce, Mort Sahl and Dick Gregory get a foothold. They trafficked in social and political issues, like civil rights, but they didnâ€™t appeal to the Catskill guests and comedians who steered clear of off-color jokes. Itâ€™s interesting that their rise (and the rise of the desegregated Playboy clubs) came around the time of the borscht beltâ€™s decline. Itâ€™s a cultural shift that would have been worth a deeper examination.

Thereâ€™s not much new to be wrung out of the wedding-catastrophe plotline, but if youâ€™re the kind who is always up for a calamity-filled trip down the aisle, â€œBreakup at a Weddingâ€ù is a moderately amusing application of the formula.

Alison (appealingly played by Alison Fyhrie) has second thoughts on the day of her wedding to the good-natured Phil (Philip Quinaz), but the two decide to go through with a sham ceremony for the sake of the guests. Disasters of all sorts ensue, and everything is captured by an omnipresent videographer (Victor Quinaz, the filmâ€™s director), who realizes that this wedding video could be his masterpiece.

The Quinaz brothers wrote the film with Anna Martemucci, and the script keeps the zaniness level high while avoiding the crassness that others in the genre indulge in. Everything goes pretty much as you guess itâ€™s going to, but the conceit of seeing the whole story through the eyes of the videographer adds a dimension to the familiar goings-on.

Thereâ€™s not much difference between regular English soccer fans and the undead variety in â€œCockneys vs Zombiesâ€ù: Even when expired, theyâ€™re still ready to rumble with anyone wearing the colors of a rival team.

And thatâ€™s pretty much the point of this spirit-of-the-Blitz comedy from Matthias Hoene. Filled with East End grit and â€œEastEndersâ€ù escapees, the ragtag story is merely an excuse to remind us, all too emphatically, that Londoners wonâ€™t lie down. So when a zombie horde is loosed from a 17th-century vault by two startled construction workers, its chomping progress is less terrifying to residents than galvanizing.

Especially for a bunch of still-game geezers menaced in a retirement home. Led by Ray (Alan Ford), a crusty codger with the lungs of a carnival barker, these fogies are hellbent on proving that neither wheelchair nor hip replacement will slow them down. â€œWeâ€™re old-age pensioners!â€ù Ray yells. â€œWeâ€™ve got to take care of ourselves!â€ù Except that they donâ€™t, because his enterprising grandson and assorted sidekicks are heading to the rescue â€” just as soon as theyâ€™ve finished their bank robbery.

As subtle as its title, â€œCockneys vs. Zombiesâ€ù is mildly funny and easily likable. Lowered expectations are crucial; anyone looking for â€œShaun of the Dead 2â€ù faces certain disappointment. That said, Mr. Hoene hides a few surprises amid the rotting flesh (finally, someone has noticed that any zombie mob would logically include the under-5s), and Daniel Bronksâ€™s photography reveals an East End gradually being swallowed by gleaming tower blocks. Rayâ€™s not bothered: When youâ€™ve fought off the Nazis, doing the same with greedy developers and the partly decomposed is a doddle.

Big bangs and fast talk are the name of the genre game in â€œ2 Guns,â€ù a slick, slippery thriller that taps into the anarchic playfulness that made the best American action flicks of the 1980s and â€™90s pop. Directed by Baltasar Kormakur, riffing on the cheerful irreverence of Shane Black and the hyperbolic style of Tony Scott, the movie turns on a pair of seemingly bad guys who may be good. A reissue of the five-part comic series on which itâ€™s based sets the scene nicely: â€œTwo guys walk into a bank.
