Late in the documentary â€œAmerican Promise,â€ù one of its directors, MichÃ¨le Stephenson, sits next to her adolescent son, Idris â€” one of the movieâ€™s subjects â€” as he reads a disheartening e-mail. Theyâ€™ve been opening college admissions notices and wading through some bad news. The two are shown separately and together, and at times in close-up. (Participants either talk directly to the camera â€” and sometimes to the various silent camera persons, who are introduced in the final credits â€” or avoid its gaze.) You can see every flicker in their faces, which allows you to notice and think about the glassiness in Idrisâ€™s eyes. He never cries, but you may find yourself on the verge.

At this point, you have spent a lot of time with Idris, whose life, triumphs and failures â€” starting when he was 5 and continuing until after he graduates from high school â€” are laid bare for more than two perfectly watchable, if increasingly exasperating, hours. You care about this kid because the filmmakers have made you care, which makes what happens next difficult to take. â€œYou didnâ€™t get in,â€ù Ms. Stephenson says flatly, as the camera lingers on another notice. Itâ€™s one of the more insensitive expressions of parental disappointment Iâ€™ve seen in a documentary â€” until, that is, Idrisâ€™s father, Joe Brewster, the movieâ€™s other director, gets on the phone.
â€œYouâ€™re a brilliant young man,â€ù Mr. Brewster tells Idris, â€œbut youâ€™re lazy.â€ù You may tremble again, this time with anger.

And you may wonder â€” not for the first time â€” what these filmmakers, these parents, thought they were doing by turning their son into a cinematic spectacle. Their intentions are vague, even with the introductory text that explains how, 13 years earlier, Idris and his friend Seun Summers began kindergarten at a private Manhattan institution, later revealed as the Dalton School.

â€œExpecting great things,â€ù it reads, â€œwe set out to document the boysâ€™ entire education.â€ù What follows is an intellectually murky look at two children that hovers around race, class and gender and consistently fails to take the childâ€™s point of view as each faces a rigorous academic regime, demanding parents, disorders and worse. By the time Idris and Seun are preadolescents, theyâ€™re struggling, and so are the filmmakers.

In some respects, â€œAmerican Promiseâ€ù is best viewed as a look at parenthood in an anxious age. Mr. Brewster and Ms. Stephensonâ€™s love for Idris is as transparent as their worry. (Seun faces his own heavy burdens and tough love.) Yet there are times when their concern feels less about Idris and more about them, as in an early scene when Ms. Stephenson talks about a letter from Dalton inviting Idris to participate in a tutoring program. Standing in her kitchen, she worries about â€œa perceptionâ€ù that young black boys need extra help. In the next scene, Mr. Brewster says that some parents at Dalton â€” without specifying their race â€” â€œare spending up to $30,000 a year for tutoring â€” thatâ€™s more than the tuition.â€ù

Itâ€™s impossible to know what to make of these two scenes, which follow a pattern that informs much of the movie: Race is raised as a possible reason for Idrisâ€™s and Seunâ€™s problems, and then other potential determinants (a learning disorder, illness) are introduced. But the filmmakers donâ€™t engage with these life events and issues: They just line them up as if their significance were transparent. But nothing is, including Mr. Brewsterâ€™s description of how they started to monitor Idris, using a spreadsheet in which â€œevery hour of the week was accounted for.â€ù Mr. Brewster says that some people thought they were controlling Idrisâ€™s entire life, but the problem was that they â€œwerenâ€™t controlling enough.â€ù Itâ€™s no wonder that this documentary itself sometimes feels like a method of parental control.

Asking a bug, even a very large one, to carry your whole movie seems as if it ought to be against animal cruelty codes, but thatâ€™s just what â€œBig Ass Spider!â€ù does. Everybody loves a character with absolute confidence, peerless skill and unshakable cool. The square-jawed gangster known as Boss (the undeniably appealing Akshay Kumar) is that kind of guy. Between lethal kicks, as he easily dispatches 10 or 12 tough guys, Boss â€” whose agility is beyond Olympian â€” does a few dance steps and smiles. This is a man who prefers to fight to music, which is good, because sometimes that drowns out the sounds of all those necks being snapped.

There are matters worth caring about here, including a heartbreaking father-son rift and an older sonâ€™s touching loyalty to his little brother. There are Bollywood musical numbers, of course, with fabulously aggressive choreography and the usual over-the-top array of gorgeous scenery, pointless costume changes and dramatic, sexy poses. But mostly there are explosions, huge knives, broken glass and blood. Ten times, you think, this is the big finish. You wish it were.

â€œBossâ€ù is billed as an action comedy, but it isnâ€™t always clear what is part of the joke and what isnâ€™t. Surely the soap-opera-melodramatic music cues are ironic. As are lines like the accusation an older father makes to a shamelessly corrupt policeman: â€œYouâ€™re misusing your power and position.â€ù The young moviegoers sitting behind me laughed loudest when Bossâ€™s frail father reacted to learning the truth about a long-ago tragedy. The old man had a stroke. Wow, funny.

The last time we saw Carrie White, she was looking a little, well, red around the gills. She had just taken a splashy blood bath in Brian De Palmaâ€™s 1976 horror freakout â€œCarrie,â€ù and then settled in for what looked like the big sleep. Stephen Kingâ€™s tormented teenager proved a restless soul, though, and returned in a 2002 television movie and a short-lived 1988 Broadway musical that was revived off Broadway again in 2012. Now sheâ€™s back, as they like to say in movie ads, in a fine, largely faithful screen remake, directed by Kimberly Peirce that stars ChloÃ« Grace Moretz as its goddess of gore. Itâ€™s hard to keep a franchise crazy down, especially one that can be retrofitted for todayâ€™s fears.

Ms. Peirce gets off to an enjoyably disgusting and blunt start with Carrieâ€™s mother, Margaret (Julianne Moore), screaming for help in a blood-streaked bed. Thereâ€™s an enormous cross hanging above the bed, and some burning candles off to the side add a nice Gothic touch to what quickly becomes a very weird scene as Margaret â€” thrashing, screaming and to her great and evident surprise â€” squirts out a baby. After giving the infant nestled between her legs a quick look, she pulls out an alarmingly oversized pair of scissors and, whoosh, goes for the kill. But something stops her (divine or narrative intervention), and instead she embraces Baby Carrie, a child to hold, protect, mother and smother until death do them part.

Soon after, Ms. Moretz has taken over the title role, and Carrie has set off down her dreadful path. Margaret, as the opener suggests, is a religious fanatic of ambiguous denomination who has an unpleasant habit of mortifying her own flesh by, say, gouging her pale thighs with sharp, unsubtly phallic objects. Fearful of the fallen world, or rather its effect on her too mortal flesh, she keeps Carrie on a tight leash and in modest clothing. A seeming prisoner of her motherâ€™s madness, Carrie finds no refuge at school, where the other girls taunt her, including in the shower, where, after she gets her period for the first time, sheâ€™s pelted with tampons and chants of â€œplug it upâ€ù by the likes of Chris (Portia Doubleday) and Sue (Gabriella Wilde).

As in the first film, blood runs through â€œCarrie,â€ù first as a symbolically suggestive trickle â€” initially as an unholy brew of menstruation and the blood of Christ â€” and then in great, gushing waves as the body count mounts. Ms. Peirce plays up the storyâ€™s religious themes and Carrieâ€™s burgeoning power as she discovers her telekinetic gifts, even as the dread of the female body that deepens Mr. De Palmaâ€™s version somehow goes missing. This â€œCarrieâ€ù has its share of terrors, certainly, partly because of the seeming timelessness of its deeper, more resonant themes. Although now, when Carrie â€” one of the more memorable screen victims of bullying â€” locks the doors of the school gym and does her bloody worst, itâ€™s a good guess that it wonâ€™t be the movie that you will be thinking about, but recent headlines.
â€œCarrieâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Murder and whatnot.
Displaying a near-smothering fascination with 1940s noir, â€œCut to Blackâ€ù is a mildly engaging lowlife odyssey that struggles not to choke on its own style.

Aiming for moody and landing firmly on glum, the story (by the director, Dan Eberle) follows Bill (Mr. Eberle again), a private investigator and former New York detective. Somewhere between the two vocations, he accumulated a felony conviction, an alcohol addiction and numerous debts; now he enjoys regular pizza and fornication with his landlordâ€™s wife and suffers ominous nosebleeds at inopportune moments. All thatâ€™s missing is the broken-down tootsie who badly needs rescuing.

Not for long, though, as here comes Jessica (Jillaine Gill), an alabaster stripper who gyrates behind glass at a kinky sex club. Jessica has a sick stalker, a shady boyfriend and an estranged father willing to pay Bill a bundle to protect her from both. Needing the cash and the redemption, Bill obligingly staggers through a needlessly convoluted plot â€” propelled by his own hard-boiled narration and perpetually doleful countenance â€” before finally washing up by the bedside of a pustular blonde. All together now: â€œWhat?â€ù

More high homage than actual movie, â€œCut to Blackâ€ù is nevertheless weirdly diverting, mostly because of the impressive black-and-white cinematography of James Parsons. Delivering a saturated aesthetic that manages to transcend the filmâ€™s tonal inertia and restricted budget, Mr. Parsons gives life to cold flesh and bleak dialogue. His talent, and Mr. Eberleâ€™s depressed performance, gradually win you over; they just take far too long to do it.

After a remarkable trilogy of concert films with Neil Young, the latest music documentary from Jonathan Demme, â€œEnzo Avitabile Music Life,â€ù turns the spotlight on the mushier notion of world music. Not that the sounds of all nations gathered by the Neapolitan musician and groove ambassador Enzo Avitabile, the filmâ€™s focus, donâ€™t have soul. But the fuzziness of Mr. Avitabileâ€™s sentiments on boundary-blind unity is echoed in the movieâ€™s slack, tag-along portraiture.

Mr. Avitabile glommed on to American funk in the 1980s, mostly, before embracing rhythms further afield. Mr. Demme drives home that indiscriminate hunger for music of all schools and passports within the first half-hour: the congenial, nimbus-haired Mr. Avitabile taps out a beat on his keyboard at home, listens to classical music in the car and soon enough records songs with Pakistani, Palestinian and Cuban collaborators, often on traditional instruments.

The heart of the movie, whose title evokes a career boxed set, are these recording sessions, which Mr. Avitabile organized for this documentary. These pleasurable performances unfold, sans audience, in a church; each supergroup circle of talent plays under august columns as if in the process of canonization. Mr. Demmeâ€™s camerawork captures the skill and the smiles of these musicians, including Trilok Gurtu, Daby TourÃ©, Ashraf Sharif Khan Poonchwala. Mr. Avitabile, in fact, remains an elusive figure. Mr. Demmeâ€™s portrayal of his qualities â€” an Alan Lomax-level desire to seek out music, a love of his daughters, an interest in Buddhism â€” feels less than revelatory. A trip to his old neighborhood yields a bit of the theater of the street, but the whole jaunt feels a little like a campaign stop, even with Mr. Avitabile revisiting the stuffy basement where he practiced as a youth. Mr. Demmeâ€™s fondness comes through, but he doesnâ€™t seem to get us past his subjectâ€™s tendency to demonstrate rather than engage.

Not that Mr. Avitabileâ€™s investment is fake or shallow, as shown by his impromptu, unstoppable delivery of a history of 20th-century music. But Mr. Demmeâ€™s work here doesnâ€™t rank with his strongest achievements in music documentary, much less his close-to-the-bone sequences with Mr. Young. And Fatih Akinâ€™s transcultural music documentary, â€œCrossing the Bridge: The Sound of Istanbul,â€ù or John Turturroâ€™s Neapolitan barnstormer, â€œPassione,â€ù pose dynamic alternatives to this filmâ€™s presorted vÃ©ritÃ© and often studio-bound technique. No matter: you can always just close your eyes and listen.

Call it one kind of hell on earth: In â€œHaunter,â€ù 15-year-old Lisa is the only member of her Reagan-era suburban family who realizes that they are reliving the same day, over and over. When Lisa (wholesome, not bratty, in Ms. Breslinâ€™s hands) questions the supernatural order of things, the filmâ€™s boogeyman emerges, along with the macabre underpinnings of the past.

The implication of life after death as a risky search for meaning subtly refreshes the notion of eternal suffering, even if the movie is itself haunted by influences from â€œPoltergeistâ€ù to â€œInsidious.â€ù Another undertow is generated by the specter of fatherly rage.

Mr. Natali muscles his frights, along with flashes of light and close-ups, freely shuffling between ghostly dimensions. But this director of â€œCubeâ€ù and the bigger, bonkers â€œSpliceâ€ù scales the ambitions of his new movie appropriately, even cautiously. And lifted by the sepulchral Stephen McHattie as Lisaâ€™s nemesis, the filmâ€™s frazzled thought experiment becomes an adequate yarn.

The title â€œHellbendersâ€ù refers to a Brooklyn-based group of interfaith ministers whose peculiar practice involves racking up sins. These are debauched exorcists on a suicide mission: misbehave enough to invite possession, then commit suicide, dragging the demon with them to the underworld.

There are some good lines. (â€œIâ€™m a woman, and youâ€™re a Catholic; everything I do is a sin to you.â€ù) But this feature film, written and directed by J. T. Petty, opens unpromisingly. Weâ€™re introduced to the group in their squalid home base, where they broadcast each intended sin (â€œlust,â€ù â€œwrathâ€ù or â€œslothâ€ù) as they go about daily activities (looking at pornography, punching one another or wallowing in filth). Like failed sketch comedy, the gag becomes prescriptive and runs a little too long.
But the high-concept mission starts to jell, and it seems like a charming throwback to 1980s films, like â€œGhostbustersâ€ù and â€œPolice Academy,â€ù that featured motley, sloppy brigades of justice.

The cast is put to good use to play the familiar types of this genre. Clancy Brown is terrific as the salty, foul-mouthed leader. The crucial antagonist (their Stay Puft Marshmallow Man) is a Norse demon named Black Surtr, who is 30 years behind schedule of invading New York, so the â€™80s influence is explicit in every way.

But rather than one of those big-budget films cited above, this movie has the humor and insouciant pileup of bizarre and disgustingly beautiful images of a cult classic on late-night cable. Even the nongore images are disturbing and unforgettable, like one involving a bunny, baby oil and a misplaced receipt.
â€œHellbendersâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for bloody violence, sexual content and drug use.

There was an amusing Saturday morning cartoon series in the early 2000s, â€œJackie Chan Adventures,â€ù in which the title hero traveled around the globe tracking down 12 magic talismans representing the Chinese zodiac. In tow are an archaeologist (Yao Xingtong) and a French heiress (Laura Weissbecker), while J Câ€™s antagonists include his scurrilous employer (Oliver Platt) and an artifact-seeking rival (Alaa Safi).

There are scattered subplots â€” primarily one about activists petitioning for the repatriation of art â€” but mostly the film is about exotic locations (including a volcano), garish humor (often at the expense of Mr. Chan or women), fisticuffs, stunts and frenetic visual bombast. As usual in his movies, the closing credits feature outtakes revealing injuries he sustained during shooting. Mr. Chan is almost 60; he has said that this is his final action movie, and the credits also show clips from an impressive career of awe-inspiring stunts. What a pity this workout doesnâ€™t deliver a stronger kick.
â€œChinese Zodiacâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for almost bloodless action.

In â€œIâ€™m in Love With a Church Girl,â€ù Jeff Atkins, the 37-year-old rapper better known as Ja Rule, plays Miles Montego, a drug dealer turned concert promoter. â€œHeâ€™s smart, heâ€™s rich, and heâ€™s good-looking,â€ù audiences are instructed. Though not all of those qualities are obvious, Mr. Atkins plays the character with a perfunctory swagger.

Stephen Baldwin plays one of the Drug Enforcement Agency officers trying to bust Miles, monitoring his every move and disbelieving that he could be reformed. But he is, or tries to be, after meeting a pert good girl (Adrienne Bailon) who tells him that God is better than sex.

Yet itâ€™s only after a flashy pastor rolls up in a white Lamborghini and a matching white baseball hat that Miles can really see Christianity in his future. â€œLast time I read the Bible I saw nothing about style being a sin,â€ù says Pastor Galley, played by the filmâ€™s writer, Galley Molina, a real-life pastor who based the screenplay on his own life after prison.

Rather than glorify the drug-dealing aspects of his story, Mr. Molina also chose to produce the movie through his company, Reverence Gospel Media. Though the story of Christian salvation through romance in an urban setting bears a surface similarity to films by Tyler Perry, â€œIâ€™m in Love With a Church Girlâ€ù has none of the bathos and rigorous adherence to melodrama that make Mr. Perryâ€™s films fascinating. Instead this is a message film with the narrative sophistication of a recruiting pamphlet.
â€œIâ€™m in Love With a Church Girlâ€ù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested) for a scene of violence and some suggestive content.

The conventions are trundled out in Stanley J. Orzelâ€™s cross-cultural romance, â€œLost for Words,â€ù but not the tension or the chemistry. Sean Faris, resembling a very poor manâ€™s Ethan Hawke, plays Michael Vance, a former Marine who has been hired by the information technology department of a company in Hong Kong. How do they meet? He bumps into her as he arrives at the airport and as he jogs in a park.

Anna is also new in town, joined by her cynical, randy roommate, Mei Mei (Joman Chiang). Both perform in the troupe of a taskmaster (Terence Yin) who may covet Anna. But she remains wistful over a lost love of her own. As they stroll in postcard locations around the city, sharing lessons in English and Chinese, Michael and Anna cultivate a relationship that ultimately takes them to her familyâ€™s rural mainland home for the Chinese New Year.

When Anna takes him to a Mass at her familyâ€™s â€œunderground churchâ€ù â€” as opposed to what she calls the local â€œpatriotic Catholic churchâ€ù â€” the service is raided by soldiers. Michael fights them, only to be thrown in jail and deported. Hope endures, but not for this movie.

Every Monday, Marcelle Danan, a French art dealer in Los Angeles, picks up William Laga, an artist she represents. They buy canvases and paints, and then Mr. Laga creates: abstract maplike visions blending hues and textures. Since Mr. Laga is a schizophrenic whom Ms. Danan met on the street, â€œMondays With William,â€ù a spare, cleareyed documentary by Steve Beebe, starts out as a feel-good film about artâ€™s power to reclaim lives but becomes a commentary on the homeless and the mentally ill among them.

Triumphant in his first show at Ms. Dananâ€™s gallery, Mr. Laga becomes a small sensation on the Los Angeles art scene. The sales pay the rent for a studio where he lives and works for a year. â€œMondays With William,â€ù though, moves beyond this pleasant fable to the troubled one afterward, where dragons be. Subsequent shows donâ€™t do well; customers â€œtalk about helping,â€ù Ms. Danan notes ruefully, â€œbut they donâ€™t help.â€ù Mr. Lagaâ€™s demons also regroup: his studio is contaminated, he announces; he must leave.

For audiences of â€œThe Soloistâ€ù â€” the dramatization of a Los Angeles Times columnistâ€™s relationship with Nathaniel Ayers, a homeless schizophrenic musician â€” this is familiar turf. But Mr. Laga, who speaks of government conspiracies against him and of pulling out his teeth to stop the â€œmessagesâ€ù he receives through his fillings, wonâ€™t acknowledge he even has a condition, let alone see a doctor. â€œMondaysâ€ù bravely shows the complications of a broken life that refuses easy fixes, because there are none. Thanks to Ms. Danan, Mondays are taken care of; itâ€™s the rest of the week thatâ€™s the problem.

The problems with â€œParadise,â€ù Diablo Codyâ€™s first directing effort and fourth produced screenplay, begin almost immediately as its damaged heroine, the ickily named Lamb (Julianne Hough), sits on a beach and â€” in singularly annoying voice-over â€” catches us up on her life so far. This cheap trick might help Ms. Cody avoid actually showing us things, but it doesnâ€™t bode well for whatâ€™s to come.

â€œThe old me was content, virtuous,â€ù Lamb tells us, referring to her home-schooled, church-filled upbringing in a small Montana town. But that was before the plane crash that left her burned in body and sour in spirit. Determined to experience the earthly pleasures so far denied her, Lamb packs her bags, elbows aside God and her scandalized parents (Holly Hunter and Nick Offerman) and heads for Las Vegas. Before this is over, she might even embrace evolution.

Like much of Ms. Codyâ€™s work, â€œParadiseâ€ù plays out in quippy sound bites, only this time they feel entirely unsuited to Lambâ€™s sheltered background. Accordingly, neither the character nor the dialogue â€” too tired to be funny, too vinegary to excite warmth and too dull to skewer the filmâ€™s fundamentalist underpinnings â€” jells, leaving Ms. Hough hobbled in more ways than one. Virtually devoid of makeup, and with her marvelously mobile body encased in thick compression garments, sheâ€™s unrecognizable as the â€œDancing With the Starsâ€ù alum whose moves could make a camera sit up and beg. Here, sheâ€™s a sweet but indistinct presence with a generic prettiness and middling acting skills that lack the zing required to snag our attention.

â€œIâ€™m a slut!â€ù Lamb crows, perched chastely on a couch alongside a friendly bartender (Russell Brand, mercifully subdued and hence slightly more palatable than usual). Together, he and a weary lounge singer (played to low-key perfection by Octavia Spencer) act as Lambâ€™s guides to a Vegas that badly needs a break from Hollywood screenplays. (Dare we hope that â€œLast Vegas,â€ù a â€œHangoverâ€ù for codgers, due out soon, is accurately titled?)

Youâ€™d never know that much of the filming took place in New Orleans. The exterior shots feel strangely lifeless; even the Fremont Street zip line seems to sag. This lethargy extends to the unimaginative, television-ready framing and messy medium shots that never bring Lambâ€™s journey into focus. Seesawing between wide-eyed ignorance and knee-jerk bigotry, the character seems burdened by at least two unreconciled personalities. Unfortunately, neither one is worth the price of admission.
â€œParadiseâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Pill-popping, hooker-whispering and one-armed-bandit pulling.

Based on stage shows in Berlin in 2010-11, â€œPeaches Does Herselfâ€ù records a body-positive rock opera starring the happily raunchy, ditty-slinging singer of the title. The fan-friendly hit list spans electro thunks, guitar-riffing glam chants and even ballads as Peaches â€” an elfin figure at the center of yonic and phallic sets and costumes â€” moves from innocence to experience. Itâ€™s a mix of brash celebration and sexual-wilderness heartbreak.

The simple, herky-jerky story begins with Peaches fiddling with her drum machine on an outsize bed. A muse emerges from a giant flying vagina and spurs her to embrace abrasiveness. Peaches bellows and bops her way through a bunch of songs before encountering her supreme vision of beauty in an Amazonian Adonis, a transsexual apparition (Danni Daniels) who overshadows our heroâ€™s ithyphallic drag outfit. The two nuzzle in a number merging â€œEinstein on the Beachâ€ù with keyboard noodling.

Feeling a little stage-bound because of frequent far-back long shots, the show canâ€™t quite become a true extravaganza on screen. But Peaches â€” even without commanding the screen â€” shines through, vulnerability winning out over bravado here. Even the audience-baiting use of the stripper comic Sandy Kane seems to come from a place of freak-speech-for-all inclusion (and maybe homage, since she appears to play the muse from earlier).

Peaches, who is credited as director, pre-empts criticism with an abortive introduction by a stuffy German lecturer. For her part, the film faithfully adds another colorful chapter to the teaches of Peaches.
Is that political commentary lurking beneath the grunts and four-word sentences of Arnold Schwarzenegger and Sylvester Stallone?

â€œEscape Plan,â€ù an enjoyable enough version of the action movies these stars have been feeding off lately, puts the two of them in a supermaximum-security prison where assorted terrorists and other extremely undesirables are housed. Itâ€™s an off-the-grid detention center, privately run, and the administrators think nothing of inflicting abuses of all sorts. This film is not likely to be shown on movie night at GuantÃ¡namo.

Mr. Stalloneâ€™s character makes a living by going undercover as an inmate and trying to break out, to identify the weaknesses in the prison security system. He is hired for a black-ops assignment that quickly turns sinister. Mr. Schwarzenegger is the inmate he teams with to try to escape.

Jim Caviezel oversees the prison with ruthless efficiency, except for when he needs to be stupid for the escape plan to work. Mikael Hafstrom, the director, pushes the suspense buttons efficiently, and the plot twists are disguised well enough for the not-very-demanding crowd this film will draw. The scenes with Mr. Stallone and Mr. Schwarzenegger are a little disappointing â€” itâ€™s their first pairing as top-billed co-stars, yet the script never gives them the kind of memorable exchange that makes fans howl with delight. But all in all, â€œEscape Planâ€ù does what it sets out to do.
â€œEscape Planâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) because prison is a violent, bloody, foulmouthed place.

Like someone using a thin smile to hide a heavy heart, â€œThe Taiwan Oysterâ€ù employs a comic veneer to camouflage a deep sense of melancholy. This is a film that holds tight to its sorrow while trying not to scare you away.

Simon and Darin, two kindergarten teachers, take it upon themselves to steal the corpse of this man they barely knew and bury it in the countryside. That leads to some standard road-trip misadventures â€” a cute woman joins them; ill-tempered gangsters appear â€” and to a sweet sadness as Simon uses the journey to reassess his lonely life.

â€œIâ€™m not afraid to die,â€ù Simon (a disarmingly mopey Billy Harvey) says. â€œIâ€™m afraid of being insignificant.â€ù Darin (Jeff Palmiotti, working a tad too hard) is a contrast irresistible to screenwriters: a rascal eager to party. â€œI find my solace in the arms of beautiful women,â€ù he replies. â€œCâ€™mon, youâ€™re depressing me, man.â€ù

â€œThe Taiwan Oyster,â€ù directed by Mark Jarrett, alludes to â€œAs I Lay Dyingâ€ù â€œEasy Riderâ€ù and â€œLost in Translationâ€ù as its scenes linger for a few extra moments to build a forlorn mood. Part romance, existential meditation and dark comedy, the film, like its perplexed characters, isnâ€™t always certain of what it wants to be. Yet in the end it does pretty well for itself, despite those self-doubts.

At the very end of â€œThe Fifth Estate,â€ù the filmmakers offer their subject, the WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange, a chance at pre-emptive rebuttal. Not the actual Assange, of course, but the actor Benedict Cumberbatch, with platinum locks and an Aussie accent providing an uncanny simulacrum. Asked what he thinks of â€œthe WikiLeaks movie,â€ù Assange snorts that itâ€™s more like â€œthe anti-WikiLeaks movie,â€ù bashes the books itâ€™s based on and casts imperious doubt on its accuracy.

In the weeks before the filmâ€™s release, the real Mr. Assange has not been shy about sharing his feelings, publishing an open letter to Mr. Cumberbatch on the WikiLeaks site and describing â€œThe Fifth Estateâ€ù in an e-mail to a New York Times reporter as â€œa reactionary snoozefest that only the U.S. government could love.â€ù As of this writing, the government has not weighed in, but it seems to me that Mr. Assangeâ€™s judgment is only half right. This version of the WikiLeaks story, directed by Bill Condon from a script by Josh Singer, is a moderate snoozefest, undone by its timid, muddled efforts at fair-mindedness.

Mr. Assange, who has published hundreds of thousands of classified documents exposing the secrets of governments, banks and other powerful institutions, is a figure who inspires strong feelings, including ambivalence. The intense devotion of some of his admirers can seem like yet another digital cult of personality, while the disdain and condescension of critics often looks defensive and clueless. â€œThe Fifth Estateâ€ù tries to have it both ways, to harness the righteous, transgressive thrill of the WikiLeaks project and also to wag a cautionary finger when it appears to go too far.

The story, flashing back from a pivotal moment in 2010 when Assange and his colleagues are preparing to publish a huge cache of diplomatic cables, traces an arc from admiration to disillusionment. It charts the relationship between Assange and Daniel Domscheit-Berg (Daniel BrÃ_hl), a German hacker who joined WikiLeaks in 2007 and later wrote one of the books that Mr. Condon and Mr. Singer drew upon. Daniel is initially impressed by Assangeâ€™s courage and idealism and dazzled by his charisma. Leapfrogging from city to city, sleeping on couches and living out of a backpack, Assange is like a cyber-anarchist Joan of Arc, a clean-shaven, silver-haired wizard in the kingdom of the scruffy.

He is suspicious of authority, committed to truth-telling and instinctively drawn to the side of the underdog. He also shows tendencies toward paranoia, monomania and rudeness. He hogs laptops and power cords, bursts in on Daniel and his girlfriend (Alicia Vikander) as they are trying to enjoy a quiet moment and brings in new recruits who threaten Danielâ€™s special position. He also, almost incidentally, has a transformative effect on the practice of journalism, entering into mutually beneficial if sometimes awkward alliances with publications like Der Spiegel, The Guardian and The New York Times.

When WikiLeaks exposes the shady dealings of an international bank and publishes video of the killing of civilians in Afghanistan, â€œThe Fifth Estateâ€ù becomes a swift and rousing global thriller, with energy and velocity that recall some of the better â€œBourneâ€ù movies and a flurry of fine supporting performances. (The always excellent David Thewlis deserves mention for his brooding, fidgety portrayal of the Guardian reporter Nick Davies.) But the geopolitics and the news-breaking are tangled up in too much psychodrama, and the movie loses its focus and energy as subplots and tangential themes proliferate. As we zoom from squatter apartments to newsrooms to government offices (where Laura Linney, Stanley Tucci and Anthony Mackie worry about their jobs and their diplomatic contacts), the picture grows fuzzier, and the vital questions it wants to raise about privacy, transparency and security grow muddier.

I blame the Internet. Like nearly every other movie that tries to confront that elusive, pervasive force head on, this one quickly loses track of what it is talking about. The challenge of conveying, on screen, the special intensity of online life is formidable. The clicking of keys and the dragging of mice; the pallor of faces illuminated by glowing plasma; the little bar, always growing too slowly, that shows how much data has been downloaded â€” these are visual clichÃ©s that seem to be the only available tools.

Trying to show us what WikiLeaks is, Mr. Condon builds an open-air newsroom in the sky where virtual selves collaborate, invisible to one another and out of reach of the rest of the world. Trying to explain it, he and Mr. Singer stumble into hazy psychological speculation and a sentimental story of friendship betrayed, with Daniel playing the part of Eduardo Saverin from â€œThe Social Networkâ€ù to Assangeâ€™s Mark Zuckerberg. Heâ€™s the long-suffering friend, the sane and responsible guy through whose eyes the audience discovers the creepy antisocial pathology of the more famous partner.

There is something a little too pat about this narrative, and about the more-in-sorrow-than-in-anger spirit in which it is offered. â€œThe Fifth Estate,â€ù careful not to make Assange either too pure a hero or too grotesque a monster, turns him, in spite of Mr. Cumberbatchâ€™s enigmatic grace, into a bit of a bore.
â€œThe Fifth Estateâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Swearing and some violence.

â€œIt seems like youâ€™re at a tipping point between becoming L.A. or becoming Copenhagen,â€ù the narrator of â€œThe Human Scaleâ€ù says to an urban planner for Christchurch, New Zealand, a city rebuilding from an earthquake in 2011.

In this film, Los Angeles â€” with its worship of the automobile â€” is the bad. Copenhagen, with public spaces that allow citizens to mix, is the good. Thatâ€™s the gospel of Gehl Architects, the Danish firm that guides this filmâ€™s vision of cities that encourage human interaction.

The documentary celebrates that quality in Siena, Italy; Melbourne, Australia; and New York. It points out the challenges faced by Dhaka, Bangladesh, and especially Chongqing, China, which is in a nation fast changing from agrarian to urban. History is touched upon â€” Robert Moses, Le Corbusier â€” and thereâ€™s an insightful diversity of neighborhoods pictured within each of the cities mentioned. The information is a bit narrow, but the point of view sincere. (Among the things that make these planners sigh with pleasure: bike lanes and low-rise buildings.)

The talk is not of futuristic utopias, however, but of brick-and-mortar ways to create environments according to the creed of the filmâ€™s title. If the result sometimes feels like a sedate lecture, the global journey strongly enlivens the lesson; itâ€™s fascinating how alike and how different cities can be, and more fascinating to imagine what they may become.

This month is the 40th anniversary of the 1973 war between Egypt and Israel, and the analysis of that conflict continues to this day. The war is one of many challenges to the fledgling state of Israel examined in â€œThe Prime Ministers: The Pioneers,â€ù a vivid insiderâ€™s perspective based on Yehuda Avnerâ€™s memoir.

The director Richard Trank did a thorough job compiling historical footage, and Mr. Avner, a former Israeli diplomat and adviser, is our avuncular guide. As a translator and speechwriter, he still, at 84, seems honored to have had a perch so close to the pioneers of the subtitle: Golda Meir, Yitzhak Rabin, Levi Eshkol and Menachem Begin. But it is jarring to hear actors like Sandra Bullock (as Meir) and Leonard Nimoy (as Eshkol) give voice to these figures in letters and speeches because the film includes clips of the politicians in their own voices.

Mr. Avnerâ€™s recollections are political and personal: Eshkol was fond of Yiddishisms; Rabin lacked diplomatic acumen but softened when at home; Meir â€œcould give orders that would have broken others.â€ù He recalls President Lyndon B. Johnsonâ€™s negotiation strategy at his ranch: the â€œsix-foot-plus Texanâ€ù sat up high in a rocking chair while everyone else sank into the cushions of a plush couch.

This first of two releases by Moriah Films, a division of the Simon Wiesenthal Center, is nearly two hours long. (The second part is due early next year.) A bit overstuffed with history and tales of perseverance, the film doesnâ€™t have room for balanced political analysis or even exposition at times. Itâ€™s an omission that feels like a missed opportunity, but maybe that will be resolved in the next installment.
Subdued in mood and palette, â€œTornâ€ù sensitively explores the aftermath of a mall bombing through the eyes of two mothers who each lost a teenage son in the explosion.

Drawn together at the disaster site and the police station, Maryam (Mahnoor Baloch), a poised Pakistani-American real estate agent, and Lea (Dendrie Taylor), a struggling office cleaner, form a tentative friendship. But when Maryamâ€™s deceased son is learned to have frequented a mosque attended by a radical Muslim, and becomes the bombingâ€™s prime suspect, hostility and defensiveness swiftly eradicate the womenâ€™s mutual empathy.

As questions and revelations about both boys begin to surface, the director, Jeremiah Birnbaum, keeps the emotions convincingly intense if largely internalized, forcing the actors to express themselves in small, profoundly human gestures. Fathers â€” one Muslim, one evangelical Christian â€” hover helplessly on the margins, each having paid a price for his religious beliefs.

Slowly uncovering the prejudices that calamity can unleash, Michael Richterâ€™s screenplay lays bare the damage wrought by Sept. 11 while deftly dodging hysteria, wondering how we differentiate between innocent teenage behaviors and dangerous red flags. Most of all, it wonders if we can ever fully know the people we live with, leaving the question to resonate as deeply as the two womenâ€™s grief.

â€œ12 Years a Slaveâ€ù isnâ€™t the first movie about slavery in the United States â€” but it may be the one that finally makes it impossible for American cinema to continue to sell the ugly lies itâ€™s been hawking for more than a century. Written by John Ridley and directed by Steve McQueen, it tells the true story of Solomon Northup, an African-American freeman who, in 1841, was snatched off the streets of Washington, and sold. Itâ€™s at once a familiar, utterly strange and deeply American story in which the period trappings long beloved by Hollywood â€” the paternalistic gentry with their pretty plantations, their genteel manners and all the fiddle-dee-dee rest â€” are the backdrop for an outrage.

The story opens with Solomon (Chiwetel Ejiofor) already enslaved and cutting sugar cane on a plantation. A series of flashbacks shifts the story to an earlier time, when Solomon, living in New York with his wife and children, accepts a job from a pair of white men to play violin in a circus. Soon the three are enjoying a civilized night out in Washington, sealing their camaraderie with heaping plates of food, flowing wine and the unstated conviction â€” if only on Solomonâ€™s part â€” of a shared humanity, a fiction that evaporates when he wakes the next morning shackled and discovers that heâ€™s been sold. Thereafter, he is passed from master to master.

Itâ€™s a desperate path and a story that seizes you almost immediately with a visceral force. But Mr. McQueen keeps everything moving so fluidly and efficiently that youâ€™re too busy worrying about Solomon, following him as he travels from auction house to plantation, to linger long in the emotions and ideas that the movie churns up. Part of this is pragmatic â€” Mr. McQueen wants to keep you in your seat, not force you out of the theater, sobbing â€” but thereâ€™s something else at work here. This is, he insists, a story about Solomon, who may represent an entire subjugated people and, by extension, the peculiar institution, as well as the American past and present. Yet this is also, emphatically, the story of one individual.

Unlike most of the enslaved people whose fate he shared for a dozen years, the real Northup was born into freedom. (His memoirâ€™s telegraphing subtitle is â€œNarrative of Solomon Northup, a Citizen of New-York, Kidnapped in Washington City in 1841, and Rescued in 1853, From a Cotton Plantation Near the Red River, in Louisiana.â€ù) That made him an exceptional historical witness, because even while he was inside slavery â€” physically, psychologically, emotionally â€” part of him remained intellectually and culturally at a remove, which gives his book a powerful double perspective. In the North, he experienced some of the privileges of whiteness, and while he couldnâ€™t vote, he could enjoy an outing with his family. Even so, he was still a black man in antebellum America.

Mr. McQueen is a British visual artist who made a rough transition to movie directing with his first two features, â€œHungerâ€ù and â€œShame,â€ù both of which were embalmed in self-promoting visuals. â€œHungerâ€ù is the sort of art film that makes a show of just how perfectly its protagonist, the Irish dissident Bobby Sands (Michael Fassbender), smears his excrement on a prison wall. â€œShame,â€ù about a sex addict (Mr. Fassbender again), was little more than glossy surfaces, canned misery and preening directorial virtuosity. For â€œ12 Years a Slave,â€ù by contrast, Mr. McQueen has largely dispensed with the conventions of art cinema to make something close to a classical narrative; in this movie, the emphasis isnâ€™t on visual style but on Solomon and his unmistakable desire for freedom.

Thereâ€™s nothing ambivalent about Solomon. Mr. Ejiofor has a round, softly inviting face, and he initially plays the character with the stunned bewilderment of a man who, even chained, canâ€™t believe what is happening to him. Not long after heâ€™s kidnapped, Solomon sits huddled with two other prisoners on a slaverâ€™s boat headed south. One man insists that they should fight their crew. A second disagrees, saying, â€œSurvivalâ€™s not about certain death, itâ€™s about keeping your head down.â€ù Seated between them, Solomon shakes his head no. Days earlier he was home. â€œNow,â€ù he says, â€œyou tell me all is lost?â€ù For him, mere survival cannot be enough. â€œI want to live.â€ù

This is Solomonâ€™s own declaration of independence, and an assertion of his humanity that sustains him. Itâ€™s also a seamlessly structured scene that turns a discussion about the choices facing enslaved people â€” fight, submit, live â€” into cinema. In large part, â€œ12 Years a Slaveâ€ù is an argument about American slavery that, in image after image, both reveals it as a system (signified in one scene by the sights and ominous, mechanical sounds of a boat water wheel) and demolishes its canards, myths and cherished symbols. There are no lovable masters here or cheerful slaves. There are also no messages, wagging fingers or final-act summations or sermons. Mr. McQueenâ€™s method is more effective and subversive because of its primarily old-fashioned, Hollywood-style engagement.

Itâ€™s a brilliant strategy that recognizes the seductions of movies that draw you wholly into their narratives and that finds Mr. McQueen appropriating the very film language that has been historically used to perpetuate reassuring (to some) fabrications about American history. One of the shocks of â€œ12 Years a Slaveâ€ù is that it reminds you how infrequently stories about slavery have been told on the big screen, which is why itâ€™s easy to name exceptions, like Richard Fleischerâ€™s demented, at times dazzling 1975 film, â€œMandingo.â€ù The greater jolt, though, is that â€œ12 Years a Slaveâ€ù isnâ€™t about another Scarlett Oâ€™Hara, but about a man who could be one of those anonymous, bent-over black bodies hoeing fields in the opening credits of â€œGone With the Wind,â€ù a very different â€œstory of the Old South.â€ù

At one point in Northupâ€™s memoir, which was published a year after â€œUncle Tomâ€™s Cabinâ€ù and eight years before the start of the Civil War, he interrupts an account of his own near-lynching to comment on the man largely to blame for the noose around his neck. â€œBut whatever motive may have governed the cowardly and malignant tyrant,â€ù he writes, â€œit is of no importance.â€ù It doesnâ€™t matter why Northup was strung up in a tree like a dead deer in the summer sun, bathed in sweat, with little water to drink. What matters is what has often been missing among the economic, social and cultural explanations of American slavery and in many of its representations: human suffering. â€œMy wrists and ankles, and the cords of my legs and arms began to swell, burying the rope that bound them into the swollen flesh.â€ù

Part of the significance of Northupâ€™s memoir is its description of everyday life. Mr. McQueen recreates, with texture and sweep, scenes of slaveryâ€™s extreme privations and cruelties, but also its work rhythms and routines, sunup to sundown, along with the unsettling intimacies it produced among the owners and the owned. In Louisiana, Solomon is sold by a brutish trader (Paul Giamatti) to an outwardly decent plantation owner, William Ford (Benedict Cumberbatch), who, in turn, sells him to a madman and drunk, Edwin Epps (Mr. Fassbender). In his memoir, Northup refers to Ford charitably, doubtless for the benefit of the white readers who were the target of his abolitionist appeal. Freed from that burden, the filmmakers can instead show the hypocrisies of such paternalism.

Itâ€™s on Eppsâ€™s plantation that â€œ12 Years a Slaveâ€ù deepens, and then hardens. Itâ€™s also where the existential reality of what it meant to be enslaved, hour after hour, decade after decade, generation after generation, is laid bare, at times on the flayed backs of Eppsâ€™s human property, including that of his brutalized favorite, Patsey (Lupita Nyongâ€™o). Mr. Fassbender, skittish and weirdly spiderlike, grabs your attention with curdled intensity. Heâ€™s so arresting that at first it seems as if the performance will soon slip out of Mr. McQueenâ€™s control, and that the character will become just another irresistibly watchable, flamboyant heavy. Movie villainy is so easy, partly because it allows actors to showboat, but also because a lot of filmmakers canâ€™t resist siding with power.

Mr. McQueenâ€™s sympathies are as unqualified as his control. There is much to admire about â€œ12 Years a Slave,â€ù including the cleareyed, unsentimental quality of its images â€” this is a place where trees hang with beautiful moss and black bodies â€” and how Mr. Ejioforâ€™s restrained, open, translucent performance works as a ballast, something to cling onto, especially during the frenzies of violence. These are rightly hard to watch and bring to mind the startling moment in â€œMaus,â€ù Art Spiegelmanâ€™s cartoon opus about the Holocaust, in which he asks his â€œshrinkâ€ù to explain what it felt like to be in Auschwitz. â€œBoo! It felt like that. But ALWAYS!â€ù The genius of â€œ12 Years a Slaveâ€ù is its insistence on banal evil, and on terror, that seeped into souls, bound bodies and reaped an enduring, terrible price.
â€œ12 Years a Slaveâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Slave-trade violence.

For anyone interested in Hollywood deal-making, James Tobackâ€™s documentary â€œSeduced and Abandonedâ€ù provides the vicarious thrill of being at the table. You listen as financial movers and shakers coldly calculate the box-office potential of a project half-jokingly pitched by Mr. Toback and his sidekick, Alec Baldwin, as â€œLast Tango in Tikrit.â€ù

The film follows these two friends at the 2012 Cannes Film Festival as they try to find a buyer for a sexually explosive movie set near the end of the war in Iraq. Mr. Baldwin and Neve Campbell are to play updated versions of the Marlon Brando and Maria Schneider characters from Bernardo Bertolucciâ€™s â€œLast Tango in Paris.â€ù

How provocative Mr. Toback intends his project to be is suggested by an inserted clip from Mr. Bertolucciâ€™s film in which Brando delivers a misogynistic rant so violent, hateful and obscene that it still shocks. But with the proliferation of Internet pornography, sex doesnâ€™t sell movies the way it did in the 1970s. Itâ€™s almost inconceivable that Mr. Toback didnâ€™t know that when he went to Cannes to hawk his concept.

Itâ€™s one reason â€œSeduced and Abandoned,â€ù which is amply stuffed with real-life stars, including Ryan Gosling, Jessica Chastain and Diane Kruger, suggests a game within a game. (In addition to its theatrical release, the film will have a premiere on HBO on Oct. 28.) Because there is no visible script or treatment for Mr. Tobackâ€™s idea, you wonder how serious he really is. Or is the trip just a pretext for making a movie about the film business, hanging out with friends and schmoozing on the French Riviera?

As the men work their way through the jungle of producers and fat cats at Cannes, the outlines of the project vary from pitch to pitch. Nobody is interested financing in a picture starring Ms. Campbell, and even Mr. Baldwinâ€™s movie-star power is regarded with skepticism since he has mostly forsaken films for television. Along the way, â€œSeduced and Abandonedâ€ù documents Mr. Tobackâ€™s personal obsessions with sex and death and with Ms. Campbell, who starred in his 2004 flop â€œWhen Will I Be Loved?â€ù

â€œSeduced and Abandoned,â€ù which uses split screens much of the time, rambles entertainingly from topic to topic. It begins with a complaint ascribed to Orson Welles that he spent 95 percent of his life running around trying to raise money for movies and 5 percent making them. There is hardly a dull moment. It presents an informal, gossipy history of the Cannes Film Festival and includes interviews with major directors, including Mr. Bertolucci; Martin Scorsese, who reminisces about â€œMean Streetsâ€ù; Francis Ford Coppola, who describes â€œThe Godfatherâ€ù as â€œa flukeâ€ù; and Roman Polanski. There is a lot of talk about the gap between commerce and art, and Mr. Gosling offers amusing recollections of his early days in Hollywood.

With his imposing girth and sage-like pretensions, Mr. Toback is a figure of Wellesian proportions who is unflappable in the face of probable rejection. Welles was always aware of his own myth, which he unabashedly exploited in any way he could for personal gain. The same might be said of Mr. Toback, a notorious wheeler-dealer who even by Hollywood standards is a character with a capital C. At Cannes, he seems blissfully happy in his element, rejection or not. â€œSeduced and Abandonedâ€ù may be the yearâ€™s most entertaining put-on.

True solitude is a rarity at the movies, for those of us in the audience contending with yakkers and texters, and for the people on screen as well. The lonesome strangers of the old westerns almost always had a town to ride into or out of, a buzz of social life to contrast with their individualistic ways. Even movies that emphasize the isolation of their main characters tend to provide them with companions, human or otherwise. Piscine Patel in â€œLife of Piâ€ù had his tiger, Richard Parker; Chuck Noland in â€œCast Awayâ€ù had Wilson the volleyball. Those guys did a lot of talking, even when nobody else was around.

The guy in J. C. Chandorâ€™s amazing â€œAll Is Lostâ€ù â€” identified only as â€œOur Manâ€ù in the credits and instantly recognizable as Robert Redford, giving the performance of his life â€” says almost nothing at all. For the duration of the film, he is the only person in sight. In the opening scene, we hear his voice as he composes a letter of apology and farewell, presumably to unspecified loved ones back home. Later â€” or rather earlier, since most of the story flashes back from that moment of fatalism, eight days into his ordeal â€” he tries to send a distress call over the radio and tosses a few epithets at his fate. Otherwise, he is silent. And though this manâ€™s radical aloneness is terrifying, to him and to us, it is also a condition he has chosen, one we might even envy, just as his taciturn competence is something we are inclined to admire.

He finds himself in the Indian Ocean, in the empty waters between Indonesia and Madagascar, on a solo sailing voyage. We infer that he is someone who can afford a comfortable, well-appointed yacht and the leisure to pilot it in exotic places, something he also clearly has the skill to do. Heâ€™s rich, American and handsome. (Heâ€™s Robert Redford.)

What else do we know about Our Man? He wears a wedding ring and an air of poised, understated confidence. In the midst of a desperate crisis, he takes the time to shave, and we might wonder whether this act of grooming under duress is evidence of self-discipline or vanity. Even when he is absorbed in practical matters that have life-or-death consequences, our ancient mariner maintains a sense of style; there is a subtle self-consciousness in his efforts to embody the old Hemingway-esque ideal of grace under pressure. He is a model of masculine virtue and he knows it. (Heâ€™s Robert Redford.)

The ancient Greeks believed that character should be revealed through action. I canâ€™t think of another film that has upheld this notion so thoroughly and thrillingly. There is certainly no other actor who can command our attention â€” our empathy, our loyalty, our love â€” with such efficiency. Mr. Redford has always been a magnificent underplayer, a master of small, clear gestures and soft-spoken intensity. This role brings him to the pinnacle of reticence but also allows him to open up in startling ways. Behind the leathery, pragmatic exterior is a reservoir of inexpressible emotion. An opera thunders in the silence.

â€œAll Is Lost,â€ù an action movie in the most profound and exalted sense of the term, has a simple plot that I hesitate to summarize, less for fear of spoiling anything than because a prÃ©cis would either miss the point or recapitulate the whole film. A lot goes wrong. An errant shipping container punches a hole in the hull. The cabin floods, and the onboard electrical system is ruined. A ferocious storm spins, tosses and smashes the boat. Attempts to communicate are foiled by rotten luck and the metaphysical indifference of the universe.

Through it all, the man perseveres, in his patient, problem-solving way. He patches his beloved boatâ€™s wound with epoxy and cloth, hauls out the storm jib, gathers provisions for the lifeboat and digs up a never-used, old-fashioned marinerâ€™s sextant. Using this, a sheaf of maps and a copy of â€œCelestial Navigation for Yachtsmen,â€ù he sets a course for commercial shipping lanes, hoping for rescue from the big boats that were, indirectly but with unmistakable metaphorical significance, the cause of his predicament.

Like other tales of survival at sea â€” a robust literary tradition that includes classic books by Ernest Hemingway, Jack London, Joseph Conrad and Herman Melville â€” â€œAll Is Lostâ€ù manifests a strong allegorical undercurrent. Nothing registers the fragility and contingency of the human presence in the universe quite as starkly as the sight of a small vessel adrift on an endless ocean, and few representations of heroism are as vivid as the spectacle of an individual fighting to master the caprices of wind and water.

But this is not â€” or not only â€” a parable of Man against Nature, ready-made for high school term paper analysis. The physical details that carry the story and make it suspenseful and absorbing are also vessels of specific meaning, and together they add up to a fable about the soul of man under global capitalism. Our man is a privileged consumer (just look at all the stuff he has on that boat) whose fate is set in motion by a box full of goods (childrenâ€™s sneakers, as it happens) accidentally knocked out of circulation.

It is this catastrophe and the manâ€™s desperate efforts to correct it that link â€œAll Is Lostâ€ù with â€œMargin Call,â€ù Mr. Chandorâ€™s excellent first feature. That movie, about an office full of panicky investment bankers dealing with the unfolding financial crisis of 2008, is in many ways the opposite of â€œAll Is Lost.â€ù It takes place almost entirely indoors, and itâ€™s pretty much all talk. But it is also very much concerned with how powerful men react when their sense of control is challenged, and with the vast, invisible system that sustains their illusions.

Our Man is a more complicated hero than he seems, and shades of ambiguity and implication filter in through the sharply defined, crisply composed images of his struggle. Iâ€™m reminded again of Conrad, and not only because â€œAll Is Lostâ€ù is an appealing and exciting maritime adventure with one eye on the geopolitical state of the world.
Conrad once famously identified his goal as a writer as â€œto make you hear, to make you feel â€” it is, before all, to make you see.â€ù

A good filmmaker will not take that for granted, even with the advantage of a visual medium, and Mr. Chandor more than fulfills Conradâ€™s criterion of artistic achievement: â€œIf I succeed, you shall find there according to your deserts: encouragement, consolation, fear, charm â€” all you demand â€” and, perhaps, also that glimpse of truth for which you have forgotten to ask.â€ù
â€œAll Is Lostâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Our Man swears twice.

Rocky Braat, a few years into his career as a graphic designer, quit to seek authenticity (his word) by traveling to India, as so many young Americans have done before him. But his jaunt is different. After a chance stop to visit a home for children with H.I.V., he decided to stay. What compels him to remain there, working at the home, today?

Some answers are recorded in â€œBlood Brother,â€ù a stirring documentary directed with narrative depth and unguarded heart by a friend of Mr. Braatâ€™s, the first-time filmmaker Steve Hoover. The dynamic of their friendship is part of the filmâ€™s layers, but itâ€™s way back in the mix. In the foreground is Mr. Braatâ€™s relationship with the children, who call him Rocky Anna (Rocky Brother). He wrestles with them, tells them theyâ€™re beautiful, brushes their teeth, cares for their cuts, works out their disagreements and dries their tears.

Many kids, significantly, are individualized beyond simple background figures; they all have a joy that bursts through the screen, their smiles diminishing their arid south Indian environment and their medical condition. When theyâ€™re in danger â€” as in one harrowing late night motorcycle ride to a hospital, stymied by a passing train â€” the editing captures tension worthy of a Paul Greengrass thriller.

â€œNo child ever grows out of their need for family,â€ù Mr. Braat says. That includes him, and heâ€™s the mystery of the film. Though not particularly introspective and never a whiner, Mr. Braat â€” who has a troubled relationship with his father and says his motherâ€™s boyfriends beat him as a child â€” also sees the downside of his new familial sense: â€œThereâ€™s freedom in not being close to anyone,â€ù he says, as death again visits his home, and the villagers begin to distrust his presence.

He worries heâ€™ll become the clichÃ© heâ€™s always feared: that of the white king helping the darker-skinned needy. Viewers may fear this as well. But by the end of â€œBlood Brother,â€ù he is about to marry and commit to a future in a village that hardly has indoor plumbing.

Why? Perhaps itâ€™s because Mr. Braat has discovered the power of love. The film lets us witness it, particularly as he cares for a young boy, Surya, in a hospital: gently wiping fluid from his sores, scars on his eyes and phlegm from his lips. Suryaâ€™s prognosis is not good. Still, Mr. Braat is there.
â€œLove is making someone who is sad feel happy,â€ù one girl says, answering an interviewerâ€™s question. â€œBlood Brotherâ€ù showed me that love. I doubt Iâ€™ll be the only one.

â€œShahid,â€ù a Hindi film directed by Hansal Mehta, is the story of a hero, though not in the typical Bollywood sense. Based on the life and death of Shahid Azmi, a Mumbai lawyer known for defending Muslims accused of terrorist acts, Mr. Mehtaâ€™s movie is about one manâ€™s moral response to injustice.

Shahidâ€™s education begins in 1992, when heâ€™s trapped outside during the anti-Muslim riots in what was then Bombay. These early scenes, shot close in with a hand-held camera that accentuates the chaos, set the filmâ€™s tone: unblinking, human scale. We see a body on fire, staggering down the street, and Shahid (an unflashy Raj Kumar Yadav) running to reach home.

That education continues in a training camp for Islamic militants, from which Shahid flees, and when heâ€™s a prisoner at Arthur Road Jail in Mumbai, where two older, wiser inmates (one played by the charismatic Kay Kay Menon) school him. The system, Mr. Menonâ€™s character tells Shahid, â€œtakes time, but it works,â€ù a proposition that the film believes, even as it shows the ways it doesnâ€™t.

As a lawyer Shahid fights corruption, exposing prejudice and trumped-up evidence. Mr. Mehta clearly relishes the courtroom atmosphere. These scenes, set in slightly shabby spaces with plastic chairs and rickety fans, have a quarrelsome pop. In one sharp bit, Shahid points out that a pristine map could hardly have been in the pocket of blood-soaked pants for two days, as the prosecution claims. (Good point, the judge says.)

â€œShahidâ€ù is not immune from the usual biopic problems. The second half, in particular, feels truncated and overstuffed as it deals with strains in Shahidâ€™s family life and a rush of court cases. Still, Mr. Mehta has done something difficult. He has made a film of conviction thatâ€™s neither plodding nor preachy.

The evil forces in â€œBastards,â€ù the new, grimly beautiful and somewhat unhinged film from the French director Claire Denis, enter wearing masks. These are not the usual monsters that slink through the shadows, growling and prowling while baring sharp teeth and talons. The evil here slips into the back seat of chauffeured cars and smiles a dazzling white smile before grasping a childâ€™s hand, patting a womanâ€™s arm or slipping in a metaphoric knife. Evil like this only needs metaphoric weapons: power makes its bearers dirty but also keeps them clean.

If that sounds abstract, well, so too are the method and allure of Ms. Denisâ€™s work, whose films include â€œBeau Travailâ€ù and, more recently, â€œWhite Material.â€ù In â€œWhite Materialâ€ù Ms. Denis set her gaze, by turns cool and blistering, on an unnamed African country ravaged by violence, including that of European colonialism; itâ€™s a movie that serves as companion piece to her first feature, â€œChocolat,â€ù set in 1950s Cameroon. She has returned to Paris for â€œBastards,â€ù with a story that has the tragic undertow of a classic Greek tragedy and the topicality of a headline in Le Monde. At center are two families locked in a vicious, brutally personal struggle over money, a violence which, as is sometimes the case with Ms. Denisâ€™s films, takes a catastrophic toll on vulnerably human bodies.

With her customary elliptical elegance, Ms. Denis introduces the storyâ€™s individual elements: after receiving an S O S, Marco Silvestri (Vincent Lindon), a captain on a supertanker, returns to Paris. Marcoâ€™s brother-in-law has died, his sister is on the verge of bankruptcy and about to lose the family shoe factory, and his niece has been badly injured. He writes checks for his sister, Sandra (Julie Bataille), and visits his niece, Justine (Lola CrÃ©ton). He also moves into a sprawling apartment, throwing a mattress on the polished parquet floor, and begins watching a neighbor, RaphaÃ«lle (Chiara Mastroianni), who lives with her young son, Joseph (Yann Antoine Bizette). She turns out to be the mistress of a wealthy older man, a man with a dazzling smile, Edouard Laporte (Michel Subor).

A poet of the human face, Ms. Denis fills the movie with close-ups that give you a searching intimacy with the characters, allowing you to explore the creases in Mr. Lindonâ€™s face and the curve of Ms. CrÃ©tonâ€™s lips. These close-ups feel existentially driven (Ms. Denis has no use for exposition): they donâ€™t serve the usual narrative functions simply because the characters are often alone initially. The people here spend a lot of time in solitary, mulling, suggestive silence, a pointed contrast to the compulsory clamor of so many movies. And even when they talk to each other, their conversations are fragmented, sometimes cryptic and tend to open in medias res, forcing you to catch up. They already know what theyâ€™re doing, just like in real life.

The pleasures of Ms. Denisâ€™s films are in the crystalline beauty and mystery of her images, and the way that she puts all these images, including her expressive faces, into play with the fragmented dialogue and vaporous themes. Slowly, effortlessly, the pieces â€” the money, the sex, the bodies â€” begin to drift into place: Justine is involved with a pimp, Xavier (GrÃ©goire Colin), who runs a sex show out of a farmhouse. Her familyâ€™s factory plays a role, as does her dead father and Edouard, who looms over the story as a kind of monstrous patriarch. The story grips you entirely even if Ms. Denisâ€™s worldview here finally feels like a tomb: terrifying, pitiless, inevitable.

In the opening of â€œBridging the Gap,â€ù members of the Vienna Boys Choir, clad in its traditional sailor suits, arrive in a rowboat on what is apparently the shore of New Zealand and plunges into welcome rituals with Maori people. The situation almost recalls a memorable scene from â€œLord of the Flies,â€ù in which a storm-tossed choir sings â€œKyrie eleisonâ€ù in procession on a beach, but the photography here has the color cranked way up, and a plummy, National Geographic-style voice-over pours forth platitudes and edifying narration.

Blithely hokey, amusingly eager to distract and rather entertaining, the film resembles a childrenâ€™s travel show with music-video elements more than it resembles a straight-up documentary. The veteran director Curt Faudon stages scenes featuring the choir charming Indian villagers with a Hindi song or, hilariously, accompanying two guitarists in an open train, through Peru, hobo style. Mr. Faudon uses green screens and keeps the camera circling, cutting away to calendar-ready shots of landscapes, gardens and that rowboat. At one point, a boy holds a sextant aloft.

In interviews, the choristers are often arrayed as carefully as figures on an album cover. There are â€œrealâ€ù scenes about audition processes for this international choir, though â€œBridging the Gapâ€ù is preoccupied with the notion of one-world unity (reaching a climax with a song absurdly performed over a montage of hurricane destruction). But the visual pretensions are rooted in an unashamed passion about the music, and when the narrator is explaining Schubertâ€™s â€œTroutâ€ù Quintet, thereâ€™s the sense of being in a choir with an enthusiastic, if kooky, music teacher.

Who doesnâ€™t hate, at least a little bit, the high-flying wheeler-dealers who recently brought the world to the brink of economic collapse and were never held accountable? As you watch the Costa-Gavras financial thriller â€œCapital,â€ù it may rekindle some of the rage and fear that people felt when the pillars trembled.

But â€œCapitalâ€ù is not in the same league as â€œMargin Callâ€ù or â€œArbitrage.â€ù Its indictment of capitalism is so shrill and one-note that it may just as easily set off fits of giggling, because its characters are so ridiculously evil. It doesnâ€™t get sillier than a scene at a meeting where the chief executive proclaims, â€œIâ€™m your Robin Hood â€” weâ€™ll keep robbing the poor to give to the rich,â€ù and is answered with tumultuous cheering and stomping.

This is a movie in search of a tagline as succinct as â€œGreed is good,â€ù from â€œWall Street.â€ù But the best it can come up with is â€œMoney is the master,â€ù the motto of Dittmar Rigule (Gabriel Byrne), a reptilian hedge fund manager, based in Miami, whose fund has borrowed money to take over the fictional Phenix bank in France. Nothing less than a 20 percent annual yield can keep the bank afloat. Dittmar is the movieâ€™s only character to convey an enjoyment of the mischief he stirs up, not to mention a voluptuous appreciation for the perks of wealth. He slyly refers to the beauties lounging on his yacht as â€œthe fauna.â€ù

â€œCapitalâ€ù is narrated by Marc Tourneuil (Gad Elmaleh), Phenixâ€™s fish-eyed interim leader, who is given the reins after its chief executive has a heart attack on a golf course. Like Kevin Spaceyâ€™s Frank Underwood in â€œHouse of Cards,â€ù Marc occasionally turns to address the camera and let us know the full extent of his duplicity and greed.

Costa-Gavras, the left-leaning Greek-French director of â€œZâ€ù and â€œMissing,â€ù would seem to be the ideal filmmaker for an anti-capitalist screed. But the movie, based on StÃ©phane Osmontâ€™s 2004 novel of the same title, is stiff and didactic. Even the high life portrayed in the film seems pallid, as if the director were frozen in disgust.

Marc knows full well that his tenure at the top will be short-lived unless he takes drastic action, and he initiates thousands of layoffs that jack up the bankâ€™s stock price while destroying livelihoods. Under pressure from Dittmar, he participates in an insider-trading scheme that involves selling the toxic assets of a Japanese bank.

The film wastes precious time following Marcâ€™s romantic cat-and-mouse games with Nassim (Liya Kebede), a supermodel and plutocratic groupie whom he forces himself on in the back of a limousine. Nassim has a slinky manner and likes to eat caviar off her bare knee. But when she opens her mouth, she sounds about as classy as Snooki. The movie primly refuses to acknowledge that wealth and power can be fun.
â€œCapitalâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for sexual situations, language and drug taking, all fairly mild.

We have seen J-horror from Japan, K-horror from South Korea, and now, with Le-Van Kietâ€™s â€œHouse in the Alley,â€ù V-horror from Vietnam. Postpartum depression takes a murderous turn in this slight exercise, which, for all its modesty, generates a measure of dread.

In Ho Chi Minh City, Thao (Ngo Thanh Van) has just had a very bloody delivery of a stillborn infant, accompanied only by her husband, Thanh (Tran Bao Son), and a hastily summoned midwife. Soon Thao is adrift in a malaise, unmoved by Thanhâ€™s sexual entreaties and increasingly prone to rages. Thanh tries to cope with his wifeâ€™s mood swings, but times are tough at work: His shrewish mother ostensibly helps him at the factory he runs, but the workers there â€” in a reaction, perhaps, to Vietnamâ€™s growing Westernization â€” are in revolt. Complicating matters is their babyâ€™s coffin, resting in their bedroom, awaiting a burial and possibly exuding a malevolent force. Footsteps, childlike giggles and spectral visitations haunt the coupleâ€™s nights.

Mr. Kiet is proficient with pacing and textures (the coupleâ€™s home is a damp fixer-upper, scarred with peeling paint and strewn with debris from the rainy season). Ms. Van makes a convincing, implacable adversary, while Mr. Son manages to instill his feckless character with sympathetic shades. Little here is shocking â€” the film may not be rated, but the gore is strictly PG-13 â€” and the denouement is unpersuasive. Mr. Kiet, who wrote â€œHouse in the Alley,â€ù needs a better script. And yet he shows promise.

There is undeniable exhilaration in the aerial shots of â€œGo Grandriders,â€ù as a gang of motor-scooter-riding 70- and 80-somethings in matching helmets, shirts and jackets rides along majestic Taiwanese coastal roads. There is mystery, too, in this documentary about their cross-country ride, but mostly from omission in the sometimes inept storytelling.

The memories of the 17 riders tell an interesting history of Taiwan. For instance,Â a Kamikaze pilot trainer for the Japanese rides with his former enemy, a retired Taiwanese nationalist soldier. Yet all of the groupâ€™s back stories, including a couple on a long-postponed honeymoon, are unsatisfactorily brief and presented haphazardly.

Instead, what drives the story is a slightly more macabre narrative. The film opens with one rider stating: â€œWith old people, they might look healthy, but that could all change within days. You never know what will happen next.â€ù
Will everyone make it to the end? Ages are flashed on the screen as a substitute for character development, and hospitalizations are shown at the expense of interviews.

There is also liberal use of a sentimental, cloying soundtrack to unite the cluttered compositions, sloppy sound and apathetic editing. Itâ€™s like a cheap, dry cake covered with a thick layer of frosting. But even bad cake can be enjoyable, especially if celebrating something as worthwhile as these elders, their long lives and their continued gutsiness so late in the game.

Attending â€œJackass Presents: Bad Grandpa,â€ù Johnny Knoxvilleâ€™s new prankfest, could be life-changing. It may cause you never to use another vending machine, never to enter another bingo parlor, never to put your child on one of those coin-operated rides, never to eat in another diner.

Those things figure prominently in some of the movieâ€™s more spectacular gags, which often means â€œspectacularly raunchy.â€ù The film sends Mr. Knoxvilleâ€™s character, the 86-year-old Irving Zisman, familiar from the â€œJackassâ€ù television show and earlier movies, on a cross-country trip with an 8-year-old grandson named Billy (Jackson Nicoll). Along the way, they stage â€œJackassâ€ù-style pranks and stunts, capturing the reactions of unsuspecting civilians as earlier installments in the endless franchise did.

The weird-sounding mix of scripted narrative and found footage works better than it seems it might. The bits feature fewer life-threatening stunts than when this franchise and Mr. Knoxville were young, and more sight gags, many with a high gross-out factor.

Itâ€™s hard to score big laughs with hidden-camera material these days because there has been so much of it since the â€œJackassâ€ù TV show, but Mr. Knoxville and his young sidekick still land a few jaw-droppers. Certainly the contestants at a kiddie beauty pageant they visit near the filmâ€™s end will need therapy for years.
â€œJackass Presents: Bad Grandpaâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for crudeness of all sorts.

Samer Daboulâ€™s â€œOut Loudâ€ù bills itself as the first gay film from Lebanon. Six rebellious young idealists break all the social and religious rules and decide to live communally. In hot pursuit are the relatives of the two who are gay, Rami (Ali Rhayem) and Ziad (Jean Kobrously), closeted lovers who were caught kissing and are marked for death for having brought shame to their families.

The friends settle in the remote cottage of the free-spirited Nathalie (Eliane Kerdy), whom they met on the Internet. They all marry in a group wedding, with everyone vowing eternal love and loyalty. There are some rudimentary musical comedy numbers. Then tragedy strikes.

During the making of the movie, the cast and crew encountered serious harassment. Protesters against gay and womenâ€™s rights so disrupted the production that military protection was required to complete filming, and postproduction was moved to the United States.
That the movie exists at all attests to the courage of the participants to see it through to the end. â€œOut Loudâ€ù bleeds with sincerity.

Donâ€™t be fooled by the unwieldy title: â€œRemington and the Curse of the Zombadingsâ€ù is nothing if not narratively succinct. Hailing from the genre-loving Philippines, this batty horror-comedy, directed by Jade Castro (who was also one of the filmâ€™s three writers), knows exactly what it is and where itâ€™s going.

Viewers, however, may be slower to catch on, even if theyâ€™re laughing too much to care. Featuring zombie drag queens, a gay curse and a serial killer with an ingenious gaydar gun, this bighearted mockery of small-town intolerance revels in the punishment of Remington (Martin Escudero), a handsome young laborer. As a small boy, Remington loved to scream homophobic slurs at random passers-by, until a furious victim assured him that he would become gay at the age of 21.

Unfortunately, Remingtonâ€™s transformation coincides with a rash of homosexual killings, whose perpetrator remains at large. And as our heroâ€™s hips, lips and limbs develop a decidedly un-macho life of their own â€” especially when his best buddy is nearby â€” he responds with hilarious ambivalence to his new, form-fitting wardrobe and expanded romantic options. The filmâ€™s questionable continuity, bargain-basement effects and overload of gay clichÃ©s may not be to everyoneâ€™s taste, but its queer-eye-for-the-undead-guy exuberance and warmth of spirit are irresistible.

Like a documentary antidote to the adrenaline flow of â€œThe Hurt Locker,â€ù the modest, becalmed â€œNot Yet Begun to Fightâ€ù shows veterans of combat in Iraq and Afghanistan undergoing an unusual but apt form of therapy. These warriors, hobbled by injuries and psychologically fragile, enter a program that treats the guyâ€™s-guy pastime of fly-fishing as regenerative meditation. The directors, Shasta Grenier and Sabrina Lee, delicately find moments of openness in casual, lapidary interviews with five men at different points in recovery.

The soldiers are eloquently introduced with triptychs of still images spanning their military service, and an early shot of an amputee not quite keeping up on a treadmill captures their uphill battle. A pilot is racked with guilt over those killed in his helicopterâ€™s crash; a member of the Navy SEALs touchingly expresses his gratitude to his wife in the the simulated informal tones of a keyboard-assisted voice system; a fighter with an eye patch demonstrates his continuing killer instinct with marathon fishing sessions. The bulk of the film appears to be set largely along idyllic stretches of the Yellowstone and Madison Rivers.

The Vietnam veteran who shepherds these soldiers tears up readily over their vulnerability, but the movie doesnâ€™t claim that casting a reel is a cure-all. With their sensitive feature clocking in at an hour, the filmmakers make you wish only that they had developed their material further.

Joseph Levyâ€™s ordinary documentary â€œSpinning Platesâ€ù rotates among the challenges faced by the proprietors of three restaurants: the 150-year-old Breitbachâ€™s Country Dining, in Balltown, Iowa; a struggling roadside Mexican joint in Tucson; and the chef Grant Achatzâ€™s Alinea in Chicago, which has three Michelin stars. While a lot could be said about each, and about food and culture generally, this dully structured film makes its points early and often, treading water before a purposely delayed big finish.
